This movie is about a silent-screen star, Norma Desmond, who lives in a mansion with her butter. Living in her own world, Norma cannot come to the term with the fact that she is not famous anymore. Her butter, who used to be her husband and director in the years of her reputation, also helps her to be in the illusion that she is still a famous actress by showing her photos that are asked to be signed by her. The stage of being self-absorbed and losing touch with reality is to the extent that even after being charged by the police because of murdering her beloved screenwriter, she still sees everything the way she likes as she makes a speech in front of the police about how happy she is to be in a film again, ending with "All right, Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my close-up"

Call it noir, call it a thriller, you could even go as far as classing it as a horror. Whatever, it has pretty much everything.From the classic narration to a gripping storyline to a wonderful cast, the viewer is is invited to take a look at the underbelly of Hollywood, a seedier side to the hopes and dreams that the machine feeds off. A down-on-his-luck-writer falls under the guidance of an old female silent movie star, then things start going wrong.You almost feel like a voyeur as you watch the plot unfold, and I cant rate the script higher, Billy Wilder truly was untouchable in his prime.It's a classic, I'd definitely recommend this to anyone with an interest in films about films, hell, I'd recommend it to just about anyone.

reviews.review_title: Hammy as Hell, But Has Its Moments
reviews.content: Sorry, I have to align myself with those few other reviewers who found the movie, well, trite. Not that it didn't have its moments -- that particularly riveting scene, for instance, where Norma sits in DeMille's chair and a stagehand acquaintance puts a spotlight on her and people begin crowding around her, how spooky can you get? But by and large, Gloria Swanson hams up her lines to the point where she becomes a TV skit caricature (only this skit goes on way too long), Holden runs his lines off too fast, and von Stroheim mumbles all his lines indifferently (I picture him saying to himself, "Here I am, the genius who directed 'Greed', and what am I doing today??"). Let's face it, folks, this is the kind of claptrap that made the revolution in film-making some 20 years later so necessary, films like "The French Connection" and "Raiders of the Lost Ark" sweeping away the cobwebs of crass melodramas like "Sunset Boulevard" and never looking back. Tell me I'm wrong.

This movie should be tagged horror, considering the big bulging eyes that Swanson scares the viewers with, all through the film! Her acting is so over the top that it grates on one's nerves. Come to think of it, the whole movie had a very unpleasant feel to it. I really enjoy dramas of all kinds including tragedies, but this one was plain boring! I didn't really care about any of the characters' fates.The first ten minutes or so of the movie are actually good if you can get past the fact that a corpse is the narrator, although initially it was probably someone else because he addresses the corpse in the third person. But, whatever the case may be, after the first 10 minutes, the movie just dragged on & on. The butler's reasons for staying with the has-been actress are also weird! He was empowering her delusion and thus making her more dysfunctional by the day. Would you call it love or hate? And why is everyone so accommodating at the end towards a murderess even if she is mad? Why does she get to live her fantasy? Many people lose their mental balance and they are never given such a fair treatment even if they haven't just murdered someone.Had an interesting start like a good old mystery, but overall very unpleasant.

I didn't enjoy watching this film too much, but it was a good change from today's crude, violent filled film. Not to say that it's not a good movie. The plot is extremely well written in my opinion. Norma Desmond, a silent film star trying to continue her career with the new sound films. This film gave me an idea of what the film business was like in the 1950's. It also makes me think and appreciate how far film has come today. Often I pass off a high speed chase or a battle scene in movie and forget how much time and effort has gone into it. Back to Sunset Blvd... The relationship between Norma and Joe is very interesting to watch unfold. Norma can't let go, and all Joe wants to do is be free from Norma and live his life the way he wants to. All in all,Sunset Blvd. is a well written film, but not my type of movie.

Whenever I hear Beethoven's 9th Symphony, I am always knocked out by it - twice. First when I just hear it as it is: one of the most wonderful pieces of music ever created and second when I remember that LvB was deaf when he wrote it. It's a similar thing with this film. On one level, it's an absolute classic of Film-Noir drama. Snappy script, bitter-sweet storyline, characters you love to hate and a plucky young girl whom you root for (and really care about) and on the other level there's the wonderful blurring of real life and fantasy. Gloria Swanson (and her friends who come to play bridge) really were (for want of a better phrase) washed-up silent film stars; Erich von Stroheim really did direct Gloria Swanson before the Talkies came and ruined everything; William Holden really was a Hollywood golden boy who'd fallen out of box-office favour; even Cecil B. DeMille makes an appearance as himselfIt's just gripping. The way the melodramatic style of "old-fashioned" Hollywood clashes with the more "realistic" new Hollywood. The way we want the flawed characters to be better people - even though they let us down over and over again Great drama, and a great slice of cinema history.Verdict: A must for any fan of cinema, romance, drama and humanityyetanotherfilmreviewblog.tumblr.com

This was one of the most soap opera-ish movies I've ever watched, so why was I so engrossed? I was so engaged I had to question my sanity. I don't know if that says more about the film or myself. The only flaw of the film was the totally obvious relationship development between the main character, Joe Gillis (William Holden), and Betty Schafer (Nancy Olson)."Sunset Boulevard" takes place in none other than Los Angeles (hence the name). The movie begins with an anonymous man, dead, floating in the pool of an L. A. palatial estate. That was the ending we'd get the backstory to. Providing our backstory was Joe Gillis, a struggling script writer from Ohio who'd come to Tinseltown to make it big. He was holed up in his one bedroom apartment banging out one script after another in hopes he could make something worthy of selling. He was behind on rent, behind on his car payments, and one failed script away from the next bus back to Dayton.While trying to evade the repo men he wound up on the property of Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), an older actress whose best days were behind her. When he met her she mistook him for the man who was there to bury her pet chimp. That should give you an idea of how eccentric she was. She lived in an enormous, gaudy mansion with only her butler as company. It was garishly decked out with mostly photos of herself. As Joe tried to sheepishly leave Norma's home due to the mistaken identity it came out that he was a writer. This tidbit interested Norma because she had a script she wanted to have made into a movie. It seemed this was a fortuitous break for both Norma and Joe--she wanted her script professionally typed and movie-ready while Joe needed money in the worst way. So the two were paired together.It wasn't long before Joe realized that he was more than just a simple ghostwriter for Norma. She essentially claimed him, and what Norma wants Norma gets.This movie was brought to life by Gloria Swanson. She was spectacular. She was nominated for an Oscar for her role, and if I had a say she would've won it. I cannot overstate how wonderful she was. She played the delusional older actress role so grandly and so expertly that you'd think that was her true personality. The character Norma Desmond was always on stage whether she had an audience of none or many, whether they were close friends or strangers, she had to put on. I already believe that the acting in the 40's and 50's was exaggerated anyway, but she was so exaggerated in her behavior, mannerisms, and speech that it created the perfect effect.She and the movie reminded so much of a childhood favorite of mine: "Mommie Dearest" starring Faye Dunaway as Joan Crawford. The two movies are a little different, yet so similar and I loved "Mommie Dearest." Until now, that movie was the standard for the aged actress refusing to admit her career is over. "Sunset Blvd." has supplanted "Mommie Dearest" and, I believe, set the bar so high that no other movie should even attempt to reach it.I'll even go one step further. This movie about Hollywood and the film industry is the best such movie I've ever seen. That's a list that includes "The Player," "State and Main," "S1m0ne," "Hollywood Shuffle," and others.

reviews.review_title: Gloria Swanson Gives the Performance of the Century
reviews.content: Exactly in the middle of the 20th century, Gloria Swanson delivered one of the best performances in film history. I have seen this movie countless times, but I can always find something new to admire. Watching it as an old person is very different from watching it young when I thought Swanson's portrayal of Norma Desmond was camp; now it seems like pure pathos. The style of the film is noir, melodramatic and eerily gothic, but Swanson's best scenes are not only the classic descending the staircase or snapping "I am big; it's the pictures that got small." The scene in which she begs Joe (William Holden) to love her is heartbreaking. I used to feel a bit sorry for Joe, bamboozled as he was into her trap; not so now. Holden's character is a liar and an absolute cad. Even when he seems to genuinely care for her after the suicide attempt, he is really caring only for himself. When the movie was released in 1950 the idea of a woman of 50--who we are told has been washed up for the previous 20 years, which means she must have been through at 30-- falling for a man half her age must have been shocking. But it really does tell the story of how Hollywood treated its great leading ladies. No such revulsion for the male matinee idols who regularly played love scenes with girls half their age. In Sunset Boulevard, we are told in so many scenes that Joe was practically nauseated by the idea of making love to her, but he is such a user that he continues to feed her delusions. It is also interesting to note that we are never shown a sexual scene, certainly not one of those deep kisses that Humphrey Bogart and Gary Cooper regularly planted on actresses who should have been playing their daughters. Is Sunset Boulevard over the top? You bet, way over, and I cannot get enough of it.

reviews.review_title: Gave it another chance still don't like it...
reviews.content: Tried to watch it again last night with the same result. I just simply don't care about either Norma Desmond or Joe Gillie. Gloria Swanson is just too hideous to look at . All that clenched teeth, bugged out eyes,and spider like movements. It's a great performance I suppose, but not one that in any way gains sympathy.If anything she's repulsive. Holden is Holden. If you like him you probably like the movie. I'm not a Holden fan but I thought the film would be great in spite of him. Like for example Bridge on the River Kwai. However he doesn't help things here and to me he is just too boring of an actor to be of interest. Kind of like Joel McCrea or Van Johnson. Add to that the narration. It's funny at times, nicely cynical as well. But there's too much of it. The movie is over-narrated and by a guy who is dead. Wilder doesn't allow the scenes to breath. Holden's narrator continually interrupts to tell us what is going on. All in all Sunset Blvd. is one classic that doesn't hold up.

reviews.review_title: One of the rare few movies that kept me glued to the screen....
reviews.content: One of the rare few films that kept me glued to the screen from beginning to end. Gloria Swanson's performance as Norma Desmond made me see her as sexy yet insane.  That's not strange now, is it?  Who cares?  The movie is still a wonder and pure enjoyment.  I particularly love the cinematography and the shot selections.  I admired that most about the film...  I give the film an "A+" and a 10 out of 10...

SUNSET BOULEVARD (1950) is a film that I discovered in my youth that has always stuck with me. And it's just as powerful, emotional, and memorable over 70 years after it came out in theaters. THE ultimate scathing indictment and essay on the cold, ruthless nature of Hollywood. The film was nominated for 11 Oscars, won 3, and should have won more, but especially Gloria Swanson, who was nominated Best Actress, should have won. This is probably one of the top 10 performances in history that didn't win an Oscar. And her competition wasn't exactly shabby as she was up against dual All About Eve threats Bette Davis and Anne Baxter, as well as Eleanor Parker for Caged, and the actual winner Judy Holliday for Born Yesterday. The popular take it should have come down to Swanson and Davis, but that Baxter took votes that might have gone to both of those ladies, so that Holliday managed to steal the award due to the split voting. No matter, Swanson is the one who should have won the gold. Her performance is by far one of the most fascinating and unforgettable in film history.Sunset Boulevard tells the tale of struggling Hollywood writer Joe Gillis (played superbly by Best Actor nominee William Holden) who is in heavy debt and being chased by collectors one evening when he manages to escape them and hide his car in the garage of what he thinks is an abandoned mansion. Turns out, the mansion belongs to Norma Desmond (Swanson), an aging silent film star who has all been but forgotten by "modern" Hollywood. The talkies have taken over and so Norma is outdated. When Joe tells Norma that he's a writer, she enlists his help in touching up a script she's been writing and Joe uses this as an opportunity for free room and board. Norma also has a very loyal servant named Max (brilliantly played by Best Supporting Actor nominee Erich von Stroheim who was also a silent film director in real life). Rounding out the quartet of acting nominees is Nancy Olson, who was nominated Best Supporting Actress for her role as Betty Schaefer, a young girl who is a struggling writer that falls in love with Joe.The flawless script is loaded with endless sarcasm and dark humor. The movie also has a very Gothic horror element to it as Norma's huge, empty mansion is creepy and cold. The 4 main performances are great. Swanson is gloriously over the top, playing Norma as if the world is her eternal stage. Holden is exceptional as Joe, who is actually the film's protagonist with the most screen time and one could claim the plot revolves as much around his character's struggle to break free of Norma's hold as it does on Norma's descent into madness. Von Stroheim is menacing and stone-faced as the creepy Max, who is happy to accommodate Norma's delusions of grandeur. And Olson is very good as the pure and innocent young girl blissfully ignorant to Joe's impossible situation.The great Billy Wilder directed this all time classic and was nominated Best Director and should have won. No question this film deserved Best Picture. Ironically, it lost to All About Eve, another biting film about the ruthlessness in the entertainment industry. As great a All About Eve is, it is second place in 1950 to Sunset Boulevard as far as I'm concerned. At least Sunset Boulevard is a film with a ton of Oscar nods that is deserving, unlike most films in history. To this day, no other film has captured the tragic underbelly of Hollywood when fame is fleeting and big stars become has beens. A biting, sarcastic, thrilling, tense masterpiece of a movie.

reviews.review_title: Wilder's best, Holden's best, one of the best.
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's classic SUNSET BLVD. is probably Hollywood's best self-loathing look at itself. William Holden is great as a struggling screenwriter running from his creditors who encounters has-been silent film star Gloria Swanson (who is pretty much playing herself in the guise of Norma Desmond). Her tragic character and her decaying palace of a home are very heavy and very dark, the kind of thing that only a great comedy directer like Billy Wilder could give us. Erich Von Strohiem appears as Swanson's butler who was a silent film director (as the actor was in real life). The truth of these performances is part of what makes the film's statement about Hollywood so delightfully bitter. Watching this film will prove to anyone that the hype and reputation are entirely justified. The film viewer of today can appreciate the connection to David Lynch's supposed homage MULHOLLAND DR. about another dark tale associated with another L.A. street. See both films, but see this one first.

reviews.review_title: After A Decade, It Seems Better Than Ever
reviews.content: Deservedly a classic of American movies. It holds up in spite o the ongoing parodies on the Carol Burnett Show, which sank some lesser movies. (Maybe they were homages as well as parodies.) A very dark movie, with everything right ion place. Holden is excellent, though at times his voice-over narration is a little arch. Swanson is fascinating. (What could this possibly have been like with Wilder's original choices -- Mae West for Norma and Montgomery Clift? Clift would have been good but West, much as I love her, would have sunk it.) Holden's interest in Nancy Olson has never quite made sense to me. She is attractive and appealing but her wholesomeness breaks the mood. That may have been the writer and director's intention. If so, I'd call it misguided. But who am I? Bill Wilder is one of the finest directors this country has ever known and I do not propose to second-guess him.

reviews.review_title: A masterpiece of a character study
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard is a 1950 film about Joe Gillis (William Holden), an unsuccessful screenwriter, and his time with Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), an old silent film star who is still completely obsessed with herself. The film begins in a peculiar way. It is narrated by the character of Joe Gillis and starts off by showing his body in a pool, we know he dies from the start. This is actually my only flaw with the entire film, although it is very minor. I thought it would have made for an interesting twist if we didn't know, but I could be wrong and the fact that we know the entire time may have helped the film rather than hindered it. Gloria Swanson is the true star of this film. As William Holden's character has no real money left, he eventually stumbles upon Norma Desmond's home. He stays with her for the duration of the film as she gradually delves into disillusionments, self-obsession, shallowness, and pure insanity about her previous film career.This film is truly a strong character study. Quite possibly the best around. We really get into the psychology of Gloria Swanson's character and her performance does an unbelievable job of portraying it. Right from the start, we can tell something is off. She is clearly obsessed with herself but at first, it just seems like a typical stuck-up film star who only cares about herself. It gives the perception of being normal at first glance. But, as the film proceeds, we realize she isn't normal. She will go to any lengths to proceed with her disillusionment as much as possible, she wants her glory days back, not realizing she never will. Max (Erich von Stroheim) is Norma Desmond's butler and only helps with her disillusionment. He keeps it up and allows it to happen. We don't know why until towards the end, but it makes sense as it reaches the point. Joe Gillis stays with Norma to fix a script she wrote. He knows it's horrible, but he has a comfortable place to stay and basically infinite amounts of money. He's satisfied. We don't really get extremely in depth with his character, but I'm okay with that. It needed to stay focused on Norma as it did. The movie is masterfully directed by Billy Wilder, as he usually does. John F. Seitz provides the film's cinematography that gives it the distinct film noir look. I don't have a whole lot more to say about this film but it truly is a masterpiece filled with multiple haunting and memorable moments.

Joe Gillis (William Holden) is a Hollywood writer struggling to find work and pay off his debts. He unintentionally ends up parking in the driveway of a dilapidated mansion owned by Norman Desmond (Gloria Swanson), a mostly forgotten movie star of the silent era. Joe has writing skills and lacks money; Norma has loads of money but needs a writer to help her with a screenplay that she intends for her comeback. So the arrangement is made: Joe becomes a working resident as Norma falls in love with him.In addition to Joe and Norma, two other characters in smaller roles have major impact. Firstly, there is Max von Mayerling (Erich von Stroheim), Norma's dedicated (one could say pathologically dedicated) butler who has other past associations with Norma. Secondly, there is Betty Schaefer (Nancy Olson), a studio screenplay analyst with writing aspirations of her own including a collaboration with Joe.Joe's mindset lands somewhere between the opposite extremes of Norma and Betty. Norma fully believes in the illusion of Hollywood success and happiness. On the other hand, Betty is very clear and grounded about where she stands within the Hollywood system and she's found contentment with her lot - all this at the age of twenty-two. Joe begins to think less like Norma and more like Betty about his own situation before other events take a serious turn.One of the many praises of "Sunset Boulevard" is its parallel to real life especially with the choice of players who, in many cases, play themselves. Swanson, like Desmond, was a great silent screen star who failed to make the transition to talkies (this is difficult to believe considering her great work in this film). During a scene involving a bridge game, Norma's guests are Buster Keaton, Anna Q. Nilsson, and H. B. Warner, all former silent screen stars whose fame went to oblivion like that of Desmond/Swanson. And one of the best scenes involves Cecil B DeMille who also plays himself as a director working at a Paramount studio as Norma visits him. It is one of the warmest scenes in the film as DeMille shows paternal kindness to Desmond even if he's being somewhat deceptive - unable to tell her the truth about the film she wants to make. It's also one of the rare moments Norma feels at ease, surrounded by praise and attention - even if some of it is insincere.Director/co-writer Billy Wilder gets so much out of his fine cast. As the main character, Holden draws sympathy as someone acting unethically but whose situation is so desperate, he is easy to understand; as an extremely enabling co-dependent, von Stroheim's Max might be laughable at times but he shows genuine sadness when the collective illusion starts being exposed. His action in the final scene is shocking even if it is genuinely in character; as the story's anchor, Olson manages to bring a sweet charm to the smartest character who can see through all the Hollywood illusions; but Swanson truly stands out in a role who can easily draw laughter, contempt, pity, and sympathy sometimes even simultaneously as a super-egomaniac.It is that final scene that is gripping all the way through and well after the film concludes. In the hands of many other actresses, the scene could have ended up as laughable camp and placed the film in the category of "so bad, it's good". But in Swanson's hands, the scene and film end up in the opposite extreme. Her portrayal of insanity is so powerful that it leaves the viewer speechless as it also shatters the belief that Hollywood fame is the ultimate source of happiness. This archetype (a has-been star who still thinks she's famous) was also superbly played twelve years later by Bette Davis in "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane".RATING: 10 out of 10OUTSTANDING ACHIEVEMENTS:Directing by Billy WilderScreenplay by Charles Brackett, Billy Wilder, and D. M. Marshman Jr.Acting by Gloria Swanson

reviews.review_title: I wish I could vote it a 12!
reviews.content: A strange film with a strange, but magnificent, performance by BillHolden. Too bad Holden didn't win Best Actor Award for this instead ofStalag 17. This is a haunting piece which takes us into the mystic past of a oncegreat star and the Hollywood of the twenties. It's as if we open anEgyptian tomb and are overpowered with the miasma.I saw it when it first appeared and STILL if holds. It's a timelessclassic. Let's not forget Gloria Swanson who also should have won BestActress Award. Just a superb film in all as

reviews.review_title: Old but still a pretty good watch.
reviews.content: Wilder's Oscar winning noir psychodrama  "Sunset Blvd" pales in comparison with many middle tier films of today in spite of being revered as a classic. In keeping with the public's appetite of its time, "Sunset..." is melodramatic, fraught with overacting, and promotes a plot which raises more questions than it answers all in the interest of entertaining a movie going public hungry for escape from the memories of global war and the realities of reconstruction. Telling of a reluctant gigolo and hack screenwriter who is kept by a has-been Hollywood silent screen star on the verge of madness, the film is rendered like a jig-saw puzzle with characters distorted as necessary to make them fit the desired end result. In spite of its shortcomings in light of present day cinematic capability and technology, "Sunset..." is an interesting watch and a durable film.  As with another Wilder film, "Sabrina", a contemporary remake could please Hollywood exec's as well as the public at large.

***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** Swanson and Holden, who plays the biographer of the former silent movie-star are sitting together when he asks her:" You used to be pretty big?" She immediately answers: "I'm still big, it's the pictures that got small."Wilder's best performance. He directs the dramatical story of disappointment. Swanson should have won an oscar. The fact that she didn't get it is the biggest screw-up in movie history. The same thing can be said about Downey Jr for 'Chaplin'. The fact she kills Holden in the final scene adds up to what the movie is all about. Everybody knows she's excentric and a fallen idol. The part I liked the most is Holden knocking at her door, and he's being mistaken by Von Stroheim, the butler, for a funeral aranger. Swanson's chimp died. A perfect beginning to a perfect film. A great classic, and although not very fast, it is still breathtaking and very realistic. An absolute A, one of the best films ever made, with an excellent performance by Holden and Von Stroheim.On a cold winter day, staring out of the window, I often think about this masterpiece, and wonder if Swanson plays a role or plays herself.

I love this movie so much, this is one of the best films that i've seen.  I loved the story, the acting and the actors, etc.Gloria Swanson was wonderful as the aging actress Norma Desmond and William Holden is good as usual.  If you like classic films and haven't seen this, why not?  You should go out and rent this film, it's really good and I very much enjoyed watching this and I will the next time I watch it.

"Sunset Blvd." is normally classified as a drama, but I don't agree with this idea. This movie is a pure horror, because the story it tells, it's true. Sure, any screenwriter has been drowned in the swimming pool of the villa of a star, shot to death, but the plot of the movie, it's a true story. Gloria Swanson was really an actress forgotten by cinema, Erich Von Stroheim a German director, not famous anymore and Buster Keaton and the other "ghosts" were really living in those conditions. Billy Wilder wanted to watch the dark side of Hollywood, the underwood of those forgotten, who won't surrender to their destiny. It has been very brave and if you think that he's the same author of "Some Like It Hot", you can only consider him as a genius. Rating: 10 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Constant quirks and a classic ending yet a bit too much
reviews.content: Well the story rolls in very much predictably at the opening sequence. But it then stirs into a quite monotone and boring length of lost dreams, quirks and parasitism. I almost stopped watching until the side romance color came in. and that side conflict held the movie together until it reached the quite classic ending. The thing putting the ending as the starting point of the story kind of reveal everything left in the story once the gun comes to mention. I like Gloria Swanson's acting in depicting the semi schizophrenic old star. Nancy Olson acted out just enough to have the balancing side for the story. William Holden did a slightly lacking performance due to not having used enough facial expressions and mimics although he has so many close-up moments.

Wow... Sunset Blvd. is an amazing piece of film noir that excellently portrays the Hollywood of the 1950s. Gloria Swanson offers what is probably her best performance as she plays Norma Desmond, a silent film queen of the 1920's that wants desperately to be in the spotlight again. In her mind she is a true star, but Hollywood looks at her as a thing of the past. William Holden offers another great performance as the struggling screenwriter who shows up in Norma's life at the wrong time and ends up with much more than he bargained for. The set pieces of this film could not have been done better, especially Norma's mansion that seems like an eerie shadow of a time that Hollywood has forgotten. The excellent score adds to the mood even more. A must see classic.

reviews.review_title: Good but not among the greatest
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard is universally acclaimed. It is one of those films which should you dare suggest it is not among the greatest films ever made people think you're an idiot. Well, at the risk of being labeled an idiot, Sunset Boulevard is not among the greatest films ever made. It is a good film, certainly captivating in its own unique, macabre way. But is a film for which reputation outstrips reality.Most everyone is familiar with the story of Sunset Boulevard, that of faded silent film star Norma Desmond. The faded star lives in an equally faded mansion, plotting a comeback which is far-fetched to say the least. Failing screenwriter Joe Gillis stumbles into Norma's bizarre world and, at the price of his dignity, feeds her delusions. A man's gotta make a living and Joe will make his by brushing up the godawful script Norma has written as her comeback vehicle. Joe will soon realize Norma wants him as more than a script doctor. He is to be her lover, a kept man living in her grotesque mansion, surrounded by the relics of Norma's past, reminders of a life which for her is gone forever. Of course in her deluded mind Norma is just as big a star as she ever was. It's the pictures that got small.Gloria Swanson turns in a performance for the ages. Her portrayal of Norma does match the hype, even if the film as a whole may not. The descent into madness is breathtaking to watch. Yes, Swanson is a little over-the-top at times but that is who Norma is. Especially as Norma begins to lose all touch with reality. William Holden, playing Joe, is not bad but certainly not up to the level of Swanson. Joe is a bit of a dry character, he could use some more personality. Holden doesn't make him into as much of a presence as he really needs to be for the film to truly grab you. Erich von Stroheim, playing Norma's ever-faithful butler Max, does have a presence, a quite ominous one. But as we learn more about the character Max becomes less ominous and more sad. It's a sad world Norma Desmond lives in and that sadness grabs everyone who falls under her sway. Joe knows he has to escape. He tries to find happiness with beautiful young Betty Schaefer, with whom he secretly works on a script. But nobody escapes Norma Desmond easily.All in all Sunset Boulevard tells a very sad tale, centered around the quite pitiable Norma Desmond. Norma longs for a world which is forever gone. She won't accept it and nobody will try to make her do so. Max, her only companion before Joe shows up, allows Norma to live in her fantasy world. She retreats so far into her fantasy there is no way back to reality. Norma cannot be saved. She has lost her mind. And despite the fact she does some truly loathsome things you can't help but feel sorry for her. For you saw those moments where the old Norma Desmond shined through, where you could see her for the great star she once was. But those moments are fleeting and ultimately those moments are gone. Only a sad, pathetic shell of Norma Desmond remains. It's a sad journey the character takes, a journey Swanson captures ever so well. You just wish the rest of the film was up to Swanson's standard. Holden can't quite match her. Nancy Olson brings a desperately needed breath of fresh air to the film in playing Betty but the romance between Betty and Joe never fully sparks to life. von Stroheim is memorable in his own way but his character is ultimately almost as sad as Norma. So much sadness in this film. Sunset Boulevard has a captivating story to tell but in the end maybe there is a little too much sadness. And madness. By the end it veers dangerously close to parody. There is much to appreciate about the film but to label it as one of the greatest films ever is to give it more praise than it deserves. It is a good film to be sure. But perhaps upon close examination Sunset Boulevard is not quite ready for its closeup.

Sunset Boulevard is a beautiful film about a lost time. Two lost times actually. One, the silent movies' Hollywood, the years of glamour in which Norma Desmond lives. The second lost time is for us that 50s Hollywood, the violins playing behind the actors' old American accent, the complete lack of computer effects, the movies that try to catch you not with eye-filling visuals, but with moving stories, even if self-referencing to Hollywood's industry.Gloria Swanson deserves special reference. Her performance is quite amazing, with that accent that reminds me of Cruella de Vil when she says "Anita, daaahrling..." in 101 Dalmats. So much glamour, so delicate moves, all mixed up with terrible psychological distress, craziness, spotlights overdose. The final scene, with Norma Desmond walking down the stairs, is simply one of the most memorable final scenes I've seen in quite a while.

reviews.review_title: DEFINITE STORY ON Hollywood BROKEN DREAMS
reviews.content: Billy Wilder and Charles Bracket got the definite ghost story about Hollywood broken dreams. There's something vicious about the place and, on the other hand, this movie means the end of an era: Hollywood up to 1950. That year means, in my opinion, the last curtain for the so-called dream factory. And in that dream Norma Desmond and Joe Gillis become crazy. She becomes a fiend and he a pimp. The horror is that after 1950 Hollywood would never be the same and we can say that it's the end of the modern era and the beginning of postmodernism -what with the idiocy of the 50's era-? reviews.review_title: The More You Know, the More You'll Like This
reviews.content: First off, brilliant score by Franz Waxman - that alone is worth a viewing. Second, this film defies that idea about narration as a crutch to carry a movie which can't resolve itself otherwise. Narration covers almost every inch of this movie, yet works so well you can't wait to hear more of it. The key of course, it the script. Now on to my subject. I'm convinced that the trick to getting the most out of SUNSET BLVD, is not to let it be the first classic movie that you watch. After recently viewing the restored edition on DVD, I realized how much more I understood about this film than I did the first time I'd seen it many years ago. It wasn't because I'd seen it before. It was because I'd seen many early and silent films since. It's within the context of early cinema that SUNSET BLVD really takes on a horrific and realistic tone. Even the casting reflects this, although it's best if I don't comment on that for those who haven't viewed the movie yet. And if you haven't, by all means wait. Watch some major silent films if you can find them. Then watch some early classics from the '30s and '40s. I'm not saying you can't watch SUNSET and think it's great all by itself. But you're really missing much of the bite of the film, I believe, in not getting a bit of an early cinema education beforehand. Once you 'get it', this one really stays with you. For me, that's the best kind of film.

reviews.review_title: The harsh reality behind the celluloid screen....
reviews.content: The life of a movie star is something very volatile and strange.Their glam and fame make peoples love them,when they are young and at the peak of their career peoples admire their beauty and talent,we call them star because they shines among the billions like a star.But in reality they don't have the life time like a star,in fact celebrity status is more like a air bubble,so much fragile and thin which doesn't stay forever floating in the air,as the time passes it just need a little push of fate and in few moments they became past and no one remember them.But they never overcome their life style which is full of glamor and fame,they just don't want to believe that their days of repute are over,they always live in their past, unaware of their present and uncertain about their future.This is the dark and naked truth about the cruel world of Cinema that no body cares about a fading star not even their audience,a movie star is nothing more than a joker in the circus for an audience.whether it is Hollywood or any other place the story is same.Sunset Boulevard is a haunting tragedy and hard-hitting satire that make us familiar with this dark side of Film Industry,the harsh reality of a movie star's life.The movie starts with a thundering music,showing a dead body of a movie writer in the pool.the story is narrated by Joe Gillis a penny less screen writer without any work,his fate took him to a big old mansion belong to a silent movie star Norma Desmond with an ugly grimace in her face, her career is faded by time into uncertainty just like the beauty faded from her face.But she doesn't accept the truth,she said "I am big,it is the pictures that got small".Joe get hired by Norma to write a script for her movie which she think that make her a star again.He forced to living with her and then came to realize the emptiness and loneliness of her life.At the end he pay a heavy cost for his relationship with her.The movie have very strong script with excellent plot development.They given such a depth to characters,we can relate with them easily.The dialogues are very well written and hard-hitting and also create humor to give us comedy relief.Performance of Gloria Swansion brings the pain and emptiness of her character with expressions like an actor of silent era,worthy to be remembered among the greatest performances of cinema history.Willian Holden also did splendid job as a comic hero Joe Gillis.Direction of Billy Wilder was splendid and daring,he created a wonderful atmosphere in the movie,a feel of dark comedy film-noir with uncompromisingly direct and honest satire.Just look at the scene of first night at the mansion,gives us such a creepy feeling and the tragic ending that leaves you unspeakable.Sunset Blvd.is certainly the best movie made about life in Film Industry.From every level of film making this movie is undoubtedly certified as a immortal masterpiece.The brilliant script filled with memorable dialogues,powerful performances from all castes and above all visionary direction of Billy Wilder and the haunting b/w cinematography combines all together to give us a memorable experience.The haunting atmosphere of a film-noir combines with the depth of a satire makes Sunset Blvd. an unforgettable and unique experience for audience.

I felt sorry for Norma and her sad, twisted fantasy with Holden trapped in that world to make a buck.  Obviously, a time before depression meds, otherwise there may have been hope for old Norma, or at least something to keep her chilled out.  Sunset Blvd. reminded me of a long twilight zone episode, but with better direction, sets, and more drama.  Can't help but think the picture is overrated though.  So what, the film talks about the "true Hollywood", but is that such a revelation?  One need not go to Hollywood to see people getting screwed over, forgotten, passed on and otherwise exploited.  Picture quality on DVD looked stunning even in black and white.

SUNSET BLVD. B&W-113min ****(1950)D:Billy Wilder. William Holden, Gloria Swanson, Erich von Stroheim, Nancy Olson, Fred Clark, Lloyd Gough, Jack Webb, Cecil B. DeMille, Hedda Hopper. A Wilder classic, about life in Hollywood and about a hackB-movie screenwriter(Holden)who parks in front of the abandoned mansion of an old silent movie queen(Swanson)who sees him as her comeback to Hollyood. Legendary Wilder masterpiece, a mix of dark humor and film noir and also of the unforgettable assault on the emptiness and vanity of the movie business is enhanced by the memorable perfomances of Swanson and Holden and Wilder, Charles Brackett, D.M. Marsman Jr.'s Oscar winning screenplay. Great Oscar winning Franz Waxman score. An American movie classic.

"Sunset Blvd" unfortunately wasn't as exciting for me as I thought it would be after hearing all the hype. Perhaps it is because the premise is either too dated or too cliché. Nowadays, sixty years after the movie was released, we all know the dark side of Hollywood. We know how it eats people up and spits them out. There is something very real about this film noir, but today it is not something new or particularly interesting. However, sixty years ago, this film was probably more intriguing and 'groundbreaking'.I am generally a fan of more character driven movies so I did enjoy that aspect of "Sunset Blvd". The movie is well cast and the female lead, Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond, is a particularly interesting character is sad to watch because she is a fallen star who fails to grasp reality. The costumes in this movie are notable if you pay attention to them. The sets are also a strong suit.This movie accurately shows just how cruel Hollywood can be. However, this is no revelation to people who watch it for the first time nowadays. You will either greatly applaud it or it will be unappreciated.

A cash-strapped screenwriter, aiming to save his car from re-possession, stumbles into the crumbling mansion of an aging diva of the silent film era, Norma Desmond. Financial opportunity opens up, but at the same time personal dignity, a writing career, and more purist romantic opportunities begin to recede. And the workings of the Hollywood machine are laid bare in the process.If Sunset Boulevard were merely an expose of Hollywood machinations, it would occupy a niche nestling next to entertaining, but ultimately navel-gazing celluloid output such as The Player or Bowfinger. The fact that the film is an all-time classic tells you it resonates with universal themes, of identity, fulfillment, ambition, and love and all its compromises. William Holden is the cynic/dreamer writer Joe Gillis, self-assured in his contempt for Dayton, Ohio, but racked with self-doubt about his status in Hollywood. That ambivalence makes him easy prey for Norma, a veteran at 50 of an industry that has moved on without her on board. 'Eccentric' is an adjective reserved for the wealthy who are insane, and it is money, and the adulation of servant-with-a-secret Max, that keeps Norma from the gates of the Funny Farm.Gloria Swanson as Norma is electrifying; terrifying and pitiful, and utterly compelling. The excesses of the performance, seen in isolation, suggest an actress aiming at camp, but synthesized into the overall narrative are a portrait of a bipolar personality veering towards total self-annihilation. The younger lover, like her own movies that she screens constantly, allow her the illusion that time has not ravaged her life. It is an illusion her own ambitious craving for more screen time will destroy. Holden quite simply oozes cynicism and compromise. Erich von Stroheim, as Max, gives a performance of single-mindedness, his own devotion to Norma outstripping even her own egotistical self-delusions. Even Cecil B. DeMille manages to play himself straight, resisting the urge to wink at the audience, so that cameo does not come into it.Wilder directs boldly, setting his stall out from the off with a layered vision of a dead man in a pool, staring into the void, prodded at by police officers and photographers. An awareness of the interconnectivity between the cast, crew, characters and contemporary Hollywood history certainly adds spice to the viewing experience. However, Sunset Boulevard is an epic even when encountered purely in terms of the narrative contained within its 118 minutes running time. Cinematic storytelling at its finest.

Here is another perfect movie that tells a great story with amazing performances. I can't give it anything but a ten for being the towering classic that it is. However, I will admit that for me, the script has some weak spots, such as any of the banter between Joe and Betty. It's pretty dated. Ditto for all the talk about writing screenplays. But this is still an incredible achievement, especially when you know some of the details behind the making of it. This is a good one to play the commentary to. Very entertaining.

I give it 5 stars because Gloria Swanson's performance is top notch, and William Holden looks very handsome. However, this movie is very slow and boring. There is no suspense or excitement whatsoever. Any suspense ended in the first minute of the film. The protagonist is killed, and we all know who did it.

Sunset Boulevard was absolutely amazing to watch again given the fact that it was made some 40 odd years ago and still holds up as a very modern film whose commentary on Hollywood is still right on.  Gotta love Gloria Swanson for having the balls to take on this role, given the fact that she was, at this point, a faded star in real life.  William Holden is magnificent, the kind of man's man that never seem to be onscreen nowadays.  Just to have Von Stroheim and DeMille in a film playing themselves is a trip in itself.A tribute to just how amazing Billy Wilder was.  They'll never be another quite like him.

Norma Desmond is the epitome of the Hollywood has-been: a narcissistic, privilege, histrionic old woman who is stuck in the past, failing to realise the world has moved on without her. The casting of Gloria Swanson is perfect, both in terms of her insanely flourishing performance and the meta aspect of her career. Her environment reflects her own mental state - unkempt, luxurious and isolated, existing in solitude and maintained only by the most superficial facade of fandom. It is the chance appearance of Joe Gillis that upsets all of this, triggering Norma's need for affection and conflicting with Joe's career desires. This ensnares the characters in a claustrophobic dilemma that grips them until it is resolved through the peak of sheer insanity. This nightmare scenario is fuelled mainly by the expert acting that brings the anguish to life.

I've heard about this movie since before I was even a teenager, and have seen little snip-its of the film, and have always wanted to see it, but I hadn't actually seen it until tonight - at age 46.It's one of those movies that you hear so much about - you hear the praises and glorification, but when you know you'll finally be seeing it, you wonder if you're going to be disappointed, like I certainly was with 'Gone With The Wind'. The only thing I was disappointed with Sunset Boulevard, is I wish it was in full color. Other then that, THIS MOVIE WAS FANTASTIC!!It was really a gutsy move to make this back at that time, with Hollywood trying to hang on to all the glamor and glitz (behind their mask), because I do not believe that Swanson's character, Norma Desmond, only represented one woman. I believe her character was symbolic of sooooooo many actors and actresses (but mainly actresses, because of the main value placed with actresses are youth and beauty. An aging male actor is still more marketable then a middle aged actress.) There seems to be certain professions that draw certain types of people. Acting seems to draw an ENORMOUS amount of hyper-insecure, overly dramatic, and overly sensitive people - those that just thrive on gaining attention from others. The insecurity very quickly becomes egomania, snobbishness, and false pride when they gain a bit of fame, and then they become professional victims who claim childhood abuse or other when they don't get their way, or when the public knows they've done something very wrong. To show certain aspects of this in a movie made back then is TRULY GUTSY!! KUDOS!! It made way for other like movies to come about, like, "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?", "Play Misty For Me", "Fatal Attraction" (Where the emotionally disturbed woman was played by Glenn Close, who later played Norma Desmond in the Broadway version of Sunset Blvd.), and so many others.I would highly recommend seeing this flick. Now that I have finally seen this, it is now time to own it!!

This movie is a great character study and serves as an insightful look at the aftermath of the monumental transition between silent and sound in the film-making industry. The only major hang up to be found is an issue of presentation which, to me at least, doesn't do too much to tarnish the film.The acting is great across the board, with the standout of course being Gloria Swanson. Somewhat overshadowed by her is William Holden in the lead who, despite Gloria's powerful presence, gives a very watchable and nuanced performance. His role is one which is easily related to by the viewer and acts as a perfect catalyst for the feelings of the audience. The decisions made and the actions taken by Joe seem very true to life for just about anyone and the bridge that the character creates between the absurdness of the story and the audience is invaluable. Gloria Swanson does a spectacular job acting completely insane. Hers is a performance equally as invaluable as Holden's and is equally as layered. Given that the story is centered around her it is only appropriate that Norma Desmond's character is the most fascinating and is made more engrossing as the film progresses as the unraveling story of her past adds more and more depth.The rest of the actors do very well with Erich Von Stroheim providing a performance nearly as engrossing as Gloria Swanson's. The movie is impressively shot and the story well written/acted. The only issue I found was the narration by Holden as Joe. The remarks that he makes often seem redundant and the visuals within the film are frequently sufficient in getting the message across. That is not to say that the narration is entirely damaging, as it effectively expresses thoughts which the main character often cannot voice given the context of the story. A little less may have served the presentation though.Overall, a great film and entirely enjoyable to watch.

reviews.review_title: Glad to have found this gem!
reviews.content: Caught this earlier this month and what a great piece of classic cinema!  A down-on-his-luck screenwriter, desperate for cash, is taken in by an aging film star who has a deal he couldn't refuse.  Thus, begins this complex tale of love and desperation, courtesy of Billy Wilder and Co. Swanson is eerie and sympathetic in her portrayal of Norma Desmond.  Everyone else is great, but it is Swanson who "grabs" the attention.  Strongly recommened!

About to lose his car because of debt, scriptwriter Joe finds himself in an old mansion while escaping with his car. After hiding his car, the butler calls him inside. Not understanding what happened, Joe sees a dead chimpanzee and a woman upstairs. Joe says there is a misunderstanding, and the woman learns that he is a screenwriter. Norma Desmond, the former silent movie star, offers her money to help her with the script. Joe agrees to pay off his debts, and the woman has the butler prepare the room above the garage for him to stay. When he wakes up, he sees that his belongings have been brought from his house, and even though he gets angry, the woman convinces him. The butler Max is actually her first husband, and the melancholic woman sends fan letters home to feel good, and at the same time the man is the director who made her famous. Joe leaves home when the woman gets close to him on Christmas night and goes to his friend's party. They decide to work on one of their scenarios with his friend's wife. Norma cut her wrists when she left. Joe treats him well and sneaks out of the house at night, writing a script with the woman. They then go to Paramount studios to see the director for whom he sent the script. People are nice to the woman, but the director didn't like the script and the reason they called her butler is to use the woman's old car in a movie. Upon jealousy, he calls Betty and upon hearing this, Joe tells Betty to come to the mansion on the phone and tells the woman everything. After sending the woman, the man leaves the gifts and packs her belongings. Seeing this, Norma shoots the man at the exit and the man falls into the pool and dies. When the cameras and the police arrived, the woman completely lost her mind. She thinks the cameras have come for the movie and she starts acting. Max is sad that he could not protect the woman in the dream world he created.
Play Sunset Blvd! It is fast and easy to view! A good way to spend your time. Be the best!

reviews.review_title: A haunting, eerie and amazingly true look at Hollywood! One of the best films ever made
reviews.content: Perhaps the best film ever made, 'Sunset Blvd' follows the story of lonely and struggling writer Joe Gillis (William Holden) who is thrown into a web of romance and feuds with aging silent actress Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) and her creepy butler Max Von Mayerling (Erich Von Stroheim) when he accidentally stumbles across Norma's mansion when he uses her garage for his car so it doesn't get taken. Norma will do anything for him, and she also truly believes she is still famous even though people barely remember her and she can make a comeback to Hollywood. But Joe knows all to better and wants to escape her odd, aging and treacherous ways. He meets Betty Schaefer (Nancy Olson) and begins writing a script with her-and perhaps even falling in love. This sets off Norma who will stop at nothing to be in the limelight, get Joe and make pictures again...even if it means murder. An intelligent look at Hollywood with amazing performances and one of the best scripts. The use of the black and white color makes a grim and eerie look of the film, which helps pull the viewer in. A fascinating thing about the film is that while the story is fictional it somewhat holds true to Gloria Swanson, even at one point viewing a film of hers that ruined her career! A truly haunting and memorable look at the desperate and true side of Hollywood. 10/10

reviews.review_title: The dark side of Hollywood in glorious black-and-white
reviews.content: This picture takes the happily-ever-after myth of Hollywood stardom and shatters it for good.  When talking pictures became the standard virtually overnight, the big studios turned their collective backs on most of the silent icons that had helped build them.  This film offers a frequently sympathetic view of the descent of one of these icons into despair and madness - and for silent film buffs, offers a rare opportunity to see the likes of Anna Q. Nilsson and Buster Keaton in speaking cameos.  Billy Wilder's genius as a director is evident in the way that the very adult relationships among the principal characters are conveyed perfectly, under the yoke of the Hays Code, without the use of nudity or profanity

reviews.review_title: Arguably one of the finest critics on Hollywood whilst also being a brilliant film in its own right
reviews.content: Joe Gillis (William Holden) is a faded screen writer whom is at rock bottom when he fortuitously falls upon faded silent film star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) after his car gets a blow-out outside her house after he is being chased by a couple of dudes from the finance company. A co-dependency ensues between Gillis and Desmond, but Desmond didn't bank on Gillis falling in love with Betty Schaefer (Nancy Olsen) an aspiring screen writer who threatens to interfere with the relationship that has been established between Gillis and Desmond....Billy Wilder is an odd sort of director to me, because out of the films of his that I've seen it seems fairly evident that he can do 'COMEDY ONLY' well i.e 'SOME LIKE IT HOT'. He can also do drama only well i.e 'ACE IN THE HOLE.' However, the meld is when he falls into trouble - think 'THE APARTMENT.' But SUNSET BOULEVARD is definitely an example of an excellent drama like 'ACE IN THE HOLE' ...It's hard to know where to start with this wonderful film, but I think initially we need to start with Holden and Swanson; Holden gives a nice, ill-at-ease quirky performance, although the cynic in me couldn't understand why Bogart wasn't cast in the role? He would have been perfect. This isn't helped by Holden's performance which felt very Bogart-lite. OK so the film is also creepy and kooky, mysterious and spooky, but it's not the Addams family... Having said that I felt that Holden underplayed wonderfully allowing Swanson to shine whom it has to be said was truly exceptional.I must admit though that I liked Max - he's Norma's butler, but there's something very Bondseque about him; I couldn't make my mind up whether he was a poor and stunted relation to Lurch from the Addams Family or a Bond villain's henchman from the 1960's or 1970's - answers on a postcard for this one please....I've joked about the above and yes at times it is hard to take some of this seriously - it is a tad theatrical and cheesy at times, but when it comes to its critique on Hollywood it is practically spot-on and for true cinema buffs this is an absolute must watch.

reviews.review_title: So THIS is where Carol Burnett got it from
reviews.content: During 2002 and 2003, I had the opportunity to see reruns of Carol Burnett's variety show, which I had seen a few times when I was younger.  One of her zany characters was based on Norma Desmond, and she even showed a clip from this movie to explain where the character came from.  Gloria Swanson came on the show as a guest and praised Carol's performance.  And no wonder. Swanson herself was only slightly less outlandish!  This movie may not have been considered a comedy, but Norma Desmond was certainly a funny character, when she wasn't being pathetic.  Carol played the character for laughs, of course, but it's easy to see why this, one of her favorites, was a great movie to spoof.  Max was a straight character here, but on Carol's show Harvey Korman lampooned the director-turned-servant to the washed-up has-been-star.  And this character was just calling out to be spoofed, now that I've seen him.  I don't really see what was that great about this movie, but Swanson was wonderful, even when she played the Desmond character straight. You have to feel sorry for a woman who was once a star and can't bear to live life without the limelight--Max even wrote fake fan letters.  Erich von Stroheim also came across very well, even though he wasn't funny. Cecil B. DeMille was a pretty good actor, even though he just played himself.  William Holden did a good job also.  I kept hoping his character would learn to stay out of trouble, but he just couldn't seem to get a break.

Sunset Blvd. is a excellent murder mystery thats leaves you guessing until the end. There is a great shot right in the beginning where the camera is underwater looking up at the dead body directly above face down in the water and the detectives looking down upon him. This scene is actually the end of the movie. Then the movie starts from the beginning and shows you how the body got there. The film starts off fast with a great car chasing scene. There great sound effects off tire's screeching around turns and eventually one of the tires even pops. The main character Joe soon arrives at a mysterious,creepy,and what seems to be abandon Maison. This mansion gives the perfect creepy vibe to the movie. Right away there's a very scary shot of Norma looking down at him through an upstairs window, a very classic shot to warn the audience something just not right with the house. The inside of the house is even creepier with tons of weird directions and organ music playing in the background. One of my favorite parts of the film is when Norma is standing in front of the projector light and it looks as though smoke is coming off her head really signaling to the audience of her evil mysterious ways.Norma's character overall is great she did a very wonderful Job of play the crazy old actress from Hollywood with priceless facial expressions. I think without her strong acting it definitely would not have been such a good film. I didn't enjoy how Joe and the younger Women fell for each other so fast and didn't really understand the scene where they looked like they were going to make out in the bathroom of her boyfriends party. It was very awkward and strange, as well as the rest of the film but I just didn't think it made sense to put in. Overall its a good film and would recommend it.

Sunset Boulevard was a film directed in 1950 by Billy Wilder. It was a dramatic Hollywood story in black and white film. It was nominated for 11 Oscars, including Best Actor and Actress for Lead and Supporting Roles, Best Cinematography. It took home the Oscars for Best Art Direction, Best Music and Best Writing. The film starred William Holden as Joseph "Joe" Gillis and Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond. Gillis is a washed-up screenwriter and Desmond is a washed-up actress who wants to make a Hollywood comeback. The film opens with a very dark scene and storyline of Gillis ending up face down in the pool. Gillis gives a voice over narrative saying he will explain, and we transfer to six months early at the beginning of this story. In the quest to find/have a script to come back to the Hollywood glamour and never aging brings about greed and tragedy. Norma Desmond cannot accept the fact that she is not young anymore, and that she is no longer a star.The film was dark and shadowy. The lighting through the film was dramatic, sometimes catching a silhouette of the characters. The opening scene of a dead Joe Gillis laying face down in the water, but the shot was from the bottom of the pool, looking up to see the police standing over the pool was eerie. The scene was created by placing mirrors at the bottom of the pool and filming from above the pool. Swanson's performance of an aged- washed up actress was great. In many of the shots and scenes, she is shown trying to portray a younger, in style actress, but in reality, she is someone who no longer has what it takes to succeed in Hollywood.

reviews.review_title: Wilder's Tale About Delusion and Fame!
reviews.content:
"There's nothing else. Just us, and the cameras, and those wonderful people out there in the dark. All right, Mr. De Mille, I'm ready for my closeup."
These are the painful words from aging actress Norma Desmond as she grapples with fame right after she committed a murder. This phrase is one of the most memorable phrases in cinema's history. Billy Wilder has a knack of making such endings in his movies as evidenced by Some Like It Hot. Sunset Blvd. Is one of the best movies about Hollywood. It tackles a very relevant topic as it deals with fame and what happens when fame run its course. The movie is every bit of a film-noir as it is a comedy. Just like Wilder did with Double Indemnity, he created a movie that thrills at nearly every turn and the relationship between William Holden and Gloria Swanson keeps coming and grabbing you until the shocking ending. You can also classify the movie as a black comedy. Personally, I did not have any belly rolls but rather uncomfortable giggles which is by design. The pet monkey funeral sequence is just an example of one that illicit such giggles. Regardless of the genre, the movie is about as good as it can be. It is a surefire classic and one that cements Billy Wilder's as cinema's most impressive director.Billy Wilder had an eye on a story like this for quite some time. Living in Berlin in the 1920's, Wilder was always fascinated by American culture that was depicted through moving images. He had interest in the star system and the luxurious homes that came with this star system. Two decades later, living in Hollywood, he would think about these homes and ponder what became of the Greta Garbos or the Mary Pickfords of the silent era as many of these stars struggled to continue their careers with the advent of sound and dialogue. People tried to guess, but no one really knew who Wilder based Norma Desmond on. It is likely a composite of different actresses. Of course, with Gloria Swanson and Erich von Stronheim being important figures of the era, we see a little bit of themselves. A movie von Stroheim directed with Swanson as the lead is screened for Holden's character. In fact, Wilder made it a point to use authenticity. Cecil B. DeMille played himself. Former silent stars such as Buster Keaton make an appearance. Hollywood's influence is everywhere. It is an age-old theme that is even relevant today as we always see stars who lost their luster years ago try to make a comeback. Wilder's and Charlie Brackett's screenplay is highly intelligent and uses several genres to make a story about characters, young and old, trying to make their way through the unforgiving valleys of Hollywood.Joe Gillis (William Holden) is a struggling B-writer who is having problems financially. His car is on the verge of being possessed by creditors. While trying to avoid them, he stumbles upon a mansion of former Hollywood, Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson). Norma lives with her servant, Max (Erich von Stronheim). His job is to satisfy her ego and make her believe she is still loved by the public. Joe takes this opportunity to create a screenplay for Norma's comeback but does not realize what Gloria has in store for him. As he becomes seduced by her wealth, it might be too late to realize just how far he needs to go to satisfy his needs and Norma's needs.Gloria Swanson, a product of the silent era, was one of the few who made peace that her film career ended and went into radio/television. She was superbly intrigued when Wilder approached her with the script. Because of her healthcare routine, she looked really good for her age. I am glad she took the role because she is fantastic. She is a nutcase, but you understand where she is coming from. I am sure I would feel it if I lost my fame because of changing times. Acting opposite from Swanson's star performance is the younger William Holden. Eager for roles since coming home from the war, Holden made every scene count. As he was drawn into the luxurious lifestyle of Norma's, so were the viewers. Erich von Stronheim, originally a director, is mysterious and more than just the personal valet. He is pivotal in the story and when we find out who he really is, the reveal works. Also, Nancy Olson is good as the girl who falls in love with Holden as she wants to start a career in Hollywood herself.Nominated for 11 Academy Awards, Sunset Blvd is one of the best movies if not the best movie Hollywood has made about itself. Paramount did not really know what Wilder was making as he started shooting without a finished screenplay and worked the screenplay a little bit at a time. The idea about an aging actress in Hollywood is very similar to another 1950 classic, All About Eve. Both are similar, yet different in their own ways. Of course, they both need to be seen. This is the film-noir version of the 1950 Best Picture Oscar winner. It is thrilling, has some unpredictable twists, and is an important character study about fame and how it can affect people. One of the best endings the movie has!My Grade: A+

'Sunset Blvd.' is widely regarded as the first movie which took a no-holds-barred look at Hollywood itself, and the unflattering side of movie-making. Gloria Swanson, 53, a real silent film star, plays Norma Desmond, a silent film star who used to be 'big' and was now just an almost insane shadow of her former self. Swanson had been in 67 movies before Sunset Blvd., and was in fact near the end of her career. Five years before his role in 'Picnic', William Holden, 32, plays Joe Collins, a 'B'-grade scriptwriter that can't get scripts accepted anymore, and is three months behind in both his rent and his car payments. That these two characters' lives would become intimately tangled resulted from one random event, the car tire's blowout. There is little fiction here, aside from the characters' names. The real studio is featured, as are the great director, CB DeMille, and silent stars like Buster Keaton playing bridge with Norma and others. As a pseudo film-noir, it is shot in B&W, which works for this story. The DVD has a great-looking picture, with several worthwhile extras.  A good movie.SPOILERS follow, for my own recollection, quit reading, OK??The movie opens with Joe floating, dead, face-down in a pool, but still able to narrate. Six months earlier, Joe was running from the guys out to repossess his car when the tire blew out. He turned into a driveway and into the garage of an apparently empty and dilapidated mansion. He is invited in, thinking he was the man to embalm and bury the dead pet Chimp. Soon he finds out that a middle-aged lady and her somber butler live there, then surprised to find it was Norma Desmond, who was writing a script for DeMille for her to star in a movie. The script was bad, but Joe needed money so agreed to work for $500 weekly to help her rewrite the script. Not wanting her script to leave, she required him to stay in the room above the garage, and the next morning he awoke to find all his belongings from his apartment now in this room!  Plus, Norma had his back rent paid. He became a kept man, showered with new clothes and other gifts, although he knew the script would never be made into a movie. A roof leak over the garage forced him into the main residence and, when Norma dressed him up for an elaborate New Year party, and he found out no other guests were invited, he fully realized her intentions towards him. Angry he left, she slit her wrists, he came back, began working nights on a real script with a young lady, Betty, fiancee of his friend Artie (Jack Webb), who was out of town on a shoot, Joe and Betty appeared to be falling in love, Joe not wanting to wrong his friend, brushed Betty off, headed with his suitcase back to Ohio, Norma shot him, three times, he fell into the pool, when newsreel staff arrived, Max her butler said 'The cameras have arrived', she walked out to them as the movie ended.

My husband had never seen Sunset Boulevard, so we watched it together. The great thing about this film is that it's like watching living history. Southern California, in all its glory, in 1950, before it was overrun by cars and freeways and people. When it was a beautiful sunny state filled with orange groves and people with dreams.It's fantastic to view the film just on this level. But of course, there's so much more to it.Aging silent movie star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) and struggling screenwriter Joe Gillis (William Holden) end up crossing paths in a way that is highly, highly unlikely.But once they do, Sunset Boulevard becomes a fairly riveting story about fame, money and the price people pay to keep it or be near it.William Holden is so beautiful that all he has to do is just stand and look at us. I found his acting to be fairly wooden, but on occasion he tapped into a few emotional states of mind and indicated that he might have some talents. But his main talent was a fantastic profile, an incredibly hot haircut, and a good, strong voice. That was enough.Gloria Swanson looked amazing for what was considered "old" at the time (about 50). There are scenes in which she is getting her skin treated, and there are magnifying glasses exposing her face and while a filter may have been used, she still had stunningly beautiful skin. I kept thinking: in this day and age she'd never be out of work. She would have embraced social media and people would have never forgotten who she was.But for the purpose of the movie, as great silent film star Norma Desmond, she lives in the past, where she was "big." There are a lot of great quotable lines from this screenplay and Gloria gets most of them, including, "I still am 'big,'; it's the pictures that got small."The cast is rounded out with Nancy Olson as Betty Schaefer (a reader for a movie studio) and Erich von Stroheim as Max (Norma's chauffeur, butler, and former husband -- before which he had discovered her).Nancy had that sort of wholesome Wisconsin girl goodness about her. She was not super talented, but she did a good job in the small role she was given. I'm sure she didn't realize she was going to become part of movie history. Erich spoke English clearly, but with a very slight accent that made it clear that he was not a native speaker. He is stiff throughout, but that is the role he was supposed to play. His dedication to Norma is sad, but it's clear he still loves and worships her.One of the things I found odd about this movie is that Jack Webb (of "Dragnet" fame) plays Artie Green, who does something in the movie business (production? It wasn't clear to me), and who, unless I'm mistaken, has a hard crush on William Holden. He calls Joe "beautiful" and touches his face and clearly wants to be near him. And who wouldn't want to be? In that day and age, Bill Holden was a god. I just found it be a unique moment in the 2-3 scenes where Jack and Bill are together. I feel like Billy Wilder told Jack in private, "You have a crush on him" and Jack said, "I DO have a crush on him" -- and that's how he played it.The film fails in that Joe cannot see a way out for himself, which doesn't make any sense. In other words, he shows up penniless and desperate at Norma's house, and she clothes him and feeds him and gives him basically anything he wants, but in return she expects a slavish devotion to her which is insane. But he lets it happen. Basically he's a kept man, and that's what was interesting about this movie. Who was making movies about "kept men"? No one.But at any point, Joe could have said, "Norma, it's time for me to go." But it isn't until Betty confesses her love for him and indicates that maybe the two of them could have a future together as writers that it dawns on him that maybe it's time to pack up and get out.Norma, who is sick with obsession, won't tolerate this, and this is what leads to the movie's sad denouement.Yes, it is of its time. No, it is not perfect. Yes, it is still watchable. Yes, it is over the top. Yes, there are still some great moments. So, all things said, if you are a movie fan, and know your movie history, "Sunset Boulevard" is a must-see.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies ever made. Period.
reviews.content: The absurdity, drama & sheer pleasure of this movie are a tribute to a time when movies were golden.  Great acting, great scenery chewing, and some of Hollywood's classic lines -- they're all here in Billy Wilder's sui generis flick.  Why this movie is not on DVD is beyond me!  As far as I'm concerned, EVERY Wilder movie should be on DVD -- especially now that he's no longer with us.

reviews.review_title: a very strange film noir film
reviews.content: I Thought that overall sunset blvd was a good movie. I did find it very hard to deal with Gloria Swanson even though she played a magnificent role and casting her was perfect for the role she had. You could tell she was a silence film actress because you could see how she used expressions and looks to portray just how she was feeling or dealing with things. This is what made it very hard for me to deal with this women. I felt the director did appropriate job of selecting a cast that met the demands of the movie including Nancy Olsen who plays the woman who gets William Holdens mojo for writing back. The score and dark ominous lighting did a amazing job of portraying just how dark a road William holden's character was moving down the line and just how far and extreme it might get to escape it. This is why the beginning scene which happens to be the last scene sets off a great example of what can happen in life if you just accept things and let people start to run your life. Wiliam Holden knew there was no escaping the dark, scary tones of what Gloria Swanson's life had become because without her he truly had nothing. Overall, this movie was brilliant and strange while keeping you on the edge of your seat to see what will happen to "Joe Gillis" next.

reviews.review_title: One of the ten best of all time!
reviews.content: I thought I had seen all of the important movies made during the past fifty years, but somehow I had missed Sunset Boulevard. I had seen parodies of the characters and was familiar with the story line, but I was really not prepared for this gem. Wow! When it comes to great acting, it just does not get any better. I really couldn't care less about the film's commentary on Hollywood; I watch this film to be mesmerized by Gloria Swanson. The premise of a kept man is creepy enough, but Swanson really takes this movie to another plane. If you have never seen this classic, do yourself a big favor and rent it. You will enjoy every minute. Very few movies can be called perfect, and this one may not be, but it is awfully close.

reviews.review_title: "Alright Mr DeVil, I'm ready for my close up."
reviews.content: Classified as a film noir, or a black comedy it held true through and through. The movie started out with great imaging in the first first few scenes of seeing Joe dead with his eyes wide open basically looking at you in the pool. I noticed this whole movie was based around that one big pool. Then, once the image is set in our mind, the story and plot comes in, and time is reversed back to where it all began. This was the first film that I have seen where the Mis-en-scene was really breath taking. It was the first film where a movie used real names in Hollywood at the time. Wilder showed that the set was at Paramount Pictures. Wilder showed how movies were started and made. Also, this was the first movie of that time where i noticed other references to movies in the film. First film I have seen relevant to todays time period. Great lighting throughout the film. The settings looked expensive. Yet again, I have seen this house before in other films. They use the same houses to film quite often. Gloria Swanson was a great, intense actress.
