I really felt her character during the whole movie. I loved how she went insane at the end over her fame and not being what she once was. She really pulled this character off and made it believable. It was a good movie, I wouldn't watch it again, but it was worth watching the first time.

reviews.review_title: crazy in enjoyable sort of way
reviews.content: This movie was crazy! It's an actresses nightmare. The story was beautiful because it had taken just an innocent man in financial troubles and put him in a situation were basically he sold himself to the devil in exchange for nice things to surround himself with. It's quite a mouth full. Poor Norma didn't know what to do with herself; old and out of work. Although, she was snobby and completely into her non existent career I couldn't help, but feel bad for her. There was an odd balance in the movie because it felt realistic and really unreal at the same time. The camera portrayed Norma's zanny, needy qualities very well. The lighting in the end particularly symbolized the star she once was that may always last through her movies, but it also enlightened what her stardom had made her became. It's just crazy what fame and money can do to people. The movie was very enjoyable to watch never a dull moment.

That`s it! Life is art. And art is life. I don`t doubt it. The simple things of life may be showed as art, just because they're art. Getting old may be seen as an end, as something people should be afraid of. I it isn't. I think everything depends on the way we seen things. Some people just don`t accept the way things get different as years go by. They find it difficult to understand what is happening around them. That`s the idea of this film. An old actress still live the old years she was successful and doesn`t really see people don`t think of her anymore. She lives alone in an old big house and she is assisted by a loyal man who serves and takes care of her. One day, a young writers gets there by chance and he gets involved with the old lady. That`s when the movie really begins. These two people discuss their points of view, talk about their experiences and make us feel good watching it all. I can`t tell much of the film, cause it talks by itself. I just have to say Billy Wilder is brilliant! He shows again he was one of the best directors ever! I also have to say people should have more respect for the ones who came first. Old people still must be heard and respected, cause they will always have something to say and to teach us.My grade 10/10

This film begins with a writer in Hollywood by the name of "Joe Gillis" (William Holden) who is having difficulty selling any of his work and as a result he is down on his luck and out of money. As luck would have it, however, while trying to elude some men attempting to repossess his automobile a flat tire causes him to drive into what he thinks is an abandoned mansion on Sunset Boulevard. Once there he is met by an elderly man named "Max Von Mayerling" (Erich von Stroheim) who motions for him to come into the house as the owner wishes to see immediately. It's then that he meets a former silent movie actress by the name of "Norma Desmond" (Gloria Swanson) who mistakes him for a funeral director called upon to bury a pet. Once the error is corrected she informs him that she has a script for a movie she has been working on and would like his professional opinion on it as she is planning on returning to the movie business to reclaim her former glory. Although he accepts her eventual offer of employment what Joe doesn't tell her is that the film industry has long since evolved and she simply doesn't have the talent necessary for such a return. What Joe doesn't understand is the danger associated with her mental and emotional instability during this particular time. Now rather than reveal any more I will just say that this was an entertaining drama which benefited from good performances by all involved. I especially like the haunting ending which Gloria Swanson delivered with such eerie precision and I recommend it for those interested in a film of this type. Above average.

Struggling screenwriter, Joe Gillis (William Holden), on the run from the repo man, stumbles upon the decrepit mansion of faded, silent film star, Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) at 10086 SUNSET BOULEVARD, where he soon meets devoted servant / chauffeur, Max (Eric von Stroheim) and eventually, Norma herself.In a short time, Joe is hired on to work on Norma's big "return" movie script. Of course, the catch is that he must stay at her mansion, and she has more than a working relationship in mind.This is Director Billy Wilder's masterpiece of film noir / black comedy. It also has suspense, tragedy, and even touches of horror. With this film, Wilder uses Norma to lampoon the entire Hollywood system.Ms. Swanson is astonishing in her divinely choreographed role as a self-parody-on-purpose. Her Norma is the delusional has-been, still awaiting her reemergence on the silver screen, in spite of the decades that have passed her by. Her trip to see Cecil B. DeMille is as heartbreaking as it is pitifully absurd. Holden plays Gillis as a sort of gigolo with a conscience, never quite comfortable in his new position.The entire film is riveting, with a grand finale that, once seen, is never forgotten...

reviews.review_title: In the top 3 of all time
reviews.content: One of the finest Films ever made, Bully wilder noted for making nr as many greats as Hitchcock, this has everything, dark humour, suspense and a lot of intrigue. Possibly I've seen it 30 or more times, it's a gem ! Hollywood when it was still great ! Don't miss this film.

Sunset Boulevard (1950): Dir: Billy Wilder / Cast: William Holden, Gloria Swanson, Erich von Stroheim, Nancy Olson, Cecil B. DeMille: Absolute masterpiece representing a place where dreams happened for one Gloria Swanson who was a big silent star but now her fame is fading and she dreams her life away with private screenings of her own films. Narrated by William Holden who is sheltered at her mansion in return for a screenplay that will resurrect her. Intriguing setup rich in dialogue and plot turns that result in the ultimate revelation in the conclusion. Billy Wilder does an excellent job at presenting ill fate Hollywood careers due to technology. Wilder previously made an entirely different film called Double Indemnity and both share a common theme of dominating femme figure. Swanson delivers a riveting performance of a woman illusion to total madness. Holden feels his talent trapped and seeks escape through an outside project. Erich von Stroheim is the ex-husband who lives to revive her past. He will be instrumental in assisting her concluding performance and famous last words. Nancy Olson plays a screenwriter unable to unlock Holden's thoughts. She is engaged yet will face Holden's forced lifestyle in blunt terms. Great cameo performances by film personalities portraying themselves, including famed director Cecil B. DeMille. It is the dark side of show business where stars flicker no more. Score: 10 / 10

reviews.review_title: Stock Hollywood precursor to Baby Jane and Psycho ad infinitum
reviews.content: William Holden 32 play Joe Gilles an unsuccessful script writer who while being chased by men trying to repossess his cars has a blowout and ends up in Norma Desmond's (Gloria Swanson 50) driveway. Norma is an eccentric has been star from silent pictures. Gille decides to make money out of Swanson by helping her write a hopeless movie script she is obsessed with...he ends up as her lover out of pity...and is killed when he tries to leave her.I was disappointed. This movie has such an aura and I only watched it because I had just watched Witness For The Prosecution (which was excellent) and wanted to see what else Wilder had done.This thing starts out bad with Holden narrating quick cynical tough lines setting the stage for things. These lines are corny and unconvincing to modern audiences. That turned me off immediately.The movie reminded me of Oliver the 8th with Laurel and Hardy (good flick) only this was a dead serious noir/horror movie instead of a comedy. The stereotyped butler (from Transylvania type) is totally unbelievable as Norma's first husband and her first film director just one of many silly unbelievable parts of the story.Since this movie is so ballyhooed and doesn't measure up I gave it a 4 (normally something like this would get a 5 or 6 from me). That it is number 12 on the list of all time great movies just shows you what sells to the public = nothing that can with stand any intelligent analysis.DO NOT RECOMMEND

Billy Wilder, Director of Sunset Boulevard cast Gloria Swanson of Queen of the silent movies in this return project after Mae West and other great stars turned down the role. Lucky are we that Swanson was cast. Gloria rSwanson gives one of the greatest performances ever on film as the silent screen star Norma Desmond. It is inexplicable that Swanson did not win the Academy award the only way you can rationalize it is that she had been away from films for many years and the Academy didn't know Swanson. Bette Davis gave a great performance in All About Eve as did her costar Anne Baxter (the more I see All About Eve the more I appreciate Baxter's performance) Eleanor Parker was brilliant in Caged. But Judy Holliday was magic in Born Yesterday. It was a year of great performances.I repeat Gloria Swanson should have won the Academy Award.William Holden the perfect male leading man gives a great performance in Sunset Boulevard as does Nancy Olson and a supporting cast of great players but is Swanson who grabs your attention and never lets it go.The finale of this movie is one of the great finales of all time. Billy Wilder was a genius.

reviews.review_title: I thought I was in for a real treat
reviews.content: As I unwrapped my Blu-ray to re-watch this old favourite I thought I was in for a real treat. Perhaps I should not have watched it so soon after seeing Aronofsky's mother! That film is full of terrifying emotions and selfish actions supposedly in the service of selflessness. And here, something not altogether different but so mannered, so other worldly. The beginning is great, all mystery and ambiguity, the scene where we visit Paramount Studios and meet the real Cecil B DeMille directing while a spotlight is turned upon our crazy heroine is fantastic. But so much of this is mundane and repetitive. I understand Mae West was considered for the role and at first I thought, what nonsense, but on reflection perhaps playing this for laughs would have been preferable to this arch campiness. Holden is fine, not someone with much charisma, and I've certainly seen him better. What he lacks here is any sense that this is really going on. I know in 1950 a bed scene between the two would probably have been too much (though goodness knows there were enough film folk of maturity bedding nymphets at the time) but maybe just an unmade bed or something to indicate he had some connection with this wretched creature.

reviews.review_title: "I'm ready for my close-up, Mr. DeMille"
reviews.content: In the 100+ years of motion pictures, we've been treated to many gems, including a few set in Tinseltown itself. SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS, THE PLAYER, and SINGIN' IN THE RAIN are excellent examples, but Billy Wilder's SUNSET BOULEVARD remains the greatest movie ever made about Hollywood. Its legendary status since 1950 has been so prevalent that it became a successful Broadway musical in the 1990's. Carol Burnett also parodied it on her long running variety television show.Wilder was such a mischievous filmmaker who knew this project would nibble at the fingers that fed him. With SUNSET BOULEVARD, he gave us a cynical exercise in portraying the Dream Factory as an eat-'em-'up and spit-'em-out business that treats its own as disposable commodities to be set aside when the next big thing arrives.Considering how Gloria Swanson and William Holden are so identified with the public as Norma Desmond and Joseph Gillis, it might surprise some to learn that neither was the first choice for those roles. Mary Pickford was the first actress asked to play Norma, but the former silent screen queen demanded multiple changes to her character. Big mistake, for the one thing Wilder would never compromise on was a script he painstakingly crafted together. Once Pickford was out, Mae West was approached, but she was indignant over the suggestion she was a has-been, despite being in her late fifties. Wilder's friend George Cukor suggested Swanson, who wasn't the slightest bit offended about the character and happily agreed to join.Although Montgomery Clift was the first actor considered to play Joe Gillis, he dropped out two weeks before shooting was about to begin. Apparently, the gigolo character hit a little too close to home in his private life, for he had an ambiguous relationship with torch singer Libby Holman. Enraged over Clift's reneging, Wilder quickly set about finding a replacement within the Paramount stable. After Fred MacMurray and Ray Milland declined the offer, William Holden enthusiastically said yes.SUNSET BOULEVARD begins with police cars speeding down the title roadway with sirens a-blaring until they arrive at a mansion. The dead body of a young man with three bullet holes in him is floating in the swimming pool. The voiceover narration is done by the corpse himself as the film flashes backward in time to almost a year, where Joe Gillis is a hack screenwriter with B-movies to his credits and debts to his name. Not only is he unable to interest Paramount in his latest script, but he can't secure a loan to keep up the car payments.Keeping one step ahead of the repo men, a tire blowout lands him in the driveway of a Hollywood mansion on Sunset Boulevard. After parking his car in the owner's garage, Gillis starts checking the place out. In voiceover, Joe accurately describes the property as similar to that of Miss Havisham, which anyone who's read "Great Expectations" or seen David Lean's movie version will understand right away. There's also a dilapidated looking pool that appears to have been last used when the stock market crashed. And Gillis hasn't been inside the mansion yet ....The home belongs to Norma Desmond, a faded silent screen legend who's never forgiven Hollywood for transitioning to sound. Being the perfect embodiment of the phrase "living in the past", Norma rails against the current crop of stars she disdainfully refers to as nobodies. All over her mansion are monuments to herself, photograph after photograph of her as she appeared in the Twenties. The only other person in her gothic web is her manservant Max (Erich von Stroheim), himself an oddball too.About to lay her late chimpanzee to rest, Norma mistakes Gillis for a funeral rep until discovering his true identity. Upon realizing that he's a screenwriter, she proposes hiring him to adapt her personal treatment about the life of Salome. Norma is so delusional that she thinks Cecil B DeMille will drop everything to work with her again despite her not having made a movie in over twenty years.Since he has nothing but mounting debts, Joe agrees to her offer, but there's a caveat. Paranoid about letting her pet project out of her sight, Norma insists that he work out of her mansion, with a spare room provided for him above the garage. Realizing that the bill collectors will never think of looking for him here, he accepts, but he soon finds himself restricted, and having the humorless Max hovering around doesn't make him feel any more relaxed.Gillis has the uneasy feeling his employer views him in more than a professional capacity, something confirmed when Norma arranges a private New Year's party for just the two of them. Her showering him with gifts such as tuxedos, cufflinks, and a gold plated cigarette case only increases his feelings of helplessness and confinement. His debts have been paid off, thanks to Norma, but it's come at a cost to his freedom now that he's a kept man.Creative stimulation arrives in the form of Betty Schaeffer, a script reader at Paramount hoping to become a writer herself. Her fiancee is a good pal of Joe's, an assistant director, and while he's on location in Arizona, she and Gillis pool their resources to type out their own original screenplay. But because of Norma's possessiveness, it's a project that must be done in secrecy.SUNSET BOULEVARD is a magnificent example of what happens when first-rate talents get together to create a work of art. I don't think even the great Bernard Herrmann could have provided a better music score than Franz Waxman does here. John Seitz does wonders with the photography, especially with his use of mirrors on the bottom of the swimming pool...to obtain a frontal shot of the floating corpse.And according to Nancy Olson, who played Betty, Wilder and his team made sure that the dust and cobwebs of Norma's mansion were sprinkled about with mathematical precision. That's how meticulous their attention was to detail!!!When SUNSET BOULEVARD came out in 1950, Gloria Swanson received more acclaim for her performance of Norma Desmond than for any of her silent movies. The final shot of her melodramatically descending her staircase in a state of delusion is one for the ages. And when it came to his work in front of the camera, Erich von Stroheim has never been better.For William Holden, SUNSET BOULEVARD offered him the opportunity to move past what he derisively called his Smiling Jim roles and show what he was capable of when given the chance. It was a career altering movie for him. Holden, Swanson, von Stroheim, and Olson were all nominated forfor Academy Awards.The only people unhappy with SUNSET BOULEVARD were the moguls who didn't appreciate being implied as callous and uncaring -even though they were. One particular malcontent was Louis B Mayer, resident tyrant of M. G. M., who flew into a rage at Wilder following the premiere, accusing him of biting the hand that fed him. Undaunted, Wilder merely told him off with language that can't be used here.SUNSET BOULEVARD is another splendid feather in the cap of Billy Wilder.

"Sunset Blvd" is kind of a downer . . . but hell if it isn't a fascinating one. I knew this movie for Gloria Swanson's scenery-gobbling performance, but that's only surface stuff. This is a well-written movie about the dark side of Hollywood; a failed screenwriter down to his last dime and a movie queen has-been in denial, both pinning their hopes on each other. It's a hard movie, extremely cynical and very sad. But also sincerely gripping until the very end (even though the ending is shown in the opening shots. It's not a spoiler in the vein of Rosebud or Keyser Söze - the real lure is to see how it happened. And it's a knock-out story.8/10

From it's opening shot we know that we are not in the Hollywood of dreams. A writer floats dead in a swimming poll, he stares straight at us, perhaps accusingly. The narator begins to tell us the story, and what a story.Wilder would always be on the outside as far as mainstream Hollywood was concerned, and here you can see why. Sunset Boulevard is merciless in it's dissection of the film capital. By turns acerbic, nostalgic, vicious and hauntingly tragic, Sunset Boulevard is a ghost story. It features some of the greats from the movie capitals early years, now dusty and forgotten like Norma Desmond's mansion; the card game is like watching a seance.Gloria Swanson was, as the cliche has it, born to play Norma Desmond. Aided by William Holden and Victor Von Stroheim with cameos from some other silent era greats, she towers above the film. When she says: "I'm still big, it's the films that got small." she is speaking the literal truth.Wilder led the way for other Hollywood talents to dissect the Dream Factory. None did so as bitingly or with such obvious love for his subject. For although he may be scathing about the system, he treats his characters lovingly. Ultimately they are tragic men and women who bought into the dream and discovered, too late, how superficial it is.The final "Ready for my close up, Mr DeMille" scene is painful, capturing acturately the beauty, sadness, tragedy and pointlessness of Hollywood's dream.

reviews.review_title: 'Sunset Boulevard' is one of the greatest movies you'll ever see.
reviews.content: Los Angeles setting. Wry, reflective narration. Cutting dialogue, biting and sometimes grim or morbid humor, timeless cultural references. Above all: characters with huge personality; increasingly tangled relationships and circumstances; a course of events that slowly spirals out beyond manageability. This is a film noir, alright, and more than that, it's unquestionably one of the definitive pictures of the genre. Yet these are just broad descriptive terms for the nutritious substance of the movie - the details are the garnish, the spices, that add tremendous flavor. And, oh, how delicious it is. The production design and art direction are exemplary, filling every scene with delightful sights and sounds at every corner. The costume design, hair and makeup work, and above all set design and decoration are wonderfully fetching, a real treat for the eyes. The lines given to star William Holden for the protagonist's narration are brilliant in their sharp wit, and nigh poetic vocabulary and arrangement, and Holden delivers each with a dark panache that amounts to verbal instant gratification. And whatever the mood of a given scene, so it is for much of the dialogue at large, both Holden's, and Gloria Swanson's, and Erich von Stroheim's, and everyone's. In fact: it's one matter to see a feature described as one of the best movies ever made, but to watch it for oneself and confirm that truth is an altogether fabulous experience. Seventy years of acclaim do not lie - 'Sunset Boulevard' is an incredible, essential film.I don't know just how much one can discuss the particulars of a titanic title like this without betraying spoilers; as comprehensively stupendous as this is, to spotlight one component draws forth all the rest along with it. Consider the sizable cast, including parts for such luminaries as Buster Keaton and Cecil B. DeMille. Swanson gives the performance of a lifetime, vibrantly dynamic and charged, portraying fraught fading star Norma Desmond with dazzling presence and range that's surely among the greatest of all acting cinema has given us. Joe Gillis is a man filled with quiet, stewing complications, and Holden sells him with stark poise that belies a tumult of hope, lies, exploitation, and contempt. Von Stroheim, as Max, is a hushed yet sturdy anchor for the film, looming large at all times; Nancy Olson is a joy in her supporting part as Betty, offering warm, innocent respite from the more bleak undertones that course through the length. And so on and so on, down through the line. And at that, consider the fundamental building blocks of the picture: this is a feature by, of, and for Hollywood. The plot concerns a troubled writer and a desperate former star - the latter easy enough for anyone to conjure in an industry that too often soaks up dreams only to leave viscera trailing behind. There's a certain "insider" essence to 'Sunset Boulevard,' yet instead of glorification and self-indulgence, this saga brims with cynicism, self-loathing, and tangible dejection. And it's stunning from start to finish.The characters are rife with depth and complexity, and frankly the dialogue is humming with such electricity that I don't know if I can name any comparison. The scene writing is harsh and unforgiving, yet defined by just enough variety - and, again, no small measure of pitch black humor - that the summation is absolutely spellbinding as it propels a vivid, absorbing narrative. Meanwhile, in the same way that some straight dramas can elicit such reactions that they could feasibly be labeled as horror without even playing in that genre, the story here is so taut with tension and unease that it becomes earnestly thrilling, though the shoe itself wouldn't necessarily fit. The acting is entirely unimpeachable. The lighting, cinematography, shot composition, and direction generally are flawless, and crafted with careful artistry. And: not only is this a marvelous film noir, with ruefully knotted-up characters, and a drama with such palpable energy that it's very nearly a thriller. But moreover, as the screenplay zeroes in on the gradual escalation of pressure between the figures herein, and on their mental states that in a few different ways are bit by bit giving in to the strain - and as the assembled actors, Swanson above all, embody their roles with such powerful feeling - 'Sunset Boulevard' takes on significant airs of psychological drama, becoming ever more harrowing and sorrowful in the process. And still, after all that, the film ends not with a sad wail, but with a pointed, knowing gaze.What more is there to say? I could surely spill out still more words to describe all the ways in which this is an astonishing, captivating, must-see classic, but there comes a point where effusive praise becomes the inane babble of elated bewilderment. I cannot emphasize enough, or overstate: 'Sunset Boulevard' is one of the finest works of cinema that will ever be produced. It took me entirely too many years of my life to get around to watching it, and if there's the faintest hope that I can induce a potential viewer to expedite their own sitting, then these paragraphs will have been worth it. Watch this now. And buy it, so you can watch it again.Bravo, bravo, bravo!

You are all out of your minds if you gave this movie less than an eight. And if you hated Some Like It Hot, I'm convinced that you have no soul. If you hated something as masterful as The Apartment, then you have a hole where your heart should be. If you hate everything Billy Wilder ever did, you have no soul, heart, or brain-- you're just a retarded stick with opposable thumbs. In other words, I hate you if you hate Billy Wilder.Wilder was and always will be one of the greatest writer-directors that Hollywood has ever known. Some of you are forgetting the purpose of film-- to take you away to a world that you didn't know and entertain you. That's what Billy did, only he made it funny, satirical, or both. Sunset Boulevard did get dull at points, but that's life. If you don't want movies to be somewhat real, go delude yourself and watch Teletubbies. Personally, I wish that someone would bring Billy back from the dead to make another movie and make all of the people who probably enjoyed Disaster Movie appreciate his brilliance.So God, please send your son down here so that he can do that Lazarus thing and bring back Billy. We need him down here. With a new generation of Hannah Montana's that will marry Jonas Brother look-a-likes, I need Sunset Boulevard. Because it reminds me that Hollywood isn't perfect. It's real and imperfect just like the rest of life.I Heart Billy Wilder!

'Sunset Blvd. (1950)', a veritable cinematic classic, is surprisingly meta, comprised almost entirely of interlaced 'Easter eggs' which take the form of 'art imitating life', celebrity cameos and, of course, movie references. This 'self-eating snake' nature is perhaps appropriate considering that the piece is still one of the best, most in-depth insights into - and a near damnation of - Hollywood, specifically 'old Hollywood'. It's also a keen portrayal of a sad kind of self-obsession usually associated with famous artists, one that the person often clings to beyond all hope primarily because their personality is so intrinsically tied to it. This self-perpetuating cycle of defining one's worth by how much strangers 'admire' them is certainly toxic and is, quite boldly, on full display. Ultimately, the picture is rather bleak, showcasing how society often enables dangerous behaviour by awarding it with their attention. The themes I've mentioned would be enough to float an entire flick but this one has even more still. It looks at money, financial security, loneliness, emasculation, creativity, mental illness and attention-seeking behaviour. It's remarkably interesting. It's also consistently entertaining, styled with a lavish 'noir' aesthetic that paints every frame, along with the usually decrepit things within them, in a beautiful black-and-white hue that somehow has a real thematic resonance in and of itself. The purposefully heavy-handed, hard-boiled but often flowery narration adds to the narrative's eerily enigmatic nature. The story is seemingly straight-forward, yet it's also oddly bizarre in the best way possible. Everything just feels like it's on top-form, here. The direction uses dazzling camera-work to invigorate the dialogue-based plot, beginning with an absolutely brilliant one-shot title-sequence and otherwise featuring its lion's share of inventive angles (the under-water shot is a real highlight and a proper bit of technical wizardry, too). The performances perfectly walk the line of realism and 'showbiz', with the balance being palpably different for each character. Swanson's Norma Desmond almost feels like she's acting in a silent movie, oozing intensity from every facial feature, whereas Holden's Joe Gillis slowly transitions from a 'Golden era' star to a paranoid, under-the-thumb man who thinks he's trapped with some sort of 'B-movie' monster and may actually like it. Tying everything together is this 'behind-the-scenes' feel. You're being taken on a tour of the very thing that produces pictures like this and people like Desmond. The more you read about it after the fact, the more you realise that it must've been shot through some sort of mirror. It may be a fictional tale, but it resembles reality in more ways than it doesn't and sometimes simply presents it to you (or a version of it, at least). Its haunting end is one of the most famous of all time but the whole affair is worthy of that status. It's an ahead-of-its-time experience that's as enjoyable as it impressive. As I said, it's a classic. 8/10

The film is a true mastery in direction as well as screenplay. It was from Billy wilder, so I was expecting a lot of surprises like The Double Indemnity. He didn't disappoint me at all. The film is one of the best examples of films in which much thought is given for story. The thing which kept me attached was the authoritative narration. The story revolves around a jobless screenwriter who by chance got stuck with a silent film start and she started to love him. And after this started a series of dilemma in the mind of the lead character about the decisions to be made. Entertainment is definitely assured for true cine lovers.PROS:The fascinating stories, the powerful narrative, the character representation, were too good. The director has done a wonderful job. Billy Wilder has made a special place in my heart. CONS:Pardon me for bringing this, but the acting of Norma seemed to me as too much. Sometimes it looked to be as overacted. Now it is a different thing to say that she was acting something else in the film or two layers of acting. But that is not an obstacle.MESSAGE: "You never know what is ahead of you."VERDICT: "A must watch."

There is a lot to love about this movie, which is loaded with great performances, and intersects film noir with fading Hollywood stardom. It grabs us from the start with police called to the scene of a mansion with a body floating in its pool, and as we listen to a deadpan narrator. Director Billy Wilder gives us the first of what will be many great shots, this one from what appears to be the bottom of the pool, with policemen in the background standing over the body. The film then flashes back to a young writer (William Holden), down on his luck and pressured by repo men, trying to figure out a way to sell his work or borrow some money. He pulls into the driveway of a mansion by chance, and finds himself slowly entangled in another trap, that of an aging Hollywood star (Gloria Swanson). The feel is eerie from the start, as she seeks funeral arrangements for her pet chimp, lives in boundless ostentation, and has a single companion, her solemn servant (Erich von Stroheim) who plays an organ that otherwise wheezes drearily when the wind blows through it. While her pool and tennis courts have fallen into ruin, she lives in the past, surrounded by her own photographs and watching her own old movies. Out of what he feels to be necessity, he begins working for her and living with her, hating every moment.Gloria Swanson, who was 51, turns in an outstanding performance, and has several fantastic scenes. The one where she and Holden sit in the dark with the projector light going through smoke is brilliant, and one of my favorites. Another is him dancing with her on the floor that she says Valentino had danced on, surrounded by an orchestra and expecting other guests, only to realize there will be none. The one where she imitates Charlie Chaplin, complete with a little tramp outfit, is truly special.Wilder is excellent at gradually revealing just how far gone she is. It was a nice touch of his to include silent movie stars as her bridge companions in a small scene, including Buster Keaton, and to see Cecil B. DeMille on the set at Paramount was fantastic. We see both her delusion of still being an important star as she rolls up to the gate house in her expensive old car (an Isotta-Fraschini), and yet we also see her past stardom recognized by one of the gate keepers, and then people on the set when they realize she's there. It's a very touching moment. Things get more complicated when Holden begins working with the fiancé (Nancy Olson) of his affable friend (Jack Webb, soon to be better known for Dragnet). Not all of the scenes revolve around Swanson, and the one where Holden and Olson play act a romantic scene at a party is intelligent, funny, and utterly charming.The film gives us a behind the scenes look at Hollywood - brainstorming over scripts, the writing process, the vanity of those in the limelight, and the opulence. Swanson gets a little over the top at times especially towards the end, but the film feels both sadly true, and yet also fantastical, with her mansion other-worldly and not unlike that of the one Miss Havisham has in 'Great Expectations', as Holden observes early on. With such a setting and those poignant overtones, and having excellent direction, cinematography, script, and cast, it's hard to go wrong with this one.

Sunset Boulevard is easily one of the finest movies of all time. Billy Wilder shows a mirror to Hollywood and all the old stars who refuse to accept the reality and still try to live on their past deeds. All the people associated with the entertainment industry are guilty of this thing at some or the other point in their life. The performances of most of the actors in this movie are quite convincing. It has got an authentic feel that certainly adds to the appeal of the movie. The climatic scene will surely stay in the mind of any viewer for a long time after he has seen this finely crafted and well made piece of art. This is surely one of the finest movies that have been directed by Billy Wilder.

Recently I decided to rent all of the AFI's top 100 movies that I'd never seen. To my surprise, only three were missing.  Birth of a Nation, Some Like it Hot and Sunset Blvd.  Of the three, I found that two were still great and this is one of them. (BoaN was the clunker, in my opinion).  As timely today as it ever was, all of the archetypes presented ring true and could be cut from today's cloth as well as the vintage vicuna of Gigolo Joe's overcoat. The dialogue sparkles, the acting impresses, the direction stands out (some tracking shots are among the best ever committed to celluloid).  Often imitated, never surpassed, it's as good as its hype.  Don't miss.
A compelling film. Norma Desmond is a chilling and terrifying character. So many lines and moments from this film have made their way into pop culture.
A true classic movie. Acting is a bit of an exaggeration, but it's a very good movie for its time. It also has a great theme.

The scary eyes of Norma Desmond will haunt my dreams. Great performance by Gloria Swanson whom ive never seen before.Im really enjoying discovering these classics at the moment and having enjoyed Double Indemnity this is another Billy Wilder success. Directed with the same perfect pace and a visual flair he managed to rein in some quite dark and often surreal material here to create an engrossing and intriguing drama.

reviews.review_title: "I Am Big. It's The Pictures That Got Small"
reviews.content: A satirical conflict between the two eras of cinema, an observation of the best & worst the film industry has in store for everyone, and a remarkable study of one of the most idiosyncratic movie characters you'll ever see, Billy Wilder's Sunset Boulevard is a tribute, & at the same time, a criticism of Hollywood film industry and is arguably the finest film of his illustrious filmmaking career.The film stars Gloria Swanson in a career-defining role of Norma Desmond; a silent queen whose stardom vanished ages ago but remains alive in her delusional mind, and William Holden as Joe Gillis; a struggling writer narrating us the tale of his demise & how it's connected with Norma. Swanson's performance is unforgettable here as she seamlessly immerses into her given role & plays Norma with such flawless finesse that it overshadowed almost every other aspect of this film.Nicely directed & brilliantly written by Wilder with many moments of sadness & wit cleverly glued together, Sunset Boulevard paints a remarkable yet pitiful portrait of a bygone actress living in a world of her own and is an immensely entertaining & hugely rewarding cinema about Hollywood that culminates with a much more tragic finish than expected by etching Norma Desmond's final shot into our minds for it to haunt us forever. A classic noir drama.

reviews.review_title: A masterpiece- Norma Desmond not to be forgotten
reviews.content:
The end scenes is what film legend is made of. Lines & a scene that will live forever, with Norma and Erich.
Gloria Swanson as a fading silent Screen giant. (she has the voice too), is not to be forgotten. Erich von Stroheim is a real German director, fled to the USA, perfect in this role.
William Holden his best role. The Woman studio script writer, Bill's love interest, also great. Someone said, things slowly get out of hand for Bill (Gillis), too true.
By all means watch it. and if you've seen it watch it again.

Sunset Boulevard from 1950 is a magnificently twisted Film Noir. Norma Desmond was a once extremely famous Hollywood Actress. Everyone knew who she was, loved her films and her mind absolutely adored her. What Norma doesn't realize is that she has been out of the spotlight for a longtime. She has been hiding away in her once gorgeous home, holding on to what she once was. Her house is very reflective of what she herself had become over the years. The house hadn't received much attention and in turn has become dull and un-groomed; Norma Desmond did the same. Joe Gillis is a screenwriter that has also been struggling with his career. He manages to fall in to Norma's world, and in the end shatters it. Joe agrees to help Norma with her comeback film, but in the process realizes that nobody is waiting to see it. Norma's mental state isn't always logical, but her character makes you feel for her. She was once this beautiful actress that was on top of the film world; now she's lucky if she is a distant memory. This is a dark film that shows what fame can do to a person. Norma seems as though she is stuck in the spotlight and doesn't know how to live life otherwise. The script was great, but Gloria Swanson was perfect at pulling everything together.

I'd heard quite a lot of things about this particular film, for years. Oh yes, Gloria Swanson is amazing (since that's where most of the conversation originates from) but there are so many good performances in this, and the film itself is stellar. It's odd to think that both this and All About Eve came out in the same year, both stories about Hollywood to great degrees. Also odd because both feature two female performances considered among the greatest of all time, and yet neither of them won. The final scene of this is really haunting stuff, stuff of nightmares, possibly one of the greatest final scenes ever. Basically, it lived up to its reputation, and then some.

reviews.review_title: 8.6/10 - a layered look into the cruelty of Hollywood
reviews.content: "You see, this is my life! It always will be!There's nothing else. Just us, and the cameras, and those wonderful people out there in the dark."Sunset Boulevard is a film with such a strong statement that it horrified many people that were offered to work on it. It criticizes Hollywood in a very strong way, a way that leaves an impact on the viewer.To give you a general idea of the plot: it follows Joe Gillis, a troubled Hollywood writer who's drowning in debts. As he runs away from the finance company he finds himself in a rather large mansion, being hired to fix a screenplay for a long forgotten Hollywood star Norma Desmond.As I've written above, this film is one painful criticizm of Hollywood - how it worships moneys instead of art, how it casts away anyone who isn't needed anymore, how it kills good writing. I think that esepcially in the final, haunting scene, the critcizm was evident and strong. It is said that Gloria Swanson just burst into tears after filming this scene, and I can definitely see why.Sunset Boulevard has many strengths - Swanson's acting gives so much life the Desmond's character, the score is on point and adds a lot to the film (especially during the opening sequence and during the final scene), the layers of criticizm here (both through the plot as an alagory and through the actual casting) are quite brilliant, and I appreciate this film a lot.I can't say that I have any big issue with this film, or any noteable one. I like it a lot, and I appreciate it even more.So, if you wanna get a creative, layered look into the cruelty of the film industry, Sunset Boulevard is definitely the film for you. I can't say that this film shook me to my core or that I had a really high emotional connection to most of it, but the ending is phenomenal and it is a very smart and interesting film to watch. I'm feeling an 8.6/10 on this one.

It doesn't get much darker than Sunset Boulevard, the perfectly named title of this cinematic masterpiece. Appropriately in the sunset of her career, Norma Desmond, played by the talented Gloria Swanson (and who seems to have a lot in common with her), takes on a boarder, Joe Gillis, played by William Holden, who is a Hollywood writer. Norma wants Gillis to service her as both a writer and a lover. Gillis, who is desperate for money, takes Desmond up on her proposition. Unfortunately, there are complications, such as Gillis' girlfriend outside of the house. I particularly like Max, played Erich VonStroheim, who plays the role of the old-time director to the hilt. A fascinating look at the ugly side of Hollywood.

Despite it being one of the classics, somehow, I've manged 42 goes around the sun without seeing "Sunset Boulevard". Finally getting to it, I found it to be one of the timeless ones, that's meta impact remains just as potent all these years later.Running from a debt collection, struggling Hollywood screenwriter Joe Gillis (William Holden) ends up at the faded mansion of former Hollywood star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson). Despite now being 50, and having not worked since the talkie's arrived, Norma is convinced that her self-written adaptation of Salome will be her root back to stardom. She engages Joe to edit her script and, seeing the opportunity for financial stability he agrees. Her delusions and obsession with him deepen and when he decides that she is not worth the stress, she takes matters into her own hands.Part film noir and part comedy, I was surprised at how genuinely funny "Sunset Boulevard" remains. It's mostly in Holden's scenes away from the house, at the start when he's trying to get a job or the scenes with Betty, played by Nancy Olson, who, for inexplicable reasons, also seems to fall in love with Joe, though there is quite a bit of chemistry in their verbal sparring. Swanson's overacting is striking at first, as she lurches around like a hungry Vampire, but it makes sense as you come to understand that she's essentially lost to her fantasy, stuck somewhere between the silent screen presence she once was and the addict desperately trying to organise another fix. She's never not magnetic though, whenever she's on the screen and deserved her Oscar nomination for the role.It also won one for best Art Direction, which perhaps should have been awarded solely for the iconic scene of a body floating in a swimming pool, shot from underneath, which looks impossible given the technology of the time, before a relatively simple trick allowed its production.Funny, dark, memorable and thought provoking, It truly is one of those films that is deserving of it's classic status.

reviews.review_title: One of the great films of Hollywood's golden age.
reviews.content: This movie is really special. Not only does it show us a lot about the world of Hollywood during its golden age, but it also reveals a lot about the actors' egos, vanities and their titanic struggles to preserve their careers and stay in the limelight. Brilliantly directed by Billy Wilder, it is considered by many to be one of the great movie classics, combining entertainment, artistic value and cultural relevance. In 1951, it won three Oscars (Best Screenplay, Best Art Direction in a Black and White Film, Best Comic Film Soundtrack) and could perfectly have won one more, for Best Actress. But awards like these are never completely fair, especially in years so fertile for good films.Starting with the iconic scene of the dead man in the pool, the film intrigues us, and curiosity grips us, as the film shows how it all happened, introducing us to an average screenwriter who struggles to write a successful script that can leverage his career. He owes money, is in serious trouble and takes advantage of the opportunity to earn some easy money at the expense of a retired silent film actress, who decides to hire him to revise and type a script, written by herself and designed to mark her return. The script is mediocre, and he knows that the film will never happen, but he is coerced into silence, becoming the privileged eyewitness of the former star's gradual loss of lucidity. Of course, things get complicated as he loses his individual freedom and becomes more dependent on the whims and desires of his mistress.Despite the fiction, the film is based a lot on several loose true facts: one of them, the most obvious, is the fall of several actors in the course of the transition from silent to talking films. There were great actors who looked magnificent on screen and had great physical and facial expression, but who didn't survive this transition due to things as prosaic as a poor English fluency or a strange accent. Others, however, simply did not know how to understand and adapt to the novelty. The collapse of their careers and personal lives led to alcoholism, drugs, mental disorders. The film is able to condense almost all of this into a single character: Norma Desmond, the epitome of the fallen star.The cast has several well-known names, three of which - William Holden, Erich Von Stroheim and, obviously, Gloria Swanson - offer us the interpretation of their lives and their work of greater value and recognition. Of course, we cannot ignore that Swanson was a great star of silent cinema and that she shone in films like "Trespasser" or "Indiscreet", and that Holden would continue to be a highly sought actor after this, having won his Oscar for Best Actor in a film that starred two years later. But there is no doubt that this film immortalized the three of them.Technically, the film is impeccable, and the merit lies a lot in the brilliance of the dialogues, in the excellence of the conception and development of the characters, in the extraordinary way in which Wilder managed to get the best out of Swanson and lead the actress to a magnificent performance, which has so much to brilliant and difficult as well as provocative (especially from the point of view of many Hollywood shooting stars, who saw themselves in character and felt offended by it). With an excellent pace, the film does not waste time or let the atmosphere of tension and drama fall into a standstill. The mansion, owned by the Getty family, acquires character by itself as it becomes the most obvious symbol of the disturbed personality and only of its resident. The black and white cinematography is magnificent, and accentuates, in its details and shooting angles, the dramatic feel of the film. The soundtrack isn't memorable, but it's effective and functional.

reviews.review_title: GREAT film; should have won the Oscar over ALL ABOUT EVE
reviews.content: SUNSET BLVD.(1950) D: Billy Wilder ****  A great film, one of the best ever made. Magnificent direction from Billy Wilder, very well written, great performances all around. At first it would seem that Gloria Swanson's wild-eyed, over-the-top hysterics might be out of line, but they wind up fitting the nature of this picture perfectly. William Holden is good as the desperate houseguest, Nancy Olson makes the ideal girl-next-door, and Erich von Stroheim is on the money as Swanson's butler. Great to see Cecil B. DeMille playing himself here, too. A much better film than ALL ABOUT EVE, and more deserving of the Best Picture Oscar for 1950. This film might have been slighted due to its offbeat (for 1950) nature.

Boyo-2 wrote: "Gloria Swanson must be commended for her bravery in taking a part which may or may not have echoed her own Hollywood career." I completely agree. With many members of the public, real-life and screen can become blurred. Other actresses had turned down the role of Norma Desmond, and Ms Swanson, who was not in any way like the role she played in this film, showed real guts in accepting the role.The arrival of talkies came really quickly. I have read through some of the film magazines at the time. I read letters from the fans displaying undying love for Clara Bow, Norma Talmadge, Jack Gilbert etc. Within the space of a year the fans had dumped them in favour of the new talkie stars. This film is a possible scenario of what might have happened to one of these stars.Like Miss Havisham in Dickens's Great Expectations Norma Desmond still lives in a time warp. She is still a star, and she is planning her big comeback. Her manservant, ex-director and ex husband humours her. But one day reality comes in the shape of her toyboy played by William Holden. She cannot face reality, so she kills it.This is possibly the first time that Hollywood got to grips with the stories of what has happened to people who were spat out by the film industry.

reviews.review_title: My #5 favorite film of all time
reviews.content: Sunset Blvd. is one of those film that grabs you (by the neck) from the first frame and doesn't let go until the screen goes black at the end. Billy Wilder directs this film with utter brilliance. More Hitchcockian than Hitchcock would have ever had made. The music score of Waxman remains in the ear long after a viewing. The cinematography of Seitz is beautifully crisp and sharp it puts many color films to shame. And it would be impossible to disassociate the film with the lead actress Swanson. So many classic lines but who could forget the greatest last line ever for a movie. It is the greatest Hollywood film about Hollywood ever made.

Some artists do not enjoy watching themselves in performance. Often seeking seclusion and shying away from the glare of publicity. At the opposite end of the spectrum are the self absorbed, obsessed and enveloped by their own importance.Sunset Blvd.'s Gloria Swanson is one such figure. Twenty years past her sell-by date, but still wallowing in her once glittering career as a silent star. Existing as a recluse, with only servant Erich von Stroheim for company. Driven by the fantasy of a glorious return to the screen.Enter floundering, creatively bankrupt hack, William Holden, who realizes too late that not scrounging, scraping and scrimping the outstanding payment on his car proves to be a costly mistake. A wardrobe full of expensive clothes and a primarily liquid diet of vintage champagne cannot disguise the fact that by parking his ailing automobile in Swanson's garage he has become imprisoned in her bizarre, unreal world.Holden's onerous task of transforming Swanson's muddled, woeful scripts into a marketable finished product for Cecil B. DeMille at Paramount, in order to rekindle the all but forgotten star's career, is nothing short of a' silk purse from a sow's ear' undertaking. Throw in the added ingredient of Swanson's constant meddling and it descends into a challenge as thankless as polishing a cowpat. Meanwhile, Swanson remains blissfully ignorant of the fact that both she and the industry that once embraced her, have both changed beyond recognition.Overlong, overrated and occasionally overbearing Wilder's dark satire nonetheless, presents a unique insider's view of a Hollywood on the brink of the big collapse. Studio-bound and stagy, seven decades on Sunset Bvld. has lost much of the universal potency and paramount importance evident at the time of its release. Notwithstanding, it remains an incisive statement on the mercurial nature of stardom and the potential damage it can wreak upon those who become intoxicated by its allure. Largely determined by the capricious complexion of audience response. One day you're up and the next.....you're doing an Imodium ad!

My only other reference to this story is an amateur dramatic performance I saw. That production was absolutely outstanding and far better than some professional shows I've seen. It also stands up against this film as the superior, but that doesn't mean that the film doesn't have its own merits.Gloria Swanson plays a superb version of Bette Davis and I can see why the Oscars were faced with such a tough decision that year. The character of Norma Desmond is very enigmatic and I'm sure it must have resonated with many actresses of the time.I was slightly disappointed by William Holden though. He was a very handsome chap, but he doesn't play an attractive character, so it wasn't easy to feel sorry for him in his situation, which I felt with the stage version. It was hard to like either character really and I just ended up on the butlers side.The story has a similar feel to Great Expectations with it's older lady fallen in to disrepair in a home of the same shabby aesthetic who works with a younger man, although for slightly different motives.I do love stories of old Hollywood or any "Backstage Pass" film. The glory days must have been very exciting and that comes across here on the sets. The glamour and the excesses all seem so appealing.I think the film is well and truly overdue for a remake, but not necessarily a revamp. The time frame is perfect or even a tad late. It could probably be set anywhere from 1940, but doesn't need to be brought up to date. It's a tale that I think is interesting and worth a watch, but could be better.622.05/1000.

reviews.review_title: "Funny how gentle people get with you once you're dead."
reviews.content: Sunset Blvd. is a capital D Dark comedy, perfectly walking the line between extremely unsettling & absurdly hilarious (dead ape). The writing is among the best of its kind; flowery & full of noir-heavy tropes that sit within the genre while standing above it. Swanson is of course undeniable, but Holden shouldn't be forgotten, playing the line between Stockholm syndrome & sly suspension skillfully and coolly. A better film than Demille could ever make.

Its funny how some movies never seem to become dated. I guess Hollywood doesn't change. Neither does our impression of it. The idea that people played by the actors today do still exist today isn't so far fetch.I think the acting was on point. People picked up upon the highs and lows of the characters they played.Sometimes we wonder if life is imitating art or is art imitating life. With the way the world is today, there are some movies like this when you really do wonder what the basis is. Things in Hollywood were hush hush back then, I guess we'll never know.

reviews.review_title: Sunset Boulevard drives down the venomously paranoid streets of a scathingly ruthless Hollywood.
reviews.content: Silver screen classics, particularly noir films, drain the life force out of me. They require effort, stamina and widened blood-shot eyes in order to bypass the often gruelling glacial pace commonplace in films of that era. Then you get the odd few, '12 Angry Men' for example, that surpass even the greatest of expectations. Offering more captivation than a modern masterpiece, ageing finer than a bottle of Châteauneuf du Pape. This, ladies and gentlemen, is why we watch films. Sunset Boulevard may just be one of the most proficiently entrancing films I've ever watched, and I adored it.An unsuccessful screenwriter is hired by a faded silent-film star to write her screenplay, marking her ambitious return to the silver screen. Yet, when delusions become obsessions, her paranoid fantasies start to shroud him in a poisonous fog of wealth and ownership.Before I envelope myself in my own stream of consciousness, I want to start with some bold statements. Here goes nothing! Swanson's role as Norma Desmond is one of the greatest performances of all-time. Wilder and Brackett's screenplay is one of the greatest scripts of all-time. And, Sunset Boulevard is possibly the greatest story about Hollywood. Period. Now, just let those comments sink in for a moment. Much like you, I am also surprised by the overwhelming praise that flooded my mind as I watched this. But it happened. The infamous quote was executed. "All right, Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my close-up". And it was the first time I noticed that I blinked. For nearly two hours, I was hypnotised by the level of quality that was being output way back in 1950. Stunned into silence, I had to patiently wait for the overwhelming sense of perfection to leave my body.Sunset Boulevard was effortlessly perfect, and the majority of that stems from Swanson's excruciatingly realistic performance. This drama, first and foremost, is a character study. A silent-film star trapped in her own deluded mind where fame, fortune and popularity is left unchanged. Her refusal to accept change, her inability to progress, her latching onto her own self-importance. It's regressed her mentality into a state of delusional grandeur. Forming a tangible fantasy of her fabled "return" to the screen.Wilder's close attention to Swanson's theatricality grants us minuscule details when depicting her regressed state. The exaggerated body movement, particularly of the arms and face, are a secondary result of her excessive work in the silent-film era, almost likening her to a vampiric entity. The schizophrenic behaviour, instantly switching between happiness and melancholy, encapsulating her broken mental state. And none of this, absolutely none of it, would've been possible without Swanson's masterful performance. In fact, it's one of the greatest. She beautifully realised the character of Norma Desmond with an equal balance of power and fragility. It may just be one of the most accurate performances depicting melancholy that I've had the pleasure of viewing. Her range was extraordinary, and she devoured every single artistic set piece.Then you get Holden's illusory narration that exhumes the mind of a skilled writer. The flow, tempo and idyllic vocabulary. A poetic river that explored the illusory world of Hollywood. It instantly ensnared me with its sharp dialogue, allowing us to empathise and sympathise with his reluctant choices. Wilder's humour, and believe me there are some giggles to be had, compliments the delusory world being depicted. Fractured, almost. One scene you'll smile, the next you'll glance in fear. A clashing of tones orchestrated to produce a gorgeous symphony of thematic competence.Wilder's strong directorial hands ensured that the splitting of tones was minimal, only allowing subtle hints of fragility to seep through the cracked walls of the dilapidated mansion. A microcosm for the incongruous mind of Norma Desmond. Such simplistic yet memorable art design that emitted a trapped state of disrepair.Waxman's soothing score also alluding to a fantastically perfect world that Desmond embraced, yet still managing to draw up tension when required with erratic pitch changes. The majestic costumes, the concise editing, the gorgeous cinematography, the supporting performances. Nothing in this picture was wrong, and that's a rare statement for me to make.The ethereal aesthetic, considering it's entirely narrated by a murdered victim, only enhances the ghostly quality of its lead character. It's acute depiction of Hollywood's evolution, never steering away from its extremities, makes it one of the best films exploring the industry. It's definitive. It's sensational. It's perfect. Yes, Sunset Boulevard has just acquired the highest score possible. If ever there was a classic you need to watch, this is the one.

This film is older than my parents, yet it still left me speechless. I can only think of a few other films as timeless as "Sunset Blvd." I absolutely adore everything about this film. It is a landmark film in terms of its subject matter. Bill Wilder is one of the first directors to take on the problems that can come with living in the spotlight. For it's time, the film is an original idea. I can't think of any other film from that time that explores the idea of being a "has been" in terms of Hollywood society. The acting is superb all around, with special recognition deserved by the two leads. Gloria Swanson a fantastic job playing, well herself...but crazy. William Holden does a wonderful job keeping Norma's fantasy world intact as Joe Gillis.

Sunset Blvd. was a very impactful film and it deals with a lot of tough subjects and it shows also how Hollywood worked back then but you can even say that even today such staff may be hidden better but it is for sure still there buried under tone glomour and money,story in this film is very bravely told and Billy Wilder wasnt scared to represanted studios in their different lights and to expose them to our eyes,and show how easily they dispose actors once they become old or not useful to them,actors were great expecely Holden but Gloria Swanson was brilliant here and it is miracle that she didnt won oscar for this film,direction and storytelling was also very strong and it leaded story forward,Sunset Blvd.was a brilliant film with great dose of Noir and acts that were scenes stealers

Director/writer Billy Wilder and associates have created a film that rises above even the level of even a lot of the best melodramatic films of its era by ingeniously creating a device  the story focused on a silent film star and her distorted self-image  that encompasses the style and limitations of melodramatic acting itself, making a performance from Gloria Swanson as former Sennet bathing beauty Norma Desmond seem perfectly appropriate even at times when it might otherwise have been considered laughable. In fact the film in general shows a real black comic streak, right from its famous opening shot of screenwriter-turned gigolo Joe Gillis (William Holden) floating face-down in Desmond's swimming pool.One thing that stands out in the film is that it manages to be at the same time a very caustic fable about the allure and corruption of Hollywood while paying tribute to the classic era of silent films. Now that the film itself is older than the films it was then paying tribute to, it seems if anything more poignant then ever. It's true that Desmond eventually becomes a ridiculous person, but if anything the pathetic nature of her later years accentuates the marvel and the dignity of her earlier stardom and the era when she ruled the box-office. I'd actually be surprised if many people have not been introduced to the romance and majesty of silent cinema through this film  a film which ironically mocks the "talk, talk, talk" of the sound era while including some of its very best dialog. Although in many ways more grotesque than the average Lon Chaney or Boris Karloff character, Norma Desmond also captures the sympathy of the audience like all great movie monsters. It's possible to see Norma as a "femme fatale", but I think her situation too pitiful for that designation  I would liken her instead to Frankenstein's misunderstood and abandoned Monster (created as she was by Max, after all) or to the regal Dracula, hiding from the modern world in his ancient castle while he waits for new blood to devour and corrupt.There's a great deal of sadness and mystery, too, in this concept of 1920s Hollywood as a kind of lost and unlamented world. This is of course heightened by the presence of supporting actors like Buster Keaton, Ana Q. Nilsson, and especially director Erich Von Stroheim  like Swanson playing a thinly-disguised grotesque version of himself. Von Stroheim's Max is, like the troubled artist himself, a former director; his present-day role as a butler is fitting also because Von Stroheim had to play a number of such menial roles in his later years. "Sunset Boulevard" provided a once-in-a-lifetime chance for Von Stroheim and Swanson to show their powers once again; it's hard to believe either of them could really have thought of it as a "comeback" (the film's dialogue even mocks such pretensions), and they both give the kind of impassioned performances that leave no doubt that these brilliant performers have held absolutely nothing back, giving us two of the most honest and nakedly human performances of the era.My only complaint about the film is relatively minor  I've always felt that Joe Gillis is just too observant, world-wise, and engaging to really fall so completely into Norma Desmond's desperate clutches. The build-up is superbly handled, with the (often un-necessary and occasionally obtrusive) narration clueing us in to the fact that he thinks he can con Desmond initially but gradually becomes entangled in her life. I've just never completely believed the scene where Gillis leaves his friend's part to run home to Norma because of her suicide attempt. It's an effective scene, no doubt  Von Stroheim's manner and his announcement are so startling in the context of the revelry surrounding Gillis that the audience probably doesn't pause much to wonder why he is so upset or if he really would go back there right away. Frankly it seems to me like it should have confirmed his feeling that he needed to escape that place. Are we to believe Gillis' pronouncement that Norma was the only person in Hollywood who was good to him? And is his guilt enough to motivate him to return and become her lover, or is he primarily just a scared and bitter man seeking some asylum from the world? Certainly his character is intriguing but I've just never believed such a likable, interesting guy who really knows better and has good friends (especially frisky Betty Schaefer, played by Nancy Olson, a character which vaguely reminds me of Betty Comden) supporting him would feel the need to shut himself up alive in a metaphorical coffin. Just because I don't want to believe it, though, doesn't mean it might be too close to true for comfort.I'm always fascinated by stories that break down the "fourth wall." This film succeeds in this difficult manoever with incredible style and verve. This is a film about success  the great prize of huge success which destroys the possibility of joy derived from less grandiose endeavors, and the sad and equally great price of failure when it comes from resignation and fear. These characters touch us deeply because it's impossible not to see their greatness, and through witnessing their tragic downfall we become conscious of our own limitations within a culture that determines the value of a human being through such narrow parameters. "It's amazing how gentle people treat you when you're dead." Our deceased narrator reminds us  this great film by Billy Wilder urges us to shed some tears for the living as well, trapped as we all are in such an ultimately senseless and uncaring world.

reviews.review_title: The greatest film-based movie of all time!
reviews.content: I can't believe I never had the chance to watch this film for a long time, but I've recently seen it and it's a masterpiece.

Probably the director Billy Wilder's most well-known movie. In it a struggling film writer, Joe Gillis (William Holden), happens to meet a former silent film megastar, the dazzling Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson). She hires him to finish the script she has written, which is supposed to be her great comeback into cinema. But soon Joe finds himself pulled deeper and deeper into her life.I have to admit I have a fondness for movies that are about movies and the business of making them. Hollywood has built quite a legend around itself, a mythos even, and it is admittedly fascinating to watch.This movie is more about actors and acting than it is about movies in general, and it has quite a cynical tone to it. I very much like the fact that they cast an actual star of the silent movie era in Glorian Swanson. Gives the film authenticity. In Swanson you can see echoes of the distant past when movie stars lived like demigods, while the studios built entire sagas around their star power alone. Sure, this star power was carefully built, maintained and patented by the studios themselves. Not that this makes it any less interesting. Quite the opposite.Holden's performance is not bad at all, but it pales in comparison to Swanson's. Holden also talks a lot, providing the film with narration. I think I would have preferred the film without his constant input, but it's hard to say. He does add much needed snark, if nothing else.If we're talking about Billy Wilder movies, I liked both The Apartment and Witness for the Prosecution a lot more, but this one ain't bad either. Recommended.

Be forewarned, the cynicism in this movie is extreme.  But if you don't watch it, you will miss the best film about Hollywood ever, and one of the best films of all time ( #12 on the AFI list). Gloria Swanson gave undoubtedly the best performance of 1950, and should have won Best Actress.  William Holden, Erich von Stroheim, and Nancy Olsen also gave stunning performances and deserved their Oscar nominations. Darker than most films, but better than most films, this is a true classic, that hasn't dated one bit.  It also has one of my favorite lines in film.   Not Gloria Swanson's, but Holden's final narration.

"Sunset Boulevard" or if you will "Sunset Blvd." is a classic Billy Wilder noir-ish tale of a forgotten silent film star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) and a down on his luck screen writer Joe Gillis (William Holden and their May-December relationship.Gillis turns into a driveway while running from finance company representatives who are trying to repossess his car. On the grounds Gillis discovers an old mausoleum of a mansion that has fallen into disrepair. Mistaken for an undertaker, Gillis is invited inside where he discovers that the owner of the house is none other than Norma Desmond and her servant Max (Eric von Stroheim).At first Gillis wants to flee but then sees an opportunity to make some money off the lonely Desmond. The opportunity becomes reality when Norma invites Joe to move in where she showers him with money and gifts in return for his affection. All goes well until Joe becomes involved with studio employee Betty Schaefer (Nancy Olsen) with whom he falls in love. This leads to tragic consequences for both Norma and Joe.Gloria Swanson was anything but the lonely forgotten silent film star she portrays in this film. There were however, some interesting parallels to her own life. She did actually work for Cecil B. De Mille (who has a cameo in this film) and was directed by Stroheim in "Queen Kelly" (1928). She had faded from films in the 30s but kept working on the stage and in the occasional film. "Queen Kelly" is the film that Norma screens for Joe where she vows to return to past glory.For Holden, this was the film that made him a super star rather than just another contract leading man. He plays a totally self-serving character who uses Norma to his own ends.Stroheim who was best known for his extravagant direction of silent films, was actually a pretty good actor as well. His performance as Max, Norma's faithful former husband/director/protector stands up with those of Swanson and Holden.Also in the cast are Fred Clark as Sheldrake the movie producer, Jack Webb as Joe's friend Artie Green, Hedda Hopper as herself and as the "wax works" playing bridge, former silent stars Anna Q. Nilsson, Buster Keaton and H.B. Warner. Nilsson is shown puffing away on a cigarette, Warner looks asleep but Keaton (misused again) manages to get in one of his signature dead pan expressions in his brief appearance.A marvelous film and another Billy Wilder classic.

Great acting all around, Billy Wilder proves he's one of the master writer/directors... a real treat of a film. Don't expect a fast moving story, but still worth the time. That score is a little overbearing at times, but hey, loud isn't always bad. ****/5

reviews.review_title: The normal way to bury a monkey
reviews.content: Sunset Blvd. is probably the Billy Wilder movie that Hollywood loves the most because it's about Hollywood. The problem that Hollywood movies tend to have and occasionally fall completely into is that they are insular without appeal to those not of the business. Sunset Blvd. is definitely full of the kinds of references Hollywood movies are tend to carry, but the central story is as relatable and fascinating from a basic human point of view that really gets the audience involved from beginning to end.Everyone is just out of place in this movie. The most obvious example is Norma Desmond, the silent star who's desperate to make it in the new Hollywood, but the rest of them are looking to move from the place where they reside to the place they wish to be. In the process, they have to play parts that they don't feel quite comfortable with. That conflict, which is present through every major character in the film, is what gives the film such a rich narrative texture.Joe Gillis is a down and out writer from the Midwest trying to make his way in Hollywood, but nothing he writes appeals to anyone anymore. He's on his last dollar and beginning to think about going back home. Running from repo men, he drives into a seemingly abandoned driveway which happens to be owned by Norma Desmond. In his desperation, he ends up as effectively her pet, replacing the pet monkey she buries on his first night in the house. What develops is an odd relationship (implied sexual) where Norma lords over Joe and Joe becomes completely subservient to Norma's whims. He accepts it to a certain degree, but he still chafes under it.He escapes nights at a time and meets with Betty Schaefer, a low level reader at the movie studio, to hammer out a screenplay that could make both of their careers (or not, Joe admits). Betty grew up in a Hollywood family and wants to be a real screenwriter instead of just a reader. She's on one end of the writing career path (Joe is on the other), and they're trying to meet in the middle. She's pretty, smart, a realist, and engaged to someone else.Through all of this, Norma is trying to get back into the spotlight. Her isolated life with only her butler, Max, has warped her mind. Max has directed her life in the background, writing fan letters for her every week and managing her day to day existence. She's writing an overlong screenplay of the Princess Salome (who was a teenager at the interesting points in her life) whom she plans to play (despite being in her fifties). She's the ultimate portrait of self-delusion, wearing a mask that she can't see through but everyone else can. She's convinced that she's just one writer and a single meeting with Cecile B. DeMille from getting her Salome on the screen. Joe is obviously that writer (admitting to us in voiceover that the script is terrible and no amount of his work on it will improve it). All along the way, even through her meeting with DeMille, everyone admits to themselves and to others Norma's delusion, but no one will shatter it for her.Joe's cynicism is what carries him through his experience overall, but it's also what allows him to finally be the one person to shatter Norma's vision of herself. The decades of her delusion, though, don't mix well with the revelation and Norma shoots Joe in the back, ending the movie where it began with Joe floating in Norma's pool.The movie is a wonderful look at delusion and deception, a very common motif in Wilder's work. The characters are rich with a great mixture of characters across the cynicism spectrum, each dealing with their own desires to be in their ideal places. Acting is great across the board, and the writing is elegantly assembled and witty all at once. It's a great piece of entertainment that thematically rich, visually resplendent, and just a fantastic time at the movies.

"Gillis" (William Holden) is a down-at-heel script writer who is struggling to keep his head above water. Not having had any successes for a while, his car is about to be repossessed and his erstwhile boss "Sheldrake" (Fred Clark) has nothing for him. On the run from the pursuing repo men, he turns his car into the drive of a decaying old mansion. Hiding his car in the garage, he is mistaken by the house's owner for an undertaker - she has a small matter that needs attending too! Realising her error she demands he leave, but not before he mentions what he does for a living. She has a script. Hundreds of pages of script - and she offers him a job, champagne and caviar if he will edit and refine it so "Norma Desmond" (Gloria Swanson), a retired former silent movie star, can present it to her favourite director Cecil B DeMille and restart her glorious career. Initially just seeing dollar signs, he agrees and what now ensues is a masterfully crafted story of love, dependency, ambition and delusion in which Swanson absolutely shines. It's clear to us from the outset that her grasp on reality is somewhat limited, and but for her dedicated factotum "Max" (Erich von Stroheim) she might well have fallen victim to her own depression many years ago. Holden is also on solid form here, his initial selfishness starts to morph into something more, he begins to care for this woman whose head is increasingly in the clouds, and upon whom she is becoming more reliant. The dialogue is delivered via a mix of Holden's quite honest narrative and the conversations between the characters delivering some of the best lines in cinema - "I'm still big - it's the world that's got smaller!".
