The mental decline and instability of "Desmond" is expertly displayed here by a star who new a thing or two herself about the silent film scene, and who brings her facial expressions, her mannerisms and her generally star-studded demeanour to bear really effectively as the audience gradually realise that nothing here is going to pan out as it seems - or as anyone wants. Von Stroheim underplays his supporting role with aplomb and though I didn't really love the sub-plot with Nancy Olson's "Betty Schaefer" - it took away from the intensity of the main storyline - it did to serve to illustrate just how powerful jealousy can be. This is a super film, that still captivates on a big screen and is really well worth sitting down to watch.,

reviews.review_title: Wilder lays Hollywood out in Lavender
reviews.content: Accused by LB Mayer of biting the hand that fed him Billy Wilder's Sunset Boulevard is one dark, suspenseful but highly entertaining work of art. Arguably his finest script Sunset also gets career highs from pantheon cinematographer Joseph Seitz and composer Franz Waxman whose score not content to just provide background intricately attaches itself to the action, accenting one powerful scene after the next.Aspiring screenwriter Joe Gillis (William Holden) is trying to stay one step ahead of the finance company out to repossess his car when takes shelter in an old movie star's run down mansion. Mistaken for an undertaker there to wake her dead monkey he's persuaded to stay in a room over the garage but the washed up silent star Norma Desmond has other designs for him. He chafes at the gigolo role but finds the lavish lifestyle hard to reject. When he connects with another writer as collaborator and romantic interest he decides to make a final break from the unstable Desmond.Holden's sardonic narration and Gloria Swanson's delusional Norma deliver Wilder and Leigh Bracket's biting script with emphasis in every word as morbid humor mixes with tragedy within the suffocating stage of the oppressive mansion along with the dour butler (perfectly played by Erich Von Stroheim) and the few visitors, actual former silent stars playing themselves, referred to by Gillis as "the waxworks."Also playing themselves are a sensitive but forceful Cecil B. DeMille and a shrewish Hedda Hopper as well as the Paramount Studio itself. There is also a fine supporting performance by Nancy Olsen as the late love interest but nothing surpasses the strident performance of Swanson that some may argue is over the top in spots while at the same time demanding it to be effective. Sunset Boulevard is an expressionistic masterpiece by one of Hollywood's best displaying it at its worst. Superb celluloid theatre.

I finally saw Sunset Boulevard on DVD this week. I had never seen this classic film before. Gloria Swanson made the most of this comeback role by delivering a great performance as silent film legend Norma Desmond. Creepy and self-delusional, Norma has basically imprisoned herself and her manservant Max in a run-down Hollywood mansion. Life at the mansion is disturbed when young script writer Joe Gillis (played by the always excellent William Holden) uses the garage as a hideout running away from his car's repo men.Events begin to unfold which leave Joe questioning his own morality and standards. I won't get any further into the plot details just in case there are any other people out there like myself who haven't seen this film.A few interesting details I have learned about this movie which might interest some folks out there. Both Mae West and Mary Pickford were offered the Norma Desmond role before Gloria Swanson. Mae West didn't get it because she wanted to rewrite much of Norma's dialog. That was not acceptable to director Billy Wilder, who didn't allow any deviation from the script. Mary Pickford always retained ownership rights to her silent films. That wasn't going to happen with Sunset Boulevard so Pickford was out. Montgomery Clift was first offered the pivotal role of writer Joe Gillis and actually accepted the part. Thinking about the role while on vacation in Europe Clift came to the conclusion that the "kept man " aspect of Joe Gillis' relationship with Norma Desmond too closely mirrored his real life relationship with a wealthy New York socialite. Clift turned the role down upon his return to America.Hollywood had very mixed reactions to this film. Famous MGM mogul Louis B. Mayer stormed out after an early screening of Sunset Boulevard and engaged Billy Wilder in a very profane tirade accusing Wilder of stabbing the film industry in the back. Wilder gave as good as he got to the red-faced Mayer. If you haven't seen Sunset Boulevard do yourself a favor and check out this classic. It will stick with you for a while.

reviews.review_title: Sunset Boulevard (1950 Paramount) is incredible for it's honesty and candor
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard (1950 Paramount) starring William Holden and Gloria Swanson is wonderful. Screen it often.It's about art, and about the trouble with art, and people part of art.Big egos, big ideas, no results, sad politics and back-stabbing on and on and on. William Holden, the then (1950) star of the movie is shown playing the role of a Hollywood "player" (a writer) who ends up with a lonely, humiliating death. He went on to win a Best Actor Academy Award for Stalag 17 (1953) and was future USA President Ronald Reagan's best man at Reagan's 1952 shot-gun, justice of the peace wedding to his pregnant bride, Nancy Davis (Reagan's daughter, Patty Davis, who went on to pose nude for Playboy Magazine, was born 7 months after the wedding...the bride, Nancy Davis, was later first lady of the USA Nancy Reagan..."good girls go to heaven...bad girls go everywhere!").Holden went on to die alone in a humiliating way in the early 1980's (found dead for days alone in his apt.), and Reagan went on to be USA President....occupied the White house when Holden was found dead.Holden became what he portrayed. This happens a lot in the movies. A word to the wise for movie stars and other actors...be careful what roles you play....you may end up playing these roles in real life.Gloria Swanson plays an old lady in this movie, and still hadn't reached age 50. Compare her with Cher, roughly the same age in Moonstruck (1987) who won a Best Actress Academy Award which included romantic nude sex bedroom scenes with much younger Nicholas Cage (roughly the same age as William Holden when Holden acted in Sunset Blvd. [1950]).Cher stayed gorgeous in her 40's, became the mother of a famous homosexual daughter turned "male" first named "Chastity," then re-named "Chaz," not a bit as pretty as Mom...bad weight problem, among other problems. That's Hollywood! Swanson and Cecil B. DeMille both acted in Sunset Blvd. (1950) and both were very good. Two of the biggest major players in silent era world cinema history....this movie is worth seeing just to look at them, see them talk, see why they were so good at what they did.The final scene shows the hero getting shot in the back....by the other hero in the movie.No epic is big enough for two heroes. Keep that in mind if you're a hero.------------- Written by Tex Allen, SAG Actor. reviews.review_title: She is a victim of technological progress
reviews.content: For such a representative film noir, I always admire it with great respect. This is the transition period from the silent era to the sound era in Hollywood, and it is also a mockery of Hollywood's own industrial system. Sunset Boulevard showcases the dark side of the Hollywood dream. It is worth mentioning that part of the film was filmed in Paramount. Movies are not just a way to express human emotions. More often, its ruthless wheels do not know how many film workers' souls are crushed to death.

This opens with a corpse.  And so to every recent movie told in flashback and leading inexorably to tragedy.  But this did it first and better.  And in Norma Desmond it created one of the most chillingly insane women ever to grace the screen.  And I'm a sucker for a psycho bitch from Hell.  But this does it in a very classy way.  Probably classier than the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical version, anyway.

reviews.review_title: A sad and true portrait of Hollywood
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevar is undoubtedly one of the greatest masterpieces of cinema and certainly one of my favorite films.The film tells the story of an unsuccessful screenwriter who has a flat tire and seeks shelter in a large mansion that appears to be abandoned, but the owner of the house was Norma Desmond, a big silent movie star who hasn't made a film in twenty years. . So she decides to hire the boy to write the script for her next film.I'm in love with this film, everything about it is incredible, soundtrack, direction, visual and obviously Gloria Swanson's brilliant performance, which I consider one of the best female performances in cinema. For me a mandatory film for everyone who says they love cinema, it is an absolute classic that deserves to be seen. He is certainly worthy of the 11 Oscar categories in which he was nominated.

reviews.review_title: Best seen as a twin film with "All about Eve" (1950)
reviews.content: In 1950 there were two classic films about aging actresses, "Sunset boulevard" (Billy Wilder) and "All about Eve" (Joseph Mankiewicz). In both films the character of the aging actress was played by an aging actress. Bette Davis (42) in "All about Eve" and Gloria Swanson (51) in "Sunset boulevard".In "All about Eve" Bette Davis is aware of the fact that her career is coming to an end. This makes her cynical and the strongest point in "All about Eve" is the sharp dialogue.In "Sunset boulevard" Gloria Swanson keeps dreaming of a come back. This makes her a tragic person. The strongest point in "Sunset boulevard" is the acting style of Swanson. With her major successes in the '20s this acting style was already very dated in 1950. This however fits in perfectly with the character she plays in "Sunset boulevard".Ironically "All about Eve" turned out to be the come back of Bette Davis while "Sunset boulevard" definitely was the last great film of Gloria Swanson.

reviews.review_title: "I'm ready for my close up Mr. DeMille"
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard (1950) is one of the most admired classic films of all time. It deserves all the praise that it has received and will always receive. Every facet of the film is done so well, especially the performances by the ever talented actors. Gloria Swanson absolutely made this film, her performance will blow you away. She commands every scene she's in, she has to because of her character. Her character is so complex and interesting, so much so that it's impossible to look away. The story revolves around a man who stumbles upon an old seemingly abandoned mansion and meets a middle aged washed up actress named Norma Desmond. She showers him with lavish gifts and lets him stay at her Hollywood mansion in exchange for him reading a script she wrote and editing it for her. Eventually, things become very complicated when other factors are thrown into the mix. And then that's where we get the real meat of the film. It really is a great film that is very entertaining. It may be very old, but it'll never lose it's quality or it's well deserved place on the list of the most famous films ever. 9/10

From the opening monologue this movie promised something interesting, and it delivers but it almost turns into an endless wacky drag, luckily the love story saves it from happening. Flawlessly acted by Gloria Swanson, she really nailed the grand delusion. I had the general idea of where the movie was going but I was still really excited to see what will happens next, perfectly constructed story and what a way to end a great drama with a great big metaphor of the killing of Joe Gillis. Joe walking down silently was a metaphor to the once great silent movie and the loud bang from Desmond's gun is the current state of cinema where dialogue rules.

This is without a doubt in my mind one of the best films ever made. We start out where our main character Joe is dead in a pool. This is the story of how he met his demise. The plot is that Joe is avoiding having his car repossessed by hiding out in an out of work actresses house, played by Gloria Swansen, who did the best acting job of her career in this film. It's a dark film, and almost seems as though it would have reached a cult status, but it reached a full fledged classic. It is one of the best movies out there, and my favorite movie (tied with Touch of Evil) from the 50's time era.My rating: ****/****. 114 mins. Not Rated.

reviews.review_title: The aura and mystery of Old Hollywood...
reviews.content: What is amazing about this film is how it still stands up to the times; still has a theme worthy of exploring; still comments on the disposable stars and tragedy of the old Hollywood system, which still seems romantic and glamorous compared to what we have today.Gloria Swanson is excellent, William Holden the tragic, "down on-his luck" writer from Ohio, trying to survive in Hollywood. Many of us know the story, or have seen parodies of it (for example, on the Carol Burnett show). But if you have any interest in Old Hollywood, you will love this film. It touches on isolation, aging, psychosis, and melodrama in a most unique way.The visuals are Gothic and haunting. The old terrazzo floor on which Valentino danced the tango, the old stars at Norma Desmond's house, discarded, playing cards to pass the time. The omniscient Olympic sized swimming pool, never haunted by guests. A mansion filled with memories and mementos, but not people.Sunset Boulevard today has but a few old buildings, modern life has all but erased the Old Hollywood which existed at that time. Today it is a strange anachronism to see Grauman's Chinese Theatre, and advertisements next to it, for todays movies . This film is worth seeing more than once. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: "I'm ready for my closeup Mr DeMille".
reviews.content: In the 100+ years of motion pictures, we've been treated to many classics, including a few set in Tinseltown itself. Despite the excellence of such examples as SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS, THE PLAYER, and SINGIN' IN THE RAIN, Billy Wilder's SUNSET BLVD remains the greatest movie ever made about Hollywood. Its legendary status since then has been so prevalent that it became a successful Broadway musical in the 1990s. Carol Burnett even parodied it in her long running variety television show.Wilder was a mischievous filmmaker who knew that this project would bite at the fingers that fed him. With SUNSET BLVD, he gave us a cynical exercise portraying the Dream Factory as an eat-'em-up-and-spit-'em-out business that treats its own as disposable commodities to be set aside when the next big thing comes along.Considering how Gloria Swanson and William Holden are so identified with the public as Norma Desmond and Joe Gillis, it might surprise some to learn that neither was the first choices for those roles. Mary Pickford was the first actress considered for Norma, but the silent film queen demanded changes to the character. Big mistake, for the one thing Wilder would never compromise on was a script he painstakingly put together. Once Pickford was out, Mae West was approached, but she was indignant over the suggestion that she was a has-been, despite the fact that West was in her late fifties. Wilder's friend George Cukor suggested Swanson, who wasn't the slightest bit offended about the character and happily agreed to take part.Although Montgomery Clift was the actor originally slated for the part of Joe Gillis he dropped out two weeks before filming was to begin. Apparently, the gigolo character hit a little too close to home to him in his private life, as he had a ambiguous relationship with Libby Holman. Enraged, Wilder quickly sought a replacement within the Paramount stable. After Fred MacMurray and Ray Milland declined the offer, William Holden's name was next, and he happily agreed to take on the role.SUNSET BLVD opens with police cars speeding down the title roadway with sirens a-blaring. They arrive at a mansion where the dead body of a young man with three bullet holes is floating in the swimming pool. The voiceover narration is done by the corpse himself, as the film flashes back almost a year, where Joe Gillis is a hack screenwriter with B-movies to his credit and debts to his name. He's not only unable to interest Paramount in his latest script, but can't even secure a personal loan so he can keep his car.Keeping one step ahead of the repo men, a tire blowout lands him in the driveway of a Hollywood mansion on Sunset Boulevard. After parking his vehicle in the owner's garage, Gillis starts checking out his temporary sanctuary. In voiceover, Joe accurately describes the place as similar to that of Miss Havisham, which anyone who's read "Great Expectations" or seen David Lean's movie version will understand right away. There's a dilapidated looking swimming pool that appears to have last been used when the stock market crashed. And Gillis hasn't even set foot inside the mansion yet....The home belongs to Norma Desmond, a faded silent screen legend who's never forgiven Hollywood for transferring to sound. She's the perfect embodiment of the phrase living in the past", railing against the current crop of movie stars she disdainfully refers to as nobodies. All over her mansions are monuments to herself, photograph after photograph of her as she appeared back in the roaring Twenties. The only other person in her gothic web is her manservant Max (Erich von Stroheim), himself an oddball too.About to lay her late chimp to rest, Norma mistakes Gillis for a funeral rep until discovering his true identity. Upon realizing that he's a screenwriter, she proposes hiring him to adapt her own personal treatment about the life of Salome. Norma is so delusional that she thinks Cecil B DeMille will drop everything to work with her again, despite the fact she hasn't made a movie in twenty years.Since he has nothing but debts mounting, Joe agrees, but there's a caveat. Paranoid about letting her pet project out of her sight, she insists that he work at her mansion, with a spare room provided for him above the garage. Realizing that bill collectors will never think of looking for him here, he agrees, but soon finds himself feeling restricted, and having the humorless Max hovering over doesn't make him feel any more comfortable.Gillis has an uneasy feeling his employer views him in more than just a professional capacity, something confirmed when Norma arranges a private New Year's party for just the two of them. Her showering him with gifts such as tuxedos, cufflinks, and a gold-plated cigarette case only increases his feelings of helplessness and confinement. His debts have been paid off thanks to Norma, but it's come at a cost to his freedom now that's he's become a kept man, a gigolo.Creative stimulation arrives in the form of Betty Schaeffer, a script reader at Paramount hoping to become a writer herself. Her fiancee is a pal of Joe's, an assistant director, and while he's on location in Arizona, she and Gillis pool their resources to work on their own story. But because of Norma's possessiveness, it's a project that has to be done in secrecy.SUNSET BLVD is a magnificent example of what happens when first-rate talents get together to create a work of art. I don't think even the great Bernard Herrmann could have provided a better music score than Franz Waxman does here. John Seitz does wonders with the cinematography, especially with his use of mirrors on the bottom of the swimming pool to obtain a frontal shot of the floating corpse. And according to Nancy Olson, who played Betty, Wilder and his team made sure that the dust and cobwebs of Norma's mansion were laid out with mathematical precision. That's how meticulous they were!When SUNSET BLVD came out in 1950, Gloria Swanson received more acclaim for her performance as Norma Desmond than any of her silent movies. The final shot of her melodramatically descending her staircase in a state of delusion is one for the ages. And when it came to his work in front of the camera, Erich von Stroheim has never been better either. For William Holden, SUNSET BLVD allowed him the opportunity to move past what he derisively referred to as his "Smiling Jim" roles, and show what he was capable of when given the chance. It was a career altering movie for him. Holden, Swanson, von Stroheim, and Olson were all nominated for Oscars.The only people unhappy with SUNSET BLVD were the moguls who didn't appreciate being implied as callous and uncaring. One in particular was Louis B Mayer, chairman of M. G. M., who raged at Wilder following the premiere, accusing him of biting the hand that feeds him. Undaunted, Wilder merely told him to stick it where the sun doesn't shine.SUNSET BLVD is another splendid feather in the cap of Billy Wilder.

I'm not really sure what to say about this film. You have to be a little crazy to want into an industry whose motto is "what have you done for me lately", but then again Norma Desmond played by Gloria Swanson is a little touched in the head to begin with.Fame and wealth for being popular with people is a pretty heady thing. Just ask any professional athlete. For the aging actress in Hollywood s golden era it's a death knell. The kind of thing that can drive a person insane. And so it is with Desmond, the kind of actress who wanted nothing but attention, and not the ability to work the inner craftsmanship that goes into a major motion picture. She misses the attention, the glitz, the glamour of being "a star", and nothing more. Like another reviewer stated, this is a pretty cynical film. But it's also over the top, which offsets the imagined cynicism. I guess there's a romanticism there that personal attachments will clash with business practicalities, and that that collision will produce an attention getting dynamic for all to witness. Norma can't see that the latter is what's pushed her aside, and that not matter how much she fawns and desired to be fawned, that her glory days in the eyes of Paramount Studios, are over. It drove her crazy.As for the rest of the film, like I say, it's over the top. The performances are borderline melodrama, the plot is thin but plausible for a woman on the wane, and the characters, like the film, are also a little too much as well.Well, I think of my own film career, and I wonder if I'm not on the Norma Desmond side of things at this point in my life. Eh, like I give a damn.See it once. If you're into the whole "Hollywood" thing (you're a woman or homosexual man with stars in their eyes, and like "glam"), then this might entertain. It's touted as a classic. I can see why, but I wouldn't rank it as one.Just me.p.s. with all of the sugary and happy Hollywood endings of other films, this one was intentionally geared to go against the market trend, and it worked.

A black comedy meta satirical noir with engaging and intriguing screenplay, equally engaging and fun narration from HOLDEN and with fantastic performances.The cast members were all fine but the character of NORMA, a self and camera obessed, suicidal, companionship yearning, aging, talkies and technicolor films hating, living in the past, yesteryear silent star was so convicingly and expressively played out by SWANSON that she stole almost every scene she was in, shared or solo.This resulted in the character being easily dislikeable, annoying, creepy and still a bit sympathetical too.Her complete descendance into madness devouring the climax was a pretty memorable and scary scene.Max was another character I felt sympathy for.Dug that BUSTER KEATON cameo appearance...
Dude was silent even in a talkies.

reviews.review_title: A tragic tale of obsession, passion and abject loneliness.
reviews.content: This is one brilliant but tragic love story, with two of the greatest actors of their generations. Gloria Swanson gives one hell of a performance as a lonely, washed up superstar, whilst a young William Holden plays the object of her desire. The film is wonderfully crafted, full of atmosphere and with some of the most brooding, dramatic scenes ever captured. Just seethes with a gripping tension but always with a tinge of great sadness. You just fall in love with this film from the very opening to the desperate ending, Contains madness and despair.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films ever made
reviews.content: Where to start? The genius of Billy Wilder as a director is well know. All his films are masterful in direction. To me that means not a shot out of place. From the beginning, Holden dead in the pool, shot from the bottom of the pool and narrated by the dead man was ground breaking and genius. The casting of Von Stroheim, Swanson, Webb, and of course Holden is perfect. The cameo with DeMille incredible. Maybe its because I am a filmmaker myself that I get so much joy out of this film. I don't watch many films more than once but I just saw this again and couldn't pull myself away. The dialogue, cinematography, editing, sound and music are exacting, as a great film should be. I lived on Ivar in the 1970's I realize it was one block away from Holden's apartment. There is so much truth in this movie about the film industry and about life.

reviews.review_title: As fine as film noir gets!
reviews.content: How do you get more culturally meta with film than by making a film noir set inside the Hollywood landscape itself? Well, Sunset Boulevard answers that non-specific question in a beautiful fashion and then some by telling a story about 'delusions of grandeur' and how time's passage can become an unforgiving beast for movie stars still gloating about their 'good old days'. Norma Desmond is an out-of-touch actress who's refused to come to terms with, or accept, reality. She happens to come across struggling screenwriter Joe Gillis escaping from the men who lent him his car. After skidding onto the former star's driveway by coincidence, Joe's life takes one dark turn after another: and the film's look into career realism as well as its equally potent career naivety (even if the person it's coming from has more experience in real life). Norma is one of cinema's prettiest faces embodying the idea of tragedy and aged celebrity-status.Sunset Boulevard is the classically conceived kind of 'toxic valentine' that's inspired similar tales from Hollywood to exploit the many rewards and dangers of being blinded by show-business. It's film-noir that doesn't involve stealing an artifact or something: it's a film noir that comes from (and explores) the very medium where the genre began. It's meta-genius in classic American cinema.Sunset Boulevard gets 5/5 stars.

Imagine if she knew about social media?Absolutely fantastic film. Terrific and haunting performance by Gloria Swanson - quite honestly, one of the best ever, even if all the actors are in a good plan - and of the best screenplays in history.It's hard to say something bad about this - maybe that romance between the writers is a bit too forced? - as everything seems to work from the very first scene until the end. Magnific production design, cinematography and what about those shots? That score? Cinema!

I just watched "Sunset Blvd." on TV since I heard it was a classic but wow what a bore. It was overwrought, overacted, and took way too long to get to its obvious conclusion. I did not like the opening scene and having a dead man narrate the film was stupid. None of the relationships felt real, it was like a bad stage play with characters that I did not care about. The characters in the film even quipped about writing movies which are cheap to produce, and that is exactly what "Sunset Blvd." is, basically a cheap staged play set right in Hollywood. And why did the other love interest have to be engaged already, that just ruined the potential for that relationship. My rating: 3/10; I won't be watching it again.

The story, set in '50s Hollywood, focuses on Norma Desmond, a silent-screen goddess whose pathetic belief in her own indestructibility has turned her into a demented recluse. The crumbling Sunset Boulevard mansion where she lives with only her butler, Max who was once her director and husband has become her self-contained world. Norma dreams of a comeback to pictures and she begins a relationship with Joe Gillis, a small-time writer who becomes her lover, that will soon end with murder and total madness.I'm surprised by this film. I really am. I thought I wouldn't have liked this film but wow, was this a brilliant film. "Sunset Blvd." plays like a satirical film noir, with hints of romance, comedy, thriller, suspense, horror, and surrealism, and yet, these things mix together perfectly on screen. It's kind of similar to "Singin' in the Rain" and "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane" combined, with the whole faded famous actress who wants to come back on screen and the transition of the silent film era to films with audio, which is not a bad thing, really.The script is filled with impeccable and irresistible dialogue but, to no surprise, the one thing that makes this movie great, in the first place, is Gloria Swanson. At first, she may seem a melodramatic drama queen. Well, she is. However, as the movie progresses, you see her character becoming crazier and crazier, to a point, where, she's so crazy that she, herself, can't see that she's crazy. It's excellent! I don't know why she didn't win for an Oscar for Best Actress but she should have. I found her as a sympathetic villain, because we, the audience, know that she's a bit misunderstood. Her character becomes a faded movie star because of Hollywood leaving her behind in the silent film era. She has become stuck in the past that everyone else has moved on.William Holden does a well job, spending along side Swanson for most of the film. Erich von Stroheim, playing Swanson's butler, also does a fine job, and Nancy Olson does a fantastic job with hitting the marks with every scene she's in. The score by Franz Waxman was surprisingly great. I loved it. I should also give a shout out to the production and costume designers too. The black-and-white film noir cinematography, by John F. Seitz, creates some dramatic effects in some scenes.Overall, the film was nothing short of brilliant. Gloria Swanson, as the infamous Norma Desmond, is dazzling, along with the other three actors I've mentioned before. The script is just right for each scene and the end of the film is perfect. If you're a person who just loves watching movies, please add this onto your growing list of movies. You won't regret it.

Billy Wilder had a long and much-honored career as a director. He made some of the best light comedies of his or any other era, but his best and most essential films pushed the boundaries of Hollywood at the time. From The Long Weekend's devastating look at the reality of alcoholism, to the frank discussion of changing societal norms in The Apartment, to making Holmes and Watson homosexual lovers in The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes, Wilder was always breaking new ground in what could be shown on the big screen.Sunset Blvd. may be his crowning achievement in boundary pushing, just because it is one of the most savage attacks on the mythos of Hollywood ever created. He spares no expense to bite the hands that feeds him, digging way deep beyond the glamor and into the reality of stars, former stars, and wannabes. The casting is dead-on, with Gloria Swanson and Ericj von Stroheim in particular--they had both been eaten up by the Hollywood system some time before 1950.Sunset Blvd's self-reflexive deconstruction of Hollywood myth would be enough by itself, but it's actually just one layer of many in a truly great film. It's also a fairly gripping detective story, downright funny in moments, and absolutely horrific in others--Swanson's famous "I'm ready for my closeup, Mr. Demille" in particular can still send shivers down your spine. Besides being one of the all-time great directors, Wilder was a hell of a writer who collaborated with some of the best screenwriters in the business; his long partnership with I.A.L. Diamond is legendary, but this is the last of 13 collaborations with Charles Brackett, who brought just the right amount of pathos and tragedy to the script, no doubt aided by his experience working behind the camera in Hollywood for years.If you are a film buff or a student of Golden Age Hollywood, you will likely add Sunset Blvd. to your list of all-time greatest movies, but you don't have to be a film student to enjoy it either. It's dramatic, funny, chilling, and really just a joy to watch unfold. Many great films of the late 1940s and early 1950s are still enjoyable to this day, but even the best of them can seem somewhat dated today. Not so with Sunset Blvd., which is as potent and stunning as it was in 1950. One of the all-time best films, Sunset Blvd. is highly recommended viewing.

reviews.review_title: Hollywood is the story, a masterpiece.
reviews.content: A film I always seemed to have skipped. If only I knew how good it was. I like films from Hollywood's Golden Age, Sunset Blvd epitomizes the Golden Age more than any other film out there.Director/writer Billy Wilder gives an insight into the Hollywood studio system, its forgotten stars from the earliest silent era of film in an interesting character Norma Desmond (played by long forgotten actress Gloria Swanson). I must admit to never hearing of the late actress but she has an extensive silent-era filmography. It has elements of black comedy, a romantic element and a shocking noir like death.What I also liked about this picture was that real Hollywood people play themselves. Legends like Buster Keaton and director Cecil B. DeMille (The Ten Commandments (1956)).One of the most important characters in the film is Norma Desmond's butler, played by Erich von Stroheim, a director from the silent era who ends up forgotten like Norma Desmond now her servant as such.I highly recommend this film to anyone who likes movies from any era. A fictional retelling of Hollywood behind the scenes.

reviews.review_title: A shocking and well-done motion picture, culturally significant.
reviews.content: The acting and drama in this movie is stunning to witness. Gloria Swanson especially shined in this film. What she was able to do with her eyes, facial expressions, as well as her body language alongside her actual line delivery was truly noteworthy. I feel like this film foreshadowed a great deal about the Hollywood movie industry with how it was becoming bigger and more complex and it showed how it changed even just in the first half of the 20th century (and makes you think how different it is now from even then). It also demonstrated how narcissism/self-obsession and obsession with the past can truly ruin an individual and their sanity. Overall it is truly well-made and timeless, but the only thing that kind of lost me a little was the love-triangle part of the plot, and it is true that some things don't hold up a ton anymore. Still, very remarkable for the time it came out!

From the fifties to the seventies, Sunset Blvd was the place to go and be. You could cruise it and there were places it could be walked for blocks and nightclubs galore. I even visited an old empty mansion in the hills, broke into it and walked around. Everyone said it was haunted and the police used to come and chase people away. Great night out. Some of that nostalgia is captured in this movie and is in the background as well as theme of the movie. As far as the movie itself goes, it is a good story, well told and acted out to perfection. It presents an older woman using a younger man for her vain and selfish purposes and the man going along with it first out of necessity and later on like an insect in a spider's web. Stuck and no where to go with a hungry female prowling around. Nicely done on this point and the point of everyone coming to Hollywood to struggle until they got recognized for anything and start to make some real money. Schwabs drugstore in the movie was a real hangout too. BTW...when one wasn't on Sunset Blvd they were cruising Hollywood Blvd. There was always some action going on these two streets. Lastly, I got the chills watching this as I had a woman chasing me just like this one chased William Holden (no sex) offering me money, free lunches/dinners and gifts galore if I only devote myself to her. Mind you I am married but it didn't stop this obsessive person including her making me her heir. I even told her off (many times) and she would not let go. Creepy and dysfunctional to say the least. Enjoy this glimpse of real life back then but still happening today here and there and everywhere.... Come and visit ...

reviews.review_title: A Young Hollywood Caught in a Movie Time Warp
reviews.content: NOTE: The following is more of an essay than a review.Hollywood, the physical place, became the center of entertainment productions on a large scale through the use of moving photo frames to tell a story from circa 1910. Soundtracks began being added in 1928, the beginning of the so-called "talkies". ("The Jazz Singer" of 1927 was a hybrid of a silent/talking film.) Very soon, motion pictures (aka movies) became the most popular form of a relatively inexpensive entertainment until the advent of television in the 1940's.Almost from the get-go, the people producing the entertainments quickly realized they were creating a whole new culture. It was no longer just entertainment for entertainment's sake. Viewers began falling in love with some of the characters on screen. They sent letters to the actors and actresses. Some viewers believed that what they were seeing was real. Films became fantasies and the screens were like windows into another world.A large number of female viewers in the 1920's believed Rudolph Valentino was a great lover, even though no one outside of Hollywood knew he was gay. Clark Gable was thought to be a very masculine ladies' man, although he tended to be attracted to bossy dominant women. Betty Davis was thought to be a trouble-maker. John Wayne was believed to be a war hero, but never served for one day in the military. Edward G. Robinson was thought to be a gangster even though in real life he loved fine art and high literature. In other words, the Hollywood studios were also presenting fabrications of sorts.These fantasies provide the set-up for "Sunset Boulevard" directed and co-written by Billy Wilder. Joe Gillis (William Holden) is a down-on-his-luck mediocre screenwriter. His main flaw is that he gets too caught up in what he thinks will sell, rather than writing an honest story. Through a couple of strange coincidences he ends up at the manor house of a forgotten movie actress from the silent era, Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) and her ever-loyal servant Max (Erich von Stroheim). She was one of the biggest stars of the silent era of the 1920's, playing in many epic films directed by Cecil B. Demille (who plays himself in the film). However, Hollywood has moved on and the demand for silent period pieces all but over, and she hasn't been cast in a feature film for 20 years.She's writing a bad screenplay based on Salome and she compels Gillis not to help her but reside in her manor. Norma's house appears like a movie set for a period picture taking place in the 19th century: velvet and satin upholstery on sofas, beds and drapery. She wears flowing garments and over-the-top makeup. She displayes dozens of photos of herself, as if her vanity is boundless. She is afterall a "movie star" in the old sense of the word, and she should be worshiped and adored. It seems more like a fantasy than a home which is I think the point the director and co-writer Billy Wilder wanted to convey.During the entire film, Norma Desmond seems to be engaged in over-the-top acting. Her interplay with Gillis is constantly melodramatic, as were many of the silent films prior to circa 1928. During the silent era, actors had to convey emotion through their expressions since there was no soundtrack. So by definition, their expressions had to be over-emphasized which seems highly melodramatic by the standards of today. So over and over again, Norma makes grand gestures and pierces Gillis with ever-growing bulging eyes.Her makeup is equally over-the-top, and she appears like a cross between the wicked queen of Snow White and the Seven Dwarves and the Wicked Witch of the West. In several scenes we see her face on top of the screen as if she is the ruler of this strange queendom. She is like the wicked queen who has captured a prince. She lavishes him with expensive gifts but Gillis longs to be free of this gilded cage. The price of Gillis imprisonment is his own career. He briefly interacts with a young budding screenwriter, Betty Schaefer (Nancy Olson) but he soon realizes he can't straddle both worlds forever. He has to make a choice between staying in the fantasy of Norma Desmond or returning to the real-world of film-making with Nancy.One of the noir masterpieces of the 20th century, and an indictment of Hollywood culture. Not necessarily for all tastes, the film is one of the first of its kind to openly critique Hollywood culture. Film actors, particularly actresses, were and still are in a way often treated like professional athletes. They are only as good as their last performances. After they've served their purpose and can no longer do so, they're discarded.

reviews.review_title: I AM big. It's the pictures that got small.
reviews.content: A dead man narrates Sunset Boulevard, eager to tell us his version of the events, the cold, hard facts, before they are distorted and blown out of proportion by the radio and television screen. Joe Gillis is a writer, and naturally wants his story to retain its integrity. Wilder gives us a witty snapshot of that idea disappearing in a puff of smoke early in the film, where Joe pitches his baseball script to an producer in a dinghy little office. Firstly it's openly mocked by a script reader (the demure yet snappy Nancy Olson) who wants something grandiose and with a message. "You'd have turned down Gone with the Wind!" splutters Joe in exasperation. "No, that was me," remarks the producer with resignation. Almost absent-mindedly whilst lounging on the couch, he twists Joe's story into an all-female spectacle with musical interludes, with the screen credit the only remaining vestige of the initial premise. And when Joe pleas for a personal loan, he launches into a spiel about his own spiralling debts that Wilder quickly cuts away from. There's no need for semantics; he's hemorrhaging money, like most of Hollywood, where original ideas are sparse and basic plots are organised by numbers and letters. Joe is played by William Holden, the strapping lead who would go on to star in other blockbusters like The Bridge on the River Kwai and Stalag 17, and who almost allows the audience to forget he is playing the everyman figure in this film, a struggling writer who has exchanged talent for a living. Wilder's dialogue is as biting and cynical as it ever is, delivered from the mouthpieces of two who have been spun around by Hollywood's washing cycle and spit out as nobodies. Joe holds himself up high, whether it is in a shabby blazer or a dinner suit and bow tie, but he has already traded away his artistic integrity. What more is a little self-respect? While he turns his nose at the array of baubles and trinkets that Norma showers him with, it's also a little flattering. His steely gaze hides a begrudging reliance, as does Norma's histrionics, betraying a twisted partnership; they need each other. Both Boulevard and Double Indemnity were photographed by John F. Seitz, who Wilder had entrusted with the latter's moody, noir lighting, and recruited to recapture. The term is French for black, and in a sense they were black both morally and physically. Seitz uses the same technique he did in Indemnity by sprinkling aluminium dust in front of the lens to render the sprawling, gothic mansion of Norma's into a dusty ruin, of luxury in decay. As Joe and Betty collaborate on their script late at night in a discreet motel (practically a synonym for seediness), he keeps the latter in the catch light, an angelic casualty of the wicked world of showbiz, but submerges Holden's face in shadow, like the very nature of his thoughts were being divulged. The guilt of their covert affair consumes him, as if he was in sole ownership of Norma Desmond. Who else but Gloria Swanson could have captured this performance? Norma's demise mirrors Swanson's, once a glittering silent icon, for 6 years the top star of Paramount, and then scuttled by the arrival of sound. The role asks for quiet desperation to be masked by flamboyance, and Norma replies in kind. She is a relic of the past, her costumes elaborate but dated, her poise a touch theatrical, but if she doesn't believe it, it might as well not be true. "I can say anything I want with my eyes," she declares, and sure enough, her pupils bore holes in any eyes who dare meet them, and makes demands, not queries. Cut away from her? Not likely. Norma still believes she commands the screen, and in some respects she does, most evidently in that final trance, where she fully commits to the illusion that has been held up for the last twenty years. But for Joe's brief peek into the enigma that is Norma Desmond, she has been long swallowed by Sunset Boulevard.

reviews.review_title: Billy Wilder and Gloria Swanson Masterpiece
reviews.content: This movie is so great that every time one sees it we gain new insights re the movie and notice new little things...it is in my opinion the best directed movie I have ever seen and Billy Wilder was a true Master of the Cinema. This is one of the great dramas of the screen and to think he also made likely the greatest comedy of all time Some Like It Hot..Gloria Swanson's landmark performance is one of the greatest in cinema history and together the fade out as Directed by Wilder and acted by Swanson is one of the greatest scenes in movie history.William Holden is classic in this movie and is perfect casting. However it is Swanson for whom we must save our most respectful applause. There is no other female performance that comes to mind ever that can top Swanon's. And to think she did not get the Oscar!

reviews.review_title: The very definition of a classic.
reviews.content: In an age when cinema generally succumbed to the tropes and clichés to which audiences were mechanically accustomed as a means for quicker cash, what better way to set the precedent of new and original storytelling as an art form than Billy Wilder's introduction to the 1950s, Sunset Boulevard - a film that explores excitingly unfamiliar territory while simultaneously presenting itself as a meta commentary of such transformation in the motion picture industry. A master of genre versatility, Wilder makes significant alterations to film noir with the addition of a light comedic backdrop, still managing to close on a note of poignancy that lingers in the mind, cementing the film as a landmark in movie history.We know immediately that we are in for something unusual for the era as the protagonist, Joe Gillis (William Holden), appears to be narrating from beyond the grave, the accompanying image containing the silhouette of Joe's floating corpse in a swimming pool. As police arrive on the scene, the rest unfolds through flashback explaining the events that led to our hero's demise. Going back to the start, we learn that Joe is a Hollywood screenwriter struggling to succeed in the dying business. After establishing his desperation as he is unable to sell his most recent script or persuade his friends to loan him money, matters get worse as he is chased by repossession men. One of his tires blows out, and he makes the quickest turn into the garage of a deserted mansion on Sunset Blvd. There he meets Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), a long-forgotten silent film star who is determined to make a triumphant return to the screen with a project she has written herself. When made aware of his experience, she hires Joe as an editor. Her butler, Max (Erich von Stroheim), puts him up in the guest room for the duration of his stay, ultimately extending much longer than he had anticipated. Thus begins a gradual obsession that deteriorates Norma's sanity, and Joe may be in too deep to find a way out.Wilder, along with Charles Brackett and D.M. Marshman Jr., provides the film's most extraordinary facet in his ingeniously crafted screenplay, earning a well-deserved Academy Award. It achieves thorough effect in blending tones, revealing twists and building conflict of all sorts. Even more impressive is the sharp wit and humor of the dialogue, giving the material infinitely more enjoyment than generic Hollywood output lacking any personality. It also fascinatingly utilizes subtle hints of symbolism and movie references, further improving the experience for film buffs in more way than one. His direction is also expectedly very good, bringing the content to life with skillfully constructed imagery and smooth editing work that flows sufficiently. A detractor from the impact, however, is the conventional use of music that hits every note one would expect at every moment they'd expect it. This is a technical aspect that is vital in evoking the right viewer reaction and unfortunately it does not always do so, making it the main attribute in which Sunset Boulevard resembles the majority of other works of its time. Even still, the positive certainly outweighs the negative as the great ensemble helps to carry the film, and is one of the very few to garner Oscar nominations in each acting category. Holden is a slick and likable leading man as always, while making Joe a sympathetic man with an internal battle as he must decide between rational logic and his heart. The love interest whom Joe desires is played by Nancy Olson, who does an adequate job of creating natural chemistry with Holden, though it may be slightly rushed and lacking emotional investment. Also intriguing is von Stroheim as the mysterious butler whose past with Norma may consist of more than meets the eye. This leads us to the one creation that drove the film beyond mere acclaim and is primarily responsible for the reason Sunset Boulevard is regarded as an all-time classic.The characterization of the deliciously psychotic Norma Desmond is absolutely brilliant, as Swanson's Oscar-nominated portrayal seamlessly conveys a woman who believably achieved fame long ago and is now stuck in denial that it ever disappeared. Joe recalls that she "used to be big", to which she replies with a disdaining tone, "I am big. It's the pictures that got small." If ever there was a performance that should truly feel like a performance, it is this one. Norma is a forever doomed actress who cannot escape the theatrics of a lively, expression-based movie star, and therefore her delivery of each line and movement is pervaded by a larger-than-life air of grandiose. Not only does this make for a highly interesting character to observe, but also often infuses her presence with hilarity and delight as she permeates every situation with unnecessary dramatics that come to be rather predictable. That is, until her mental instability spirals into a maniacal state, leading to a drastic climax followed by the iconic ending scene in which she deliriously makes her way into the spotlight for the cameras one last time, telling the hallucinatory director: "All right, Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my close-up." The film is not quite the masterpiece it is hailed to be, but it deserves immense appreciation for its sheer braveness and creativity. It indeed holds all the essential ingredients of a classic, with memorable moments that now inarguably contribute to defining the medium as a whole. A sense of freshness also separates it from the pack, and it is both entertaining and thought-provoking enough to warrant multiple revisits. Most importantly, the character of Norma Desmond and the conclusion to which her story comes is unforgettable, the finale inducing a sensation that deceives the softness of the film's earlier atmosphere and instead leaves us on a note that is all at once tragic, disturbing and darkly funny. Overall, Sunset Boulevard is a crucial part of cinema that is essential viewing for any film-goer.

From the opening of the dead body in the swimming pool to the last shot of a fuzzy Gloria Swanson, it is mesmerizing. The casting is brilliant. First, Gloria Swanson, a famous silent movie actress, was picked to play the insane and creepy Norma. While Swason herself wasn't like the character herself, she understood her situation so completely that despite the character's hugeness. Even though everything is overexaturated, you see that it is done because of the character's background, a silent movie actor had to act larger than life so that there emotions were conveyed, Norma can't distinguish anything in her life anymore. Swason was able to make the character real. William Holden was having a slump at the time after Golden Boy. He mixed the right amount of sex appeal and cynicism in the role to make it perfect. Erik Von Stroheim, the failed director, was basically playing himself in many ways. His career went down the drain after a failed movie with Gloria Swanson called Queen Kelly. He was the perfect pick for the role and made the character. Nancy Olsen is exactly what she is supposed to be, a fresh face that brings the only heart to the movie. The basic story is a failed writer named Joe hides his car from the repo men in what he thinks is an abandoned house. Norma, a formerly famous actress from the twenties, brings him in because she thinks he is there is bring the coffin for her dead chimp. She keeps him there to rewrite her putrid script called Salome and gradually turns him into her new chimp all the time abetted by her exhusaband, discoverer, butler named max. He becomes a kept man a sexual plaything. He trys to leave, but she attempts suicide and he stays. As her starts to hate himself more, he starts to sneak away to write a screenplay with young Betty Schaefer and falls in love with her. Norma then finds the screenplay, Untitled Love Story and starts to call Betty. Joe overhears and tells Betty to come to the house, tells her what he is and then sends her away. Joe then tries to leave Norma, but she shoots him and he falls into the pool. At this point Norma has completely gone off the deep end and goes down the stairs when police are there thinking that the newsreel cameras are movie cameras filming Salome. As much as this film is about how Hollywood is an awful place, you can still see that there is a love for film in it. Betty and her work with Joe on the screenplay is all sweet, careful and done with love. Norma herself shows love for film, despite how demented she is the final monologue shows a genuine appreciation for film. It shows how the business destroys the film making, but still appreciates it as an art.

Man, sure seems like people love to write mini-books on this site about Sunset Blvd. I'll try to keep my opinion concise and to the point. First, don't shoot me, but I think this is a good movie, but not a great one. It could have been a great movie, and it's certainly a classic, but I think it falls short, and here is why. The forgotten movie star living in a dilapidated, spooky mansion off Sunset Blvd. is a terrific setting. Great casting abounds with Gloria Swanson and hottie William Holden, and the strange friends each of them have. But for me, this movie falls apart every time they pull away from Gloria to concentrate on Joe and Betty's budding romance. Why devote so much screen time to a bland character, Betty Schaefer, struggling to write a who cares script called "Dark Windows" or whatever it's called, when we could be spending more time with faded, kooky Norma Desmond in her scary house with Max? Face it, no body writes volumes about Nancy Olson's character do they? We all know who makes this movie great, and it ain't her. The only fun scene with Betty is when Norma (surprise!) is tracking her down on the phone. I know Betty must provide a jealous factor for Norma, but her character could have been so easily pushed into the background, way into the background, and still have a suspicious Norma think that Joe is cheating on her. Same results, same ending, but less Betty!

reviews.review_title: Like Norma Desmond this film has not aged well but still packs a wallop
reviews.content: Not quite the shocker it was in 1950, "Sunset Blvd." still packs a wallop. For most director/writers "Sunset Blvd." would have been the height of their careers, their masterpiece, but for multi-talented Billy Wilder there were better pictures. "Double indemnity," "The Apartment," "Some Like It Hot," and two highly underrated films "Ace in the Hole" and "One, Two, Three" are better written than "Sunset Blvd." Take off the tinsel and the viewer will find some cracks in "Sunset Blvd." One distraction is the narration by the body floating in the swimming pool. There's a cliché that dead men tell no tales. Well, a dead man tells one hell of a tale in this film. The movie takes forever to get to the essence of the story. It gets better and better as the movie progresses until it explodes at the end. The best scene in the whole film is the last scene when Norma Desmond gives what amounts to a soliloquy for the newsreel cameras. Some critics have labeled this a dark comedy. There is really not much that is funny in the film. Calling it a dark melodrama is more apropos. "Dr. Strangelove" is a dark comedy. Dark comedies make a person laugh at subject matter such as death and weapons of mass destruction that would ordinarily be taken very seriously. A good dark comedy also makes one think. "A Modest Proposal" by Jonathan Swift is an example of dark comedy at its highest level. Though "Sunset Blvd." certainly makes the viewer think, its punch comes from the drama of contradiction and social analysis, not in its humor.The film has a few other weaknesses but let's look at the tinsel. What tinsel! All the actors give magnificent performances. The best among the great is Erich von Stroheim. It's easy to forget what a wonderful actor von Stroheim was until one sees him in action. It is also rewarding to see Jack Webb in a non-tough cop or punk hood role. One forgets that he was a serious actor before "Dragnet" stereotyped him. William Holden gives one of his best screen performances. Gloria Swanson is just whom Wilder needed to pull off the extraordinary acting required for her role, plus she was the real McCoy so one of her silent films could actually be used to intensify the allegory. One of the best lines in the film is delivered by Cecil B. DeMille. He has pampered Norma, telling her what she wants to hear. But as she is leaving and out of earshot, he reverts to his true attitude toward the faded screen goddess. "Tell Gordon Cole to forget about the car. I'll buy him another, or even five if he likes." In the viewer's mind DeMille is talking about Norma, not cars. To my knowledge this is the first Hollywood film to deal seriously with the subject of Narcissism in the industry. Narcissism applies to Thespians but also to any person in a position of power. Narcissistic personalities simply cannot deal with life outside the limelight. They must have mass adoration at any price. If you haven't seen "Sunset Blvd." by all means watch it and form your own conclusion. It is certainly one of Wilder's best.

reviews.review_title: Scathing look at Hollywood hits the mark.
reviews.content: As we made our way down the IMDb's top 250, our group had no idea what to expect from this classic. What we got is a film so biting and so incisive it could still impart lessons in today's celebrity world.Gloria Swanson doesn't just steal the scene, she devours it whole as Lorna Desmond, former silent film star left in her rotting abode with her butler Max and a thousand photographs and souvenirs of a bygone era. She crosses paths with Joe Gillis (William Holden), who is escaping insurers in his broken down jalopy and happens to park at Ms. Desmond's place and a strange friendship ensues...Swanson is suitably regal as she delivers line after line to Gillis and the audience ("I'm still big, the pictures are small!" "We didn't NEED to talk, we had faces!") and sinks into melodrama while still keeping the stage presence of a true star. Cecil B. DeMille appears as the overburdened director of The Ten Commandments trying to fend off Desmond's advances and her script for Salomé. the purported capping stone of her career. Meanwhile, Joe is trying to blossom a script with Betty Schaefer whose husband is away filming...it all comes to a head when she meets Joe at Lorna's and Joe walks out on Lorna, sadly for the last time as she shoots him in the back and he falls dead in her pool."I'm ready for my close-up, Mr. DeMille!" are her last words as the mob of photographers and movie makers zoom on the radiant and crazed Lorna as she descends the stairs for one final post, screen queen to the end.A must for historical purposes or just for a look behind the scenes. Truly excellent.

reviews.review_title: A lasting classic, with beautiful children
reviews.content: Much has been made of Robert Altman's use of Billy Wilder's masterpiece Sunset Blvd. in his important film The Player. But the film's stylistic inheritors include a host of other pictures, least conspicuous of which is this year's underseen gem Gods and Monsters.  It borrows plenty of tricks and tropes from the 1950 film noir tale of obsession and deceit: a body floating in a pool at the end; a fussy and doting servant (with a European accent no less!); and, most importantly, an ageing, narcissistic movie personality, subtly contrasted to a younger, somewhat lost character in need of a change.That these techniques can retain their evocativeness and mystery fifty years after the fact says much not only about Wilder as a director (and of course the film's fabulous cast), but also about the power of films that question the magical but transitory feel of classic American cinema and its personalities.  As the Hollywood illusion factory leads its audience further into the nebulous unreal, the need for plays-within-plays, for self-reflective movies-about-movies, is sure to increase.

That's how I felt about the movie overall. Certain aspects of the film seemed dated. But there are many aspects that are quite relevant too.It has an interesting premise. A struggling screenwriter Joe Gillis(William Holden) starts living with an old star of the silent era Norma Desmond(Gloria Swanson) in order to write a screenplay for a movie she wants to act in(which is supposed to be her big comeback). Joe is amused by Norma's behaviour. She still lives in an illusory world in her mansion where she is still a big star. Her faithful servant Max Von Mayerling also feeds her ego and keeps telling her that she is a big star. Norma begins falling in love with Joe and gives him presents in order to keep him. The movie then follows Norma's degeneration and the final over the top conclusion. The situation of old actresses who were stars in the past is very well portrayed in this movie. The dry humour and sarcasm in this movie is also an aspect that raises it above the other classics of the Old Hollywood era. It can also be seen as a satire of the Hollywood system. The scene where the director tells his assistants not to call her again - the same director who had once promoted her heavily - is a sad scene which shows the fleeting nature of showbiz. The portrayal of Norma's obsession with Joe is also excellent. The way Joe gillis uses the opportunity to his own advantage is also quite funny in a sad depressing way.The attitudes of the people reveal a somewhat dated attitude that doesn't quite fit in today. The scene in the shop where the shopkeeper says "Well, as long as the lady's paying for it, why not take the vicuña?" shows a somewhat derisive attitude towards a woman having a "trophy man"(while the opposite has been accepted). The attitude of Joe Gillis also seems dated. He behaves as if he is embarrassed that an older woman is interested in him. The line "I had to be with people my own age." shows the derisive attitude he has towards Norma's love towards him. I felt that the movie was a bit behind the times in these aspects. The ending was also a bit too over the top for my liking.The performances are top notch. The laidback acting style of William Holden is complemented by the over the top performance of Gloria Swanson. The over the top performance was appropriate in this movie, I guess. In many scenes she even seemed cute when she proclaims that she is one of the biggest stars. There is a likability to her character even though she seems a bit unhinged throughout. Nancy Olson is gorgeous and she is adequate for the role. Erich Von stroheim is very good as the faithful servant Max and it is surprising to note that he wasn't a professional actor while doing this film. Cecil de mille's cameo is actually quite good.I liked the movie but felt that the movie seemed a bit too dated for my taste. It can be taken as a stinging critique of Hollywood that is relevant even now. The dated aspects prevent it from becoming a great movie though.7/10

SUNSET BOULEVARD is a bit outrageous and chaotic drama that can be called a masterpiece. Characterization is phenomenal. The former silent film star resists aging and draws youth from a young, unsuccessful and somewhat cynical young screenwriter. The story is full of ambition, frustration and lies, which is fascinating. The main theme is the transience of life under the lights of Hollywood cameras. The film is full of satire and a kind of sarcasm.The story can not encircle the specified time period. This is a strange blend of true past and present false. The future in this story is practically nonexistent . The script is good, but the photo is simply mesmerizing. The false glamour and glamour without life is ideal for this story. Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond It is simply amazing, for me it is inconceivable to see any other actress in this role. William Holden as Joseph C. "Joe" Gillis He is doing quite well in addition to the dominant female roles. His emotional control is almost perfect. Character for whom I feel a certain empathy, but I can not admire him.Frustrated writer used the opportunity to earn some money, but at the same time meet the needs of older actress. Fortunately, it's not so simple. The story can be viewed through lack of self-esteem, contrived romance, external pressure, psychopathic nature and defeat at the end. Romance is very interesting. However, at times it is uncomfortable. Excellent dialogues are transferred in real relationships. Therefore act unnaturally. The atmosphere is reflected in the amazing and elegant past that is falling apart at present.Sunset Boulevard is a very intelligent movie. How to create intimacy of an actor or actress loses from commercial success. This world glamour remains in the film. Everything else is a lie. The truth is so painful that endangers lives. The film is a fresh, fun and sarcastic.

reviews.review_title: On the boulevard of broken dreams
reviews.content: "Sunset Boulevard" is written and directed by the remarkable Billy Wilder and stars William Holden, Gloria Swanson and Erich von Stroheim. The story revolves around an aged and forgotten movie star and a young and down on his luck screenwriter who happen to cross their paths and gain something out of their relationship: a young man seeks for money and fame and the old lady is simply looking for company and someone to care for.The movie's plot reflected on so many different silent era actors who just couldn't transit to the talkies and had to leave the limelight they deserved. Most of them turned out to be abandoned and died nobodies, legends once great and shining brighter than sun but now nothing more than a mention in the history books. This picture is about a person so devoted to her own self she didn't see the years go by, she didn't want to; she lived in the past absorbed by her days of glory and the only thing she needed was adoration. That's what she found in a young man's soul who came to her house by mistake: fate brought them together but instead of giving her what she longs for he uses her wealth to gain his own profit out of the poor woman's heart and her troubled mind. "Sunset blvd" is not only a street, it's also a place where dreams crash, where hearts break, people suffer and literally anything can happen.Mr Wilder's masterful script and directing, covered in the most beautiful score by Franz Waxman (undoubtedly his best work for which he received an Academy Award) and peppered by the most outstanding performances by the silent movie star Gloria Swanson who got to shine brightest again as well as the silent movie director/actor Erich von Stroheim and splendid work of the talented William Holden that altogether made this motion picture one of the most brilliant movies ever.

reviews.review_title: a movie that was ahead of its time
reviews.content: I must say that I have always thought that most older movies simply couldn't portray the same level of depth as the best movies of today. Hollywood was younger, acting was less "developed", and there were not nearly as many movies back then as there were now.But, this movie...wow. It was so bizarre, so unpredictable, so full of emotion and tension, so well acted.....so enjoyable. It's hard to believe that it was made 60 years ago.The movie kept my attention the whole time...I felt that the twists in the plot (even though you know the end game from the start) and the dialogue were superb.

A faded movie queen living in the past meets a handsome young failure and falls in love with him, trying to buy her way into his heart. Morbid, but satisfying.  It could have been a great one, had there been more dialogue. The scant dialogue and the abundant narration are major flaws. There should never be narration in a movie. Things should explain themselves. The plot is too schematic, too thin to really involve one's emotions. Movies in general contain too much action and too few words. They shun anything that a might be difficult for a 12-year-old.
Film noir, horror-spoof or intelligent analysis of narcissism and mental disorder. A gloriously fun movie. Wilder cannot go wrong: Double Indemnity and Some Like it Hot - what an enterprise!!!

Billy Wilder's Sunset Boulevard is the very suspenseful look at a screenwriter who doesn't have enough money (played by William Holden)and a silent star named Norma Desmond (played by Gloria Swanson) who has been waiting to get into the motion picture business for a long time wanting to make a film that she wanted Cecil B. DeMille to direct but had a terrible script. The film was suspenseful because we want to know why she was really that crazy, but her performance was still well done thanks to memorable lines, for example the most selfish line in the movie in the beginning where she says to Joe Gillis in her bedroom "I am big, it's the pictures that got small, and the last line in the movie which is the most memorable line in the movie when she was filming in her house and the last line "All right Mr. DeMille I'm ready for my closeup.". When Billy Wilder and Charles Brackett wrote the screenplay they wanted a frightening look at Hollywood like no other film director has done before. Not only do William Holden and Gloria Swanson have good performances but so does Eric Von Stroheim as her first husband and Desmond's butler. This is one o those movies that really deserved best picture but didn't win. I had no problems at all with this film, but I personally don't get why Alfred Hitchcock didn't direct this movie in the first place?

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest movies ever made
reviews.content: As someone who works in this industry, I know what it does to a person, and also what people will do to make it.  That is the story of Norma Desmond and Joe Gillis, one who has reached the pinnacle of success in Hollywood, only to have to have lost her youth and beauty and forgotten; and another who is struggling at the bottom to make it and will do just about anything to achieve that.That parallel is what makes this movie so genius.  Norma Desmond is one of the great characters in cinematic history, and Gloria Swanson does a phenomenal job portraying her.  I had only seen Gloria in silent films previous to this, and was doubtful of her "speaking" abilities, but she just absolutely nails this role.  I cannot imagine anyone who could have done this better than her.  Especially that end scene, where she does that eerie dance down the stairs and raises her eyebrows and walks into the camera. Absolutely Fantastic!Although William Holden was amazing, I kinda would have liked to have seen how Montgomery Clift would have pulled it off.  I think what was appealing about Monty was that sensitivity and vulnerability he portrayed, and I think that would have worked very well in this role.Other than that, the casting was perfect.  Erich von Stronheim was excellent, and what is scary is that he used to be a up and coming director in the 20s.  Nancy Olson had that innocent, wholesome look that was perfect for Betty, the only character in this movie that gives this industry any redemption.  For that reason alone, I would have given her the oscar over Josephine Hull.I know that Billy Wilder was one of the people who wrote this script, and if he came up with that line, "I'm still big, it's the pictures that got small," on top of his direction of this movie, he is absolute genius.One of the ten greatest movies ever made.

reviews.review_title: Very good but a bit on the obvious side
reviews.content: I would like to preface this review by stating I fully realize that as a person of the contemporary times my conception of pace and story development certainly conditions me to favoring a swifter more fluid progression in a film's plot. So older films will often tend to feel a bit slow. But then again "It's a Wonderful Life" is one of the top films I've ever seen despite being 5 years younger than this and about 20 minutes longer, so the point here is there's no excuse for something perceived as a flaw, not its time not anything.During some stretches the film will lack a bit of content and could've been filled with more intricacy when the narrative is clear enough to the viewer. All in all, it's obvious what the director is conveying during each section from the very start of the scene, it appears the film could've benefited from perhaps 15min less with more effective playtime. The conclusion also leaves something to be desired and contributes largely to that notion of being too self-explanatory and a scene which point is too obvious from the start. The Norma Desmond character is probably overplayed a tad (especially towards the end), which further contributes to that obviousness factor and pushes the movie towards looking like a movie rather than genuine and subtle.Of course it's still a very good film - especially if compared with the films of today it feels like a masterpiece of rare occurrence. It's strong in plot, psychologically intriguing and well crafted with several interesting developments (rather than feeding off one single idea) and the narration is just superb for about the two thirds of it before dropping to a more normal level in the last part.7.5/10.

The most admirable thing about this Billy Wilder masterpiece is the courage it took to make this film. 1950 is exactly in the middle between the self-imposed production code and the anti-American pogroms. In that narrow window comes this scathing satire of Hollywood glam in the same year as All About Eve. Both 1950s are an indictment of the soulless packaging of the movie business. Both take the point of view of the ambitions and the frustrations of leading ladies that lived long enough to witness their fading. Both were nominated for best film. All About Eve, perhaps because it was more direct and less metaphorical about its subject manner, won the day. It is no doubt a good film but today we recognise Sunset as the superior work.Many people play themselves in this film. Buster Keaton leads a team of vaguely recognisable 'wax works' whose wrinkling bodies are dying monuments to their glamorous silent movie pasts. C.B. de Mille plays himself as a survivor that transcended the transformation of the movie business.But Gloria Swanson and Erich von Stroheim are also playing themselves in this roman-a-clef where all their change about this autobiographical performance is their names.Gloria Swanson was Norma Desmond: in shared historical experience if not in personality traits. She had been a great star of the silent movies, her face known and admired world-wide. A 17 year old girl 'discovered' by Hollywood, placed on the front row of a joy ride into fame and fortune, only to be discarded when the pictures 'became too small' for her to fit in. That phrase is how she is introduced to us. William Holden's Joe Gillis vaguely recognises the dark dame in her desolate temple. 'You're Norma Desmond. You used to be big.' 'I'm still big,' comes to retort, 'it's the pictures that become small.' The butler in this palace of regret and memory is Max played by von Stroheim. Half way through the film, when in an exposition scene the history of the relationship between butler and dame becomes clearer to us, Max tells us there were three young directors in the early days of Hollywood that showed much promise: D.W. Griffith, C.B. de Mille and himself, the butler. If he said the third man was the actor who played the butler he'd have been perfectly accurate.Have-beens are a fact of life in every industry but there is, or at least should be an inherent sadness, in the cynicms of an E! special about one-hit-wonders or what ever happened to that forgotten child-star. Gloria Swanson and Better Davies (in the other 1950 Hollywood-themed movie) are representative of what must happen all the time. That in itself is no bad news. I suppose cabin crew, athletes or whoever else relies on their appearance for their living all have the inevitably early sunset ahead of them in their minds.What is particular about the movies is that persons - their appearance and more importantly their capacity to incarnate in their acting the emotions and ambitions of those who watch them - are packaged as a product that is valuable only while it waits for the next best thing.That's the theme of the film. Consider now its quality. The movie uses the device of a narrator but with the knowledge, revealed very early in the film, that our narrator has died a few hours ago and he only exists because we need to be put in the picture of understanding why he is dead.We also need to understand how he came about to meet this one particular end. He's floating, face down, in the swimming pool of a huge mansion on Sunset Boulevard. And the curiosity is awakened by the odd perspective with which we see the corpse, looking up at its face from the bottom of the pool.This is the particularity of the cinema, which allow us to look and see from corners and angles impossible in the physical world. But cinema is the subject of this film.
