What I found most interesting were the contrasts shown between the practical, "modern" film community of 1950 and the old silent film celebrities and their more outrageous tendencies.Gloria Swanson gets right into the role of the delusional star from another era, going slowly mad in her oversize mansion surrounded by souvenirs of her past.

Classic Hollywood Tale of Insanity: A struggling writer is hiding out from insurance collectors when he stumbles upon an abandoned mansion. The mansion belongs to Norma Desmond , an aged Hollywood starlet 0 years out of her prime. She's hold up in the mansion with her housekeeper, who keeps her in a delusional world of fake fan letters and false praise. She sits around and watches movies or herself and host card games with other retired actors.They hold Joe hostage to complete Norma's script she wants sent to Paramount Studios. Paramount, who's been moved on, bans Norma from the property but her housekeeper (secretly her first husband and director), keeps her in la la land.Joe falls in love with a young aspiring writer, which drives Norma more insane Joe is out creeping on her. She puts some bullets in his back and gets ready for her close-upOnce again excellent storywriting from Billy Wilder, and excellent use of lighting and cinematography
This film has robust, story-telling dialogue but leaves something to be desired at the end. The acting was commendable, but I left confused at the motives of each of the characters.

reviews.review_title: Billy Wilder's Best and a total Classic
reviews.content: It's uncanny how modern so many of Billy Wilder's movies are. That's one of the things that makes him one of the greatest directors in history. His films almost never seem dated. And this masterpiece is still a wonderful example, about a struggling, broke Hollywood screen writing wannabe who jumps at the chance of making money shacking up with a washed-up and aging silent-movie actress and writing her terrible comeback script. The story goes into bizarre and sexually-uncomfortable territory when he realizes that he has become her kept sugar baby and boy-toy.There is one element that feels VERY dated, and that is the spectacular performance by Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond, but it's supposed to feel dated! In one of the greatest performances of all time, here's a woman completely stuck in the past and in her now fading stardom, struggling to reclaim her past glory. It's fascinating the similarities between Norma and the Gloria, who at the time was also a silent movie actress who lost popularity. Even the silent movie Norma watches near the beginning is a real one starring Gloria Swanson!This movie works in every way and is a timeless classic.

Insufferable in some respects, although perhaps purposefully so. The story dragged on and on though the ego-trip of a silent actress who is struggling to be revived in the industry. Norma Desmond's infatuation with herself and total reliance on being 'known' is part of why I struggled so much through the film. If anything, I sympathized for Joe, forced to live with this person who expected everything to be as she imagined. What makes this film interesting is the story-within-story of the decline of the silent movie actor juxtaposed against a silent era actress acting as the silent actress in decline. The cast is full of silent actors, including Norma, and directors. Even the gossip at the end of the movie was a actor-turned-gossip in truth. Perhaps it had been a stretch for Mrs. Swanson to accept this role. I can't imagine that very many silent-era actors enjoyed the advent of 'talkies'. (possible spoiler:) Also, having the whole story told by a dead man is an interesting take on things. For all that he was murdered, he gave a rather kind story to the one who killed him.

reviews.review_title: A Heart Breaking story About a star
reviews.content: "No one ever leaves a star. That's what makes one a star." those lines were the dialogs Norma said to herself. I believe being famous sometimes could be very dangerous thing and destroy someone's life. as we saw in the movie Norma just lose it. and couldn't bare of being forgotten. she got paranoia. she though that she is still the best actress ever. if she could ever face with this reality that she's not that cute and young 17 years old girl that once came to hollywood for the first time, maybe the poor Joe Could be still alive. and like Joe Said "There's nothing tragic about being 50, not unless you try to be 25."

I absolutely loved how the movie was scripted. I loved how the story was told. It's a struggle with Joe's life, and what he really wants from it, and I love how it was described. It seemed to me as a great mystery movie. But not your standard mystery. It more so explains why it's a mystery and that is why I enjoyed it. Full of mystery and some would say a love triangle. It's so devious as well. I could see why this movie was so well enjoyed when it was released. There are so many surprises and quirks in this movie that make it wonderful. I personally fell in love with just about every main character in this film. They are all very well distinguished. I recommend this movie to any age group, and this is a movie would see again!

Sunset Boulevard is a really good film given the fact that it was made almost 70 years ago. And the commentary on Hollywood is still right on. Sunset Boulevard is a timeless classic and a prime example of Noir films. It's well written and on par with any other film that's made now. The only thing wrong with this film is that at some points due to the amazing writing it seems scripted. At some points the things that the characters are saying just seem so impossible to make on the spot. Gloria Swansons acting in the film was really the heart of it and was outstanding. One of the reasons possibly her portrayal of the character Norma Desmond was so good was because the fictional character and her own life were in fact very similar.

reviews.review_title: The Sunset Blvd/Scared To Death connection!
reviews.content: Although I would certainly agree that this is one of "Hollywood's finest", a true classic, etc., I have to take issue with people who comment on the uniqueness of the script, particularly in having the film being narrated by a corpse. One comment on this site even claims that this may be the first time such a device was used in films.NOT SO! In 1947, three years before this film's release, a low-budget independent film called "Scared To Death" beat Wilder to it. The film is narrated by the corpse of a young woman lying in a morgue who has been literally "Scared to Death" (hence the title). The picture stars Bela Lugosi & George Zucco (not to mention Nat Pendleton!) This is even more interesting when one considers that Wilder originally wanted SB to open with a scene of recently deceased corpses gathered in a morgue discussing their deaths! I must confess that I have a little suspicion, or fantasy if you will, as to how Wilder arrived at his vision for the opening sequence. After indulging in his little known (until now!) fetish for low-budget horror films (possibly the result of associating with his brother, W. Lee), I believe Wilder was on his way home from the theater musing on what he had just seen when the thought came to him: "Nobody who sees my movies is likely to see THIS! If these guys think opening the movie with narration by one corpse is something, I'll open one with a whole roomful!" Only the killjoys at Paramount Studios prevented Wilder's vision from reaching the screen as he originally intended. Admittedly the scene which ultimately did open the movie is at least equally bizarre and imaginative, as well as being breathtakingly shot.Is there something to the Scared To Death/Sunset Blvd connection? The world may never know! But I have my suspicions...

reviews.review_title: Do n't you hate yourself sometimes?' I often hate myself
reviews.content: Watching movies from the Golden Age, and I always inadvertently have such an experience, which is what the most cinematic movie should be. And if a person in the aura can only see the aura, then when the years pass by, it will be replaced by the same emptiness and darkness.

reviews.review_title: dark, oh so dark indeed. caustic high drama it its best
reviews.content: Classic tale of attrition, the collapse of greatness, the slime and sickness which infects the minds of those who love themselves too much. A man on his last leg, a film writer joins himself by faustian pact with the macabre shadow of a once great actress. Her lack of control as regards reality is compensated by the ever tightening grip she has on the impoverished writer who meets her. After meeting, the woman's charity ensnares the young writer, who is charged with raising this poor smoking corpse from the dustbin of history to the glare and flourish of success. The comeback will ride on the young writers script, until the end when the failed actress descends into delusion, and makes her own stage to act upon. Sunset Boulevard is a strange and destructive film certainly, it also has the rare distinction of being brilliant.

reviews.review_title: About as Good As it Gets
reviews.content: In browsing the comments for "Sunset Blvd.," I see that virtually all of them tend to understand that this happens to be one of the best pictures ever made. Don't just ask me, ... or the majority of the other posters here..., consult with The National Film Registry and the American Film Institute.Atmospheric, well acted and shot, an intelligent and slightly offbeat script, and a host of themes explored. What more could you want from a film? For those of you who cavil about this one, I find myself remembering how in the early 90's I would have sworn that "Old Style," or "Michelob" were the epitome of beers. It is only after I'd experienced a host of better potables that I become an adequate judge of real quality. For those of you who dismiss "Sunset Blvd.," I have to wonder just what IS a quality film in your estimation? While I don't particularly care for Led Zeppelin or Jimi Hendrix, I can appreciate that they are above average talents, just not my cup of tea. So, maybe it's NOT the movie, perhaps it's you.

Not a horrible movie. This movie is supposed to be a behind-the-tabloids kind of movie (think liza minelli reality show). It is so stereotypical of how the media views washed up celebrities. I do not understand how this film is rated so high. It is a decent movie (a borderline good movie) I should say but the story, plot, and directing is uninspired and unimaginative compared to the other films rated high on the lists of film critics. My review of this movie may be a little off though as a mere 24 hours earlier I had watched zoolander for the 3rd time. Which by the way brings me to another point. This movie takes itself way too seriously. Its hard to take someone seriously if that person is too serious himself.

Wealthy, silent film superstar "Norma Desmond"(Swanson), 50, was cast aside by Hollywood when she neared 30. She revels in her superstar status, delusional that it still exists; she's maintained in her mansion and these delusions of returning to public adulation and screen glory by her former film director (& former husband), now her butler-chauffeur (von Stroheim). The path of a broke, struggling B-film screenwriter "Joe Gillis" (Holden) enters Norma's territory and he becomes, for a time, her kept man, helping maintain her obsession of recapturing her superstardom. When he attempts to leave, this unhinges Norma more and she kills him. (NOTE: this is NOT a "spoiler" since the movie opens with Joe's dead body and his narrative voice-over.)This, one of the greatest of all Billy Wilder great films, was made only 22 years after the advent of "talkies" replacing silent films. It was THE first film to take a critical look at how Hollywood operated, especially in treating its former stars--& most especially young women--who were typically cast aside when they they lost their late teens/early twenties aura and glow. Film buffs will love the many inner details of this film: e.g., von Stroheim was actually Swanson's director in making the film which he (as butler) runs for the 2 leads to see. Swanson's imitation of Chaplin's Tramp is precious. With the later "Singing in the Rain" and now with "The Artist," this was the first of (IMO) the 3 most significant films dealing with the drastic effects on so many people of the transition from silents to talkies. (Wilder's less than glowing look at then traditional Hollywood has been hailed as a breakthrough and a first, because--before that--Hollywood had to be glorified in films.)My rating: is 10 of 10 bearing in mind film history and 8.5/10 without that mindset; compromised at 9.

***Jonny_Numb ("A somewhat savage, somewhat sick peek behind the Hollywood curtain", Jonny_Numb from Hellfudge, Pennsylvania, 21 August 2006) has a well-written, witty summary. Also, SpaceComics ("Classic character drama", SpaceComics from Colorado, 24 September 2005) also has interesting points to make, mentioning the parodies put on by Carol Burnett.***"Sunset Boulevard," (1950, Billy Wilder﻿), a tale of falling stardom narrated by a dead guy﻿, is poignant. To understand it today we have to recall that silent movie actors in the 1920s were living legends in the eyes of adoring film fans around the world. Also, at the half-way mark of the twentieth century there were still film studios that employed full-time labor (paying living wages) in a variety of supporting positions, allowing undiscovered talent the opportunity to climb the ranks. There was so much general excitement about Hollywood's contribution to world culture in 1950 that Billy Wilder's depiction of a mentally disturbed, former movie star undoubtedly rankled some of his peers.When Joe Gillis (William Holden) meets Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), both aspire a higher station in Hollywood. Gillis, a hack screenwriter experiencing tough times, is being chased by repo men who want his car. Gillis arrives at Norma's decaying, seemingly unoccupied mansion out of sheer desperation. Gillis is fairly likable, but when given the opportunity he takes what he needs from others. Norma, who surrounds herself with photographs from her youth (i.e., early publicity pics of comely Gloria Swanson﻿), is not well. She spends her days obsessed with the adulation she used to receive and cannot accept the reality that her film career is kaput. (BTW, for six years Gloria Swanson was the leading attraction at Paramount Pictures﻿.) Gillis becomes a kept man, accepting Norma's gifts and eventually becoming her lover. As Gillis rises in stature, it is inevitable that he will want more than he has. Temptation arrives in the form of Betty Schaefer (Nancy Olson), the youthful script girl and fiancé of Joe's close friend Artie (Jack Webb). Betty aspires to be a screenwriter, wants to team up professionally with Joe, and her eyes light up like firecrackers when she states her intention to do the hard work needed to break through. It is very likely that (director and second-listed screenwriter) Billy Wilder created Betty to represent his dream love. She sure is mine.A very memorable character is Norma's butler, Max (Erich von Stroheim﻿). Max faithfully serves the decaying Norma, maintaining her illusion of aristocracy (that silent film stars knew for real). Max suffers almost unendurably, but never receives any attention for doing so. Regarding that Stroheim had some great success as an actor and a director, this role perfectly submerges him. This is also seen with the cameos by Buster Keaton﻿, Hedda Hopper, H. B. Warner and Anna Q. Nilsson. Considering Keaton's real-life stature as a silent-era superstar, watching the legendary comedian in advanced years quietly playing Bridge in that decrepit room reminds us that Time never plays favorites.This is arguably Billy Wilder's best effort as a director. He does a very good job with the mansion interiors, creating a mysterious and suspenseful feeling. (One quibble with the writing is the name-dropping, particularly early on.) Gloria Swanson should have won an Academy Award for her fearless, often-imitated performance of Norma. William Holden﻿ plays the opportunistic Joe Gillis with complexity. Nancy Olson as Betty is simply adorable. While the cast is very strong overall, I do have some disagreement with the multiple scenes with Cecil B. DeMille﻿ portraying himself which serve to make him appear thoughtful and sensitive to Norma's problems. (Was Billy Wilder trying to kiss DeMille's rear end?) Overall, "Sunset Boulevard" is a very rich experience for audience members who still daydream about working in peak Hollywood. Cinephiles should have their chauffeur steer their Isotta-Fraschini over to the next revival theater that shows it.

reviews.review_title: Totally boring, good for just last three minutes
reviews.content: A writer(cinema or any other subjects) who has to live with bad economical conditions is wanted to pay 300 $ that corresponds to last instalment of his car or to give back his car. He never finds the money that he needs and while one day driving in road he sees the men who ask for payment priorly. Running away from those men, tyre of Joe Gillis' tyre goes off and he has to drive in a old large estate where an old film star accommodate. This star is Norma Desmond and she shares the big house with his servant Max who is her first husband. Desmond wants to patronize Gillis and he is wanted to edit Desmond's story. Gillis is obliged to accept this proposal but by the time he follows other jobs and Desmont believes lots of people are still fan of her, but she doesn't know the reality that Max writes those letters to her.Anyway,Desmont goes to an old director for a new film but she doesn't know that she is called for her old car upon using in a film. Desmont also envies Gillis and she disturbs his partner for a project by calling her.Till this point, the film is very boring so that I can play Solitaire in a small window at the same time. But the last three minutes are very creative in which Joe invites her friend and partner Betty to face up with reality. He rejects Betty and after that also Norma. Norma shoots him while leaving the house and he falls down to the pool.Police, journalists and Paramount pictures immediately come to the event place and an artificial film is made in event place as she wanted. Of course all those occur when Norma is in shock.I apologize for the lots of spoilers that I wrote above but if one day I want to remember the film, it is really necessary because the rest of film is really very boring except for last three minutes.I don't comment for any technical details or performances of actors or directing. It's understood just watching it.

Put a great story, script and cast in the hands of one of cinema's greatest ever directors and it really can't fail.This is arguably the greatest ever movie about Hollywood, but it doesn't pull its punches and shows the unsavoury side of the movies business.Gloria Swanson is superb as the ageing, bitter and delusional actress who is waiting for that big "return" to stardom. The plot and script reflect her true life story and there are references to her career in the film bringing even more realism to this human drama.Swanson shines brightest but the performance of William Holden as the struggling desperate writer was Oscar worthy - even though he didn't win he was nominated. Holden's unusual narrative during the film adds a clever and beautiful touch of surrealness to the stark reality.Lookout for quite a few classic Hollywood cameos, references and lines that weaves more fun to this darkest of comedy/dramas which is shot in black and white in classic noir style.One of the most famous lines in the film belongs to Swanson as fading star Norma Desmond, who with ego-maniacal stare declares "I am big...it was the pictures that got small", a reference to movies going onto TV.With each viewing this picture seems to get bigger making all that's come after it, look small. It's a truly great Hollywood tale with memorable characters and with the bonus of some real life movie legends playing themselves in yet another Billy Wilder classic.

This move had gotten by me over the years, but I finally saw it and I was very impressed. The story of a former superstar trying to hang onto the glory years was fascinating. The young man's struggles were extremely interesting as he tried to find his own path in this crazy world we live in. It's most definitely worth a watch and the final scene is something I can definitely relate to more now that I see where the famous quote actually comes from. If you have the opportunity to give it a watch I most definitely recommend it. In some ways, it isn't for the faint of heart, but it's a very solid movie.

Clearly a 10 star movie when current, the film today is more a document of times gone past than a gripping drama. The reason is simple - our society today isn't anything at all like it was in 1950 or so. The tension created by the (then) inverted relationship shown between male and female lacks any traction today. So this movie is today enjoyable as a window of what society thought proper over 50 years go. Swanson gives a superb performance which many take as over the top chewing the scenery today. However, you need to keep in mind that the sort of excessive emoting she does in this movie is stylistically in tune with the way silent stars needed to act to get their message across. Yes, I agree with those who've said the plot is silly, outlandish and contrived. So what? The plot only exists as a vehicle so the movie about relationships can exist. I'd suppose the enjoyment of this movie would be proportional to your age. A 75 year old personally remembers those times and would find it personally interesting. A 50 year old would have heard of those times and find it interesting in what he missed. A 15 year old would view the movie as a bizarre bore unless he were a student of history or the movies. A good accompanying movie to this one would be 'Detective Story' with Kirk Douglas - again from the same time period. Like here, the tension generated by the central story is laughable by today's standards, but resonated with audiences way back then.

For a film released in 1950, it seemed to be very provocative in the way it displays the dark side of Hollywood. Of course, the writing and acting should also be noted as being exceptional. The plot is that of a classic film noir and I had no trouble following and I just wanted to know what happened next.
Wonderfully dramatic and surprisingly poignant. Quite anxiety-inducing somehow. Nice classic film noir stuff, and a really cool boat bed. Plus a Buster Keaton cameo.

Prior to this, swanson was a famous actor in the silent era of Hollywood, almost like Norma Desmond in the film, but with the arrival of sound films, their aura gradually faded and they were slowly forgotten by fans, who were only trapped in the luxurious old houses of Hollywood, showing the films they had been in over and over again. So the film 24 times per second lie (at that time should be 16 lattice) is no longer for the audience, for those who have been out of the studio, lose box office appeal (also means that the audience) yesterday as well as movie stars, they stubbornly immersed in their weaving a dream is not willing to wake up, is cruel, everyone else is awake.

reviews.review_title: An Aging Masterpiece Crawling On Its Last Legs
reviews.content: After watching sunset boulevard I've realized that some so called masterpieces don't stand the test of time. After everything I had heard from friends and film goers alike I expected something fantastic and lifelike. But overall, sunset boulevard was nothing more than a slow, boring mess that lead up to a somewhat climactic ending. Mediocre is the perfect word for this film, starting with the less then average start all the way to the positively sad, unrealistic murder of Joe Gillis near the end of the film. Although I will congratulate the film for the very end, In which a deranged femme fatale , Norma Desmond, Is directed by her butler to walk through her house to the police. The way in which that scene was presented was quite interesting and a good ending for the surviving characters present. But, even with a pleasant ending, It still wasn't enough to get this boring, tedious, blunder of a film to grab my attention for more than 5 minutes at a time. I may be wrong and this may be a classic masterpiece. But for the average viewer like myself, It seems like nothing more then an aging film struggling to relate to a younger audience more accustomed to better, fresher films. I give this train wreck a five out of ten.

Hollywood at it's best. A film that never ages with timeless performances by all. A writers dream script. What else could be said, except that we need more movies like this, even today. Mister Wilder's ability to draw in his audience, as he does with most of his films, is a feat many directors lack. The haunted story line with an underlying creepy nuance, makes you care for even the most despicable characters, and there are plenty here. Our one touchstone is the Nancy Olson character, but even she was willing to look the other way at one point as long as Joe (William Holden) would walk away. Simply a great film that has earned it's place among the best films ever made.

MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD !!!Brilliant film, it's true, the actors are amazing, but too many twists and flaws make the whole situation hardly credible in my opinion.So the servant turns out to be the husband who used to direct Norma in her films and he has now become her slob who perfectly accepts the presence of this other man (Joe Gillis) in her life just because he wants his wife to keep living out her fantasy... that's a bit hard to swallow.And why does Joe feel so trapped ? I never quite got that ! So he has people trying to repossess his car ? Big deal. He could hide in a million other places and still work on his script with Norma from there... he doesn't *have* to stay at her place if he feels uncomfortable there (that is before he starts finding advantages in her wealth) ... but somehow he feels he has no alternative... yet he does.Anyway, despite these two major flaws (and other minor flaws), the film remains extremely enjoyable 50 years after its release.After watching this movie, I find funny to notice the growing interest of people for psychiatric cases in movies ("Psycho", "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest", "Birdy", "Whatever Happened To Baby Jane ?", "Rain Man", ... ).

This film left me speechless but not in the way most would think. I found certain parts of this film to be dull. For all the hype about how much of a classic it is, I didn't really see it. This film is about a washed-up millionaire silent film actor, who seems off her rocker from the very beginning, and ropes in a broke writer to her crazy world. This is referencing actual events because a lot of the silent film actors weren't good in the talkie films. There have been other films about this including Singin' in the Rain (1952) directed by Donen and Kelly. This being the part of the plot doesn't seem like it would make it a classic. There were some really good scenes like the one with Betty Shaefer and Joe Gillis writing a script together and walking about at night. I loved the lighting, the fluidness between the two characters and the way they instantly clicked together. The camera angles perfectly captured their facial expressions especially when they were out for a walk. But the rest seemed too drawn out and not very suspenseful.Although I didn't appreciate the film as some may, I did think that Holden played the character of Gillis very well. He was able to portray the emotions of the character, loneliness, depression, and a few others, through no words at all. Just through his posture, facial expressions and his tone. Nancy Olson did a good job with her character as well, Betty Schaefer. You could see her confliction about Joe and Artie and then she realized she didn't want to marry Artie and you saw the despair and the want for Joe on her face and in her posture. I didn't think Gloria Swanson was the right character to play Norma Desmond. Her face, posture, and how she looked just didn't fit with how imagine the character to be. Wilder did do some good things with this film, but in the end it just seemed pretty flat to me.

reviews.review_title: Bland, slight and not very funny.
reviews.content: I was finally induced to watch this film after reading favourable remarks on it in one of Simon Callow's memoirs. I didn't have high hopes, so they weren't dashed when I watched.Like almost all Hollywood films, it was form without substance - slight, bland and superficial. I thought the acting atrociously over the top; in fact the only good acting came from Cecil B. DeMille, playing himself. There was the usual excess of alcohol laced with lame wise-cracks which pass for humour in American cinema. There was almost no plot, no depth of character, The unappealing William Holden was evidently taken off the shelf for his role, and Gloria Swanson was merely grotesque.

WAs not to familiar with Noir Genre but I definitely enjoyed this portrayal. Did not know "I'm ready for my close up" originated from this movie as its such an iconic quote.Nice use of low key lighting to illuminate typical of future noir films along with some light sexual innuendos that got around the code in ingenious ways by altering a few lines. Greatly enjoyed the film cant say id re watch it though.

Film Noirs come in all sorts of different portrayals. They range from familial conflicts such as Mildred Pierce, to watching another's internal struggle such as "Sunset Boulevard." It was a strange and beautiful movie, being extremely dramatic and dark, appearing to almost model Norma Desmond after her actress, Gloria Swanson in a strangely intimate way. So many characters of the movie were real people that I wondered if it were based off of a true story. To find out that it was not made for a more confusing and wondrous experience after watching. William Holden's narration was a comical and interesting addition to the story that fit nicely in place, and added a touch of omnipresence to his character, Joe Gillis after his death. "Sunset Boulevard" was a dark and wonderful movie, enjoyable and iconic down to the very last line.

The production design of this film helped convey the stories main theme: When a person refuses to detach from their former and forgotten identity, not only is their progression damned, but the potential to be manipulative, codependent, and obsessive reign supreme in order to keep the illusion alive.Struggling screen writer, Joe Gillis, meets by way of happenstance the former silent-screen goddess, Norma Desmond. Norma is an aged woman who has lived quietly and practically alone for many years in her spacious and what seems like deserted mansion; fooling herself into believing that the world is ready for her "return" (not "comeback") to the millions of fans who have never forgiven her for deserting the screen so many years ago. Norma's refusal to detach from her former and forgotten identity as a big Hollywood star is dramatically heightened through the use of production design.The predominant set used throughout this film is Norma's spacious mansionan environment that suggests luxury and comfort for a woman who is still living off of the money she waged through a former identity. The illusory and narcissistic life that Norma continues to live is heightened through the heavy use of mise-en-scene. Framed pictures and portraits of Norma's face are displayed all throughout her mansionmost of which capture moments of past films she's acted in. She even has her own movie theater where she shows Joe the old films that she starred in. As she romanticizes and woos over her past, Joe, as well as the viewer, becomes aware of her inability to divorce herself from her former identity.Her bedroom also expresses the illusion she is under through elegancy. From a throne-like bed with silk draped from corner to corner, to fluffy and intricate pillows, exotic plants and decorative mirrors, all of these props are used to help convey to the viewer Norma's obsession with her past. In short, she is living a lie. Her stylish material possessions are what keep her from progressing onward with her life. She seems content with living in the past and will object to anyone that tries to disturb her comfort zone (as seen when she kills Joe in the enda man she fell in love with and had difficulty detaching herself from after he walked out on her, thus disturbing her comfort zone).Along with the props, her striking wardrobe is also effectively contrasted with the rest of the characters in the film. While she is clothed in expensive and fancy attire, Joe is dressed in rugged slacks and tattered buttoned shirts. There is a scene where Norma merges her own identity crisis onto Joe when she takes him shopping for new clothes. This was her way of subconsciously manipulating her own ideologies of her forgotten identity onto someone elsethe intended purpose, of course, was for her to perpetuate her narcissistic influence into those that would succumb to her manipulation. The use of make-up is also exploited to dramatize the main theme. In order for Norma to retain her old self, she undergoes extensive beauty treatments in preparation for her "return". Extreme close-ups reveal an ageless and beautiful woman, yet ironically throughout the rest of the film she is exposed as she really isan old and wrinkled woman who is attempting to hold onto something that has past.

I watched this in my Film Study class, so I'm not exactly an esteemed critic who's known for being really smart when it comes to movies. But, as an audience member, I can easily say that this has aged horribly. At the time, I'm sure it was dark and very eye-opening. But, by modern-day standards, it is a comedy, to be sure. In the beginning of the film, we see the main character dead, and narrating it. Getting to know this character was torture. I had no care for him and wanted him to die. Then, when he finally did, it was the most comical send-off. The way he died was so unrealistic, I just bursted with laughter. Then, the part where the crazy actress says "I'm ready for my close-up, Mr. DeMille." was when I realized I had watched something desperately trying to convince me it was good. This got 4 stars because it's funny.

reviews.review_title: One Of The Greatest Films Of All Time. Perfect In Every Aspect.
reviews.content: Billy Wilder was truly a master of cinema, a man who could made some of the greatest movies of all time, with some of them being comedies and some of them being dramas. In 1950, he made a film that some have called a Hollywood horror story, particularly in regards to some of the darker aspects of the industry, a film that in many ways, has grown more relevant with the passage of time, and one that is earned a place in being one of the finest achievements in cinematic history.Sunset Boulevard is a film that I would definitely rank as one of the greatest movies that I have ever seen, it is perfect in every sense. It's a powerful and even emotional film that pulls no punches as it deconstructs the myth of Hollywood, by showing that said place isn't as glorious as it seems. And furthermore, it also features some of the best writing to be spoken on film, as well as some of the best acting to ever appear in front of a camera.The film begins with police discovering a dead body floating in a pool, while some narration describes what's happening, with the narration coming from the dead man himself. Told mostly in flashback, the film focuses on Joe Gillis, a screenwriter who stumbles upon a rather rundown mansion while he's running from some men who try to take his car. Turns out that the mansion belongs to a faded silent film star named Norma Desmond, whose only company is her manservant, Max. Desmond is determined to make a film that will represent her return to the limelight, and she manages to rope Joe into writing a film for her. Little does Joe realize however, that Norma has become so determined, that she has no idea how a relationship works, and she'll do whatever it takes to make a return, even if it involves resorting to measures that will prevent Joe from leaving.For 1950, this film was certainly bold, particularly with its subject matter, because it dared to show what Hollywood was (and in many ways, still is) like. To specify, Hollywood is a place where actors and actresses are primed and prepped to become luminaries, and rise to the top of fame and fortune, only to be shown the door whenever their services are no longer needed, and in the process, the film also takes a few less than subtle stabs at directors and producers. Such ideas and moods are buoyed by the stark black and white cinematography, which adds to the rather downbeat subject matter. Black and white can always add to the drama of a film, but such an element was especially strong here, because it added to the mood of the film, and it helped convey the message that Hollywood isn't as glamourous as one imagines. And furthermore, Billy Wilder's writing and directing are sublime, in which (with contributions from Charles Brackett) keeps everything in balance to perfect a masterpiece of cinema.In regards to the acting, I don't think you find better performances in a film than in this one. William Holden was astounding in his role, in which he tries to play Norma like a violin, but only ends up getting himself entangled further. Erich von Stroheim was also incredible as Max, who like Norma, was also in silent films. Stroheim was in ways playing himself, particularly near the end (and I won't say what it is exactly), when he gets the opportunity to "direct", which was what Stroheim had been decades prior. There have been some who have called Gloria Swanson's performance one of the greatest in cinema history, which is a sentiment that I can agree with. To say that she was sublime would be putting it lightly. Much like Stroheim, Swanson was in some ways, playing herself, as she was once a silent film star who had become irrelevant as time went on, which is what Norma Desmond essentially is. Is Desmond insane? In many ways, yes. However, what makes it effective is that she only shows signs of it at first, and in some intervals, it becomes rather intimidating the further she descends. One would be rather hard pressed to say that there's a better performance in any film than Gloria Swanson's effort in this film.While Billy Wilder directed many classic films, probably his best and most powerful is this one. Even though everything else about the film was perfect, it was primarily Wilder's directing that made everything work to perfection. Sunset Boulevard is a film that has only become more relevant with the passage of time, because though the film may seem to be an elegy to the silent era and the stars who performed during said era, the film is much more than that, it's an in depth look at the film industry, that shows some of the darker aspects of it, which is very much like Hollywood today. Ultimately, this is a film that anyone who appreciates cinema should so, as many films don't get much better than this timeless cinematic classic.

reviews.review_title: Fascinating what holds up and what doesn't
reviews.content: I can't say much that's bad about this film. The truth is films of this era had a specific approach to this type of story, the melodrama inherent in it, and a style. All of that, while it may not hold up the same way today, is beautifully executed here in a story that is as universal and heartbreaking today as it was then.There's a lot to be read into the text, context, and subtext of this film, which is interesting because elements of it are newly brought to it by current audiences because of our current understanding of Hollywood. Other elements are lost, no doubt, because we can't go back to the place and time, when THOSE audiences may have had a different set of assumptions and biases re: Hollywood. But it most definitely works either way, and that's saying something.I still recommend it, as an exercise in empathy exploration and building, if nothing else. But I do believe there is "something else" -- a lot of "else" -- to be found, but that it may be different for each audience.

Good film classic noir. We can tell Joe loves her, but with the condition of sympathy, guilt and shame, and it is all because of the 20-year-old age difference and the huge gap in their social status, the film is bold tirade aiming at the hypocritical showbiz of its ageism and male chauvinism. For Norma, Joe represents the last straw of her life, her mirage of being an eternal star which is timeless and beloved.Swanson gives a show-stopping tour-de-force as Norma, exaggerates her condescending mannerism with dramatic grandeur and empress mien, the trademark popped eyes and protruding jaw perfectly render a thrilling pathos as someone who is ridiculously ill-fitted in the present world thanks to her own background which is painfully similar to Norma. The film gifts Swanson the only opportunity to shine in the talkie era and she accomplishes it with impeccability, this is one of the most powerful performance ever (I give her an edge over the equally iconic performance from Betty Davis in ALL ABOUT EVE 1950, 9/10), and its indelible impact is caustically mind-blowing, not to mention her final descending from the stairs to the cameramen, and her iconic last line.Swanson is not the only one carry an autobiographic curve in the story, so is Erich von Stroheim, as Max, her dour but loyal butler-cum-chauffeur, the only one takes care of her in the decadent manor, more shockingly is later he reveals to be Norma's first husband and the director who has brought her to stardom and accompanies her into obsolescence. In real life Mr. Von Stroheim and Ms. Swanson both suffered a career debacle after their collaboration again.

reviews.review_title: An Interesting Portrayal of a Fading Star
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's Sunset Boulevard, largely focuses on Joe Gillis (William Holden), a screenwriter who is looking for work and how he came across Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), a forgotten movie star of the silent film era. It's with Norma Desmond that Joe Gillis finally finds an opportunity to work on her script which is intended to bring her back to the limelight at the age of 50.The movie tells us quite a bit about the zeitgeist of the time it was made in. Keeping Hollywood as the background the movie majorly occurs in the manor of Norma Desmond. The story itself tells quite a bit about the state of Hollywood in the 50's and the shift from the silent era to the talkie era. It also touches on the struggles in Hollywood and how aspects such as finding opportunities or having your scripts heard works.The film specifically gives you quite a bit of insight into the life of Norma Desmond as a faded movie star from another era and her desire to get back into limelight, it truly goes into how it feels to feel to be a movie star and past your prime. In fact one of Joe Gillis' lines saying "There's nothing tragic about being 50, not unless you try to be 25," truly sums up what the film was trying to say with her character. In fact, this set-up can be seen as symbolism about how women feel after a particular peak in life whether in terms of beauty or career and suffering a midlife crisis in that period, unable to accept aging and the lack of the admiration and respect received before.The plot line for Norma Desmond was quite intriguing in the sense that it was quite unexpected with the turns the writer took with the character and I was quite surprised with the direction taken in regards to Norma Desmond falling in "love" with Joe Gillis who was in love with Betty Schaefer (Nancy Olson). Betty Shaefer had an intriguing character as a script reader and the inputs she gave to Joe Gillis were intriguing to watch.Overall, this is an interesting film and truly holds up as a classic and I might even consider it as one of my favorite movies from the '50s. It's a great character study that truly looks at how it is to be fading star. And the ending was quite unexpected for me as I forgot the beginning by that point.

When you look at the modern world in an objectual manner, you cannot unsee the human obsessive strives for fame and success. It is in fact a curse cast upon society, and it has in fact no good ending for most of those who strive for it. Nowhere in the world does the strive for fame occur more often than in the world of glitz and glamour in Hollywood. Hollywood may seem perfect on the outside, but on the inside, there is a deep dark truth about fame. Fame fades fast.The Hollywood epic "Sunset Boulevard" captures the hunger for fame excellently in this dark humour comical drama film noir. We meet the famous Norma Desmond played beautifully by the great Gloria Swanson. Norma is a faded star wanting rejuvenation and a glamorous return to the big screen. She is in fact desperate, and she doesn't have a life and a personality behind what is projected on the big screen. She lives in a fantasy, and certainly has psychological struggles to come to terms with who she has become.Norma lures a young writer named Joe Gillis (William Holden) to her castle and uses him for her own desires. She tries to get a hold on him, almost like a succubus grabs a hold of its prey. The lengths she goes to stay relevant and feed her fantasy lifestyle is captured beautifully by director Billy Wilder. The director deploys dark comical moment expertly to show the audience that Norma Desmond's life is not what it seems on the outside, and he even has a funeral scene for a chimpanzee to show the nonsensical world she lives her life.Sunset Boulevard is a great metaphor for Hollywood in many ways, and it greatly reflects Hollywood even to present date. The way in which the movie uses metaphors and symbolism such as with Norma's car, and impractical gold-plated old heap of junk is a stunning nod to the excess for excess sake symbol that have come to plague Hollywood. Sunset boulevard oozes excess and extravagance which is all a facade, and you get to know content and context when you watch the scenes with joe in his office writing a screenplay.The cinematography in the movie is overall great, and it achieves all its goals of being an almost film noir. The movie has a linear structure, and follows that of a romantic film. The directorial choice of portraying the movie in black and white gives the editors a big chance to display shadows and light in a way that compliments the story, and they achieve this to great success.I especially enjoyed the brilliant acting and over the top moments of Gloria Swanson. She is one of Hollywood's all-time greats and this, In my opinion is her Magnum Opus. This film ages better and better over time like a fine wine, and is to be enjoyed for decades to come.My rating: 91/100.

reviews.review_title: Fascinating study of a descent into madness
reviews.content: A dead man narrates this film about the descent into madness of aging silent screen star Norma Desmond, played by aging silent screen star Gloria Swanson. Aging Silent Screen star/director Erich von Stroheim plays Norma Desmond's butler, and other ASS stars, directors, and studio heads appear in cameos. The film is dark and depressing and with all those famous old faces around, absolutely fascinating. "I'm ready for my close-up, Mr. DeMille."

I believe this was pretty good for an old film. Personally, I am not too enchanted by "classics", but this one was good.I think the theme of the past aging and not being relevant anymore was a strong one in this film. Times change and if you become hung up on the past, you cannot progress to the present and future. I liked this theme in the movie.I also enjoyed the twist in that the main character was the one who was killed at the end of the movie. This was something that I didn't think was coming, as he was narrating in the beginning of the movie. Having seen many movies from many eras, I haven't seen something like this, and thus was unable to accurately predict the ending like I usually do.

for the high quality and the success ,Billy Wilder is to me the greatest director ever.He was probably the first (and only) director to make "smash-hit masterpiece" among all the great directors ever no one as him found so much public glory.Look at his film:none of them is dated,(as capra one's for example).The role of miss swanson was first gave to mae west which refused but gloria accepted and she really made a herself wonderful biography,cause the relationship with von stroehim was(almost)really the one described in the movie.Can you believe the initial scene was actually filmed in the early 50?so innovative,if you think that there were the years of doris day movies too,well.... a scene is always in my hearth:when Holden and the girl are walking down the studios and she starts to tell him about her nose-job.I found it so modern,so true and so acid in a certain way,but everything is to mention in this movie cause every sequence is amazing(the visit at the studio,the card game with buster keaton,the first year eve party...)I don't have so much DVD cause I use to buy DVD of only movies I will love too see over and over again.That's one of it. claudia

reviews.review_title: One of Billy Wilder's directorial gems
reviews.content:
This film surely deserves the credit it gets. Billy Wilder effectively creates darkly comedic dialogue in its script. The dialogue is witty, and while dark, helps shed some humor in the midst of a dark situation--this adds to the brilliance of the dialogue.
The characters are brilliantly crafted and developed, as we understand our main characters and their motivations. We understand the perspective of our two major characters, played by William Holden and Gloria Swanson. We know more about their characteristics and their goals/motivations through their dialogue and actions.
Not only is the script great, the acting is very good. Gloria Swanson creepily plays her character with a dark but brilliant delivery of dialogue, adding to the dark atmosphere of the film. William Holden also delivers his lines just as well as Swanson does.
The production design is also very fitting for the dark and creepy atmosphere of the film--the design/decoration of sets such as the house of Norma Desmond--helps add to the frightening/dark mood of the film.
I could go on and on about what makes this movie so great--and what also makes it a must-see for movie lovers. I just hope that Hollywood doesn't make a remake out of this.

reviews.review_title: A fascinating, gripping movie. A loving tribute to things past and well deserving of its acclaim
reviews.content: The legendary Sunset Boulevard. Check the greatest lists. You probably seen this one in a good chunk of them.William Holden and silent film icon Gloria Swanson (in a role perfectly suited just for her) star in this brilliant movie about a struggling Hollywood screenwriter who down on his luck and on the run finds himself through sheer circumstance meeting up with Swanson's Norma Desmond character which changes his fortunes, or does it? Alot of connection to Hollywood's silent era are in the spotlight in this movie through its players and even includes a charming tribute to Charlie Chaplin. The acting is superb from both Swanson and Holden, top of their game. A beautiful scene with him consoling her is absolutely wonderful and touching yet the story is compelling and tragic at the same time. A film noir told in flashback which gives it a suspenseful tone. It will make you feel both happy and sad. Many memorable scenes, the end scene the most famous of all. HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! Yet another sparkler in Billy's Wilder's awesome library.

reviews.review_title: Wilder Plot Gets Wilder and Wilder
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's classic is one of my favorite excursions into film noir. Sensual, yet shocking imagery and a brilliant, but meandering plot runs the gamut and lead us to the tragic conclusion. My favorite scene is the bizarre and shocking segment featuring a dead chimp. Its quirkiness is right in line with the Wilder plot that grows ever wilder with each moment.Bill Holden is exceptional as the frustrated screenwriter Joe Gillis, who latches onto washed-up silent movie star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) in hope of resurrecting both their careers. Along the way, he draws co-writer Betty into his doom. Despite herself, Betty ditches a good, decent lover for the mysterious, secretive Holden.How can this mess get any messier? Such is the talent of Billy Wilder. Check out the special DVD version, which will blow you away again and again.
This was a bit slow for me at times but I see why it's a classic. Gloria Swanson played this role with perfection! It's worth watching just for her if nothing else.

As a rule, I'm against gratuitous remakes of film classics, but the cynical yet poignant story told in Sunset Blvd. is so timeless that it could easily be redone every ten years or so, like A Christmas Carol, with each version chronicling the slow decent into madness of a different fading movie star and his show business contemporaries due to their abandonment by Hollywood. For example, Sunset Blvd. 2002 could star Jack Nicholson as Norman Desmond and Roman Polanski as Max. They spend their evenings screening Chinatown again and again while complaining bitterly about the "weasles at Paramount" who won't return their calls. Jack sits stooped over his typewriter for days on end, adding yet another scene to his mammoth comeback screenplay, 'Five More Easy Pieces', while Roman pens phony fan letters for his deluded boss, scented with Chanel #5. Jack works tirelessly each day except Wednesday, when Warren Beatty, Peter Fonda and Karen Black come over and, between bong hits and hands of canasta, swap bittersweet stories of the good old days of Hollywood, before "the suits" took over. Jack's downfall is completed when naive young screenwriter Heather Graham rejects his leering attempts at seduction and is found face down in Jack's swimming pool, bludgeoned to death with his best putter.Next week: Nick Nolte and Walter Hill guzzle lukewarm Old Milwaukee and throw darts at a poster of Eddie Murphy.

reviews.review_title: A Classic Hollywood Tale From A Classic Time
reviews.content: "Stars are ageless, aren't they?" The glitz and glamor of old Hollywood. The Lights, the Sounds, the Cameras- what happens when they've dissipated as the Stars of yesteryear before them? Sunset Boulevard tells a darkly satirical, yet poignant story of the once-great Norma Desmond- a washed up actress of the silent film era. A woman so consumed with delusion and narcissism that nothing in this world, nor any other could convince her of anything but her own self importance. She's a star, after all. Ironic as it may seem, Norma herself is not the fulcrum of the film, but rather one side of a dichotomy- the conflict between a bygone age, and the modern. In this place of the middle, torn between the two is our protagonist Joe Gillis- a struggling screenwriter trying to strike it big, who happens upon our old Hollywood queen. What comes next is a story that may ring true of many stars who have faded into obscurity- the paralyzing stigma of being a has been, the endless planning of an ever-just-out-of-reach comeback, and the whispers and rumors of days gone by- that yearning for the spotlight, the power, and the attention they once commanded. With a fantastic twist and slick direction, Billy Wilder delivers a hit in this timeless classic. It remains relevant and applicable still, even in today's world, sixty years removed from the original premiere. Sunset Boulevard is a narrative in how fleeting fame can be, but how the effects of it may be everlasting- in both the public eye, and in private. After all, the stars are ageless.

I love the way the story is told in the piece, the mix of internal and external dialogue from the main character. The "isolated" male narrating his own story, starting the story with a mysterious murder. Man, this is just a classic. The first time I watched this film, I could immediately see the lasting influence this film has had, even into contemporary filmmaking.

reviews.review_title: An absolute classic from start to finish.
reviews.content: I cannot believe I had never watched this film before. This instantly jumped to one of my favourite films of all time as soon as i watched it. Gloria Swanson is fantastic as an ageing silent movie star cast out by Hollywood after films turned to audio dialogue. This film is as relevant today as it was in 1950. I urge anyone that has not yet seen this to make it the next film you watch. I guarantee you will not be disappointed. And the ending.....Oh my god!!!

This incredible movie is among the all-time best in several categories: Best Opening; Best Closing (it will give you goosebumps forever); Best Use of Voiceover Narration; Best Introduction of a Character (Swanson behind that window); Best Quotes ("All right, Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my close-up." and "It's the pictures that got small" are the most famous, but check out von Stroheim's "I wouldn't look at the dates too closely")This movie is so brilliant on so many levels that you watch it over and over with undiminished enjoyment and increased appreciation of its artistry.

reviews.review_title: Would your opinion change if Joe went with Betty rather than Norma?
reviews.content: Sunset blvd is ahead of its time in a sense of film style and the approach of a film noir. If Joe were to go with betty the movie would result into another cliché romantic film. The ending was great in a sense of the suspense towards Norma's craziness and that she has finally snapped and has fully become psychotic. It is a slow start but the whole suspense of the film and the question of how joe died in the beginning scene kept me up on my feet to see what happened. It also helps that It was a second time watching it, so I was trying to look out for some things that I missed which made it a little more intriguing. Finding out that the characters were inspired by the real life cast made it a lot more interesting too! I like the movie how it is and don't think it should be changed except for the pacing.
This is a truly intense film that will stick with you. Well-done and very believable. Check it out and see what you think.

This film is cool because it shine's light on the development of sound in movies and the rapid changes film went through when sound and dialogue put out silent films. Gloria Swanson is brilliant as she bribes a charming young film maker (William Holden) with finer things in exchange for re-exposure in the film world. Shame for Gloria but William finds true love with an intern his own age and it cost him his life.

reviews.review_title: The sun sets on a silent stars career leading to madness.
reviews.content: Many critics say that Gloria Swansons performance was one of the very best ever captured on film. It's hard to disagree.A failed screen writer hides his car, avoiding repossession, in the home of a long forgotten silent star. It's not long before the star moves the writer into her boudoir, hoping he will make something of the appalling script she's written to revive her long dead career.Holdens performance as the gold digging scriptwriter is wonderful. But too late realises he's bitten off far more than he can chew. He has become no more than a gigolo to an ageing, clinging, suicidal has been.A Hollywood tragedy, which reflected how many once famous stars ended up living their lives. Watching and re watching their greatest films whilst waiting, without hope, for the phone to ring.An absolutely jewel of a film. A must see for fans of Wilder and Hollywood at it's very best.

This dark shadowy film noir was an excellent classic that I recommend to anyone. It is funny, dramatic,and tragic. Although the humor is dark it is tasteful. The opening scenes of Sunset Blvd. are some of the most famous in motion picture history. After the opening credits, the camera follows motorcycles and police cars as they pull up to a Beverly Hills mansion where a body floats face-down in a pool. Then a voice over narration begins telling the story of a dead man. The house is almost another character altogether and an amazing mise en scene for a film. Film lovers will love the movie driven story, fantastic performances and great direction. It's one of the few movies that will be well known forever and never forgotten.

Sunset boulevard has got to be one of the greatest movies I have ever seen and not to mention it was directed by billy wilder who has been described as one of the greatest directors of all time and here he delivers one of his greatest finest films of all the history of cinemaIt first shows flashbacks of when joe Gillis ( William Holden) tells then events of what happened before his death such as when he sells paramount pictures to producer sheldrake, this film tells about Hollywood and movies joe is a screenwriter who tries to sell records on a storyThe film like said has elements about doing films it also shows a silent film star Norma desmond( Gloria Swanson) who plans to play her role on screen the film has fictional charachters who are movie makers and it also has some real people like Cecil b demille who is working at paramount and they also work on a screenplayThe film ends with joe being shot and falling in a pool and later max sets up a scene where Norma defends her grand staircaseOverall it's another unforgettable classic from billy wilder and it recieved Oscar nominations including best actress, best actor, best director and best picture

The film offers you two very distinctive worlds of seclusion & chaos.
A struggling film writer, Joe Gillis happens to stumble upon a faded isolated actress, Norma Desmond and begins to work for her at her place.
The character of Norma Desmond is very dominant & narcissistic thereby taking away the personal space of freedom loving Joe through emotional threats as obsession for love & spotlight engulfs her.
Norma Desmond played by Gloria Swanson was brilliant.
William Holden as Joe Gillis was quite charming however I feel it would have been better if the chemistry between Betty Schaefer played by Nancy Olson and Joe was showed a little more. The intimacy between them would've perfectly balanced the unwillingness of Joe to give in to the wishes of Norma.
The screenplay was great and flawless.
A great Noir which influences many modern films.

From Anthony Mann's T-Men to Jules Dassin's Rififi, my favorite noirs have always focused on crime. Crime and noir go hand in hand, a dark subject for a dark genre. It's not required, but the violence and deception and greed that one associates with crime is such appropriate subject matter.Sunset Boulevard is mostly devoid of it, save a murder at the end, and this left me a little disappointed. In the movie's defense, though, it's got a lot of noir's other common elements There's the 1950's California setting, the black and white visuals, a femme fatale, and a dark, sometimes eerie atmosphere.William Holden does a solid job as usual, but props especially go to Gloria Swanson for essentially playing herself—a star of Cecil B. DeMille silent era movies whose popularity waned in the 30's. It's always admirable when actors can play caricatures of themselves, especially when it's in a negative light.The movie has stayed with me in the days since watching it, a good sign that it was memorable. Still, I wonder what its point was. Joe Gillis would criticize me for wanting "one of those message pictures," for not being content with a simple story, and maybe he'd be right. After all, it was at least told well.8/10

This film is excellent! It has some of the best actors of it's time, and of all time. Gloria Swanson was brilliant, and probably because she could really relate to her character. She grew up acting in silent films like her character, and she did a fantastic job. William Holden is brilliant, and the first scene we see him in truly set the pace for the film. It is a film, that many may not know, inspired future generations. Maybe even actors and directors who have never seen this are using some of the same techniques used in this film. It is a classic, and I truly hope Meryl does play in this remake. It would be excellent, and I could only see her or a few other elite actresses playing the role. I don't know who they would get for William Holden's part. All I know is that this movie is excellent and they need to retell it to the world!

reviews.review_title: A Tale as Relevant Today as it was Then
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's Sunset Boulevard tells the story of Joe Gillis (William Holden), a young emerging screenwriter from Ohio struggling to build a career and make ends meet in Hollywood. After evading loan sharks in a high-speed car chase, he blows a tire and peels out into a seemingly abandoned mansion located on the titular street. It turns out to be the residence of silent movie star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), who has long ago been chewed up and spit out by the movie-making machine that is Hollywood. She tells him that she had been expecting him when in all reality she was expecting a man bringing a coffin for her recently deceased pet monkey. Little does Gillis know that he was soon to become its replacement. Desmond ensnares Gillis with hopes of relaunching her movie career in the era of "talkies" (movies with audio), convincing him to move into the mansion to live with her and her butler, Max (Erich von Stroheim).It is no question that Swanson is the star of this film. Her character is utterly believable: a self-infatuated actress "past her prime" as they say, who lives in a constant state of nostalgia. She has all the money anyone could ask for but is stuck in the past, holding on to a dream that has come and gone long ago. Indeed, when this movie came out in 1950, "talkies" had been around for quite some time, with Singin' in the Rain starring Al Jolson being the first mainstream movie to feature sound, released back in 1927. It is interesting to observe Desmond's negative attitude toward the evolution of the technology used in Hollywood. The character presents an interesting psychological case: if she were to have it her way, silent movies would have never gone the way of the dodo, which would have been simply unrealistic. It is also interesting to watch her obsession with her appearance devour her: a problem that actresses in Hollywood have to this day.This movie is easy to follow, yet thought-provoking. There are not too many characters to keep track of, and the plot develops at a nice, steady pace. The sticky situation in which our protagonist finds himself may not be relatable but it is understandable. He's basically the woman's sugar baby, in modern terms. The dynamic that grows (or rather, deteriorates) between the two is what makes this movie so captivating. The setting is novel yet believable, and the acting is superb. I really have no complaints.I decided to watch this movie upon the referral of one of my college professors, and I am glad I did! It is definitely worth the 110 minutes of your time, and it was easily among the best movies I saw last year. It is an interesting reflection upon the role that technology plays in society and how the people who are unable to adapt get left behind. It is also a story about heartbreak, be it because of not being loved by someone you want to be loved by, or by having your dreams shattered. These themes are relevant to this day, and in fact, it's hard to believe this movie came out seventy years ago. If you are considering watching this movie, go for it! You will not regret it.

Sunset Blvd., to this day, tells such a real story. The young Hollywood star being shoved out when not needed anymore, and the struggling writer who is sure he'll someday make his break; two stories colliding with the unwavering need for success. It is this fight for fame that makes this film so endearing and creepy. That, and Norma Desmond's destroyed, cluttered house, which creates a perfect setting for the story. The house is so suffocatingly sad with all the photos and sculptures that whenever the story goes somewhere else in Hollywood, it's like a breath of fresh air. The nights when Joel and Betty were writing in her office was like waking up from a dream, because it was so mundane and 'real life' compared to Norma Desmond's false reality.
Sunset Blvd. fits flawlessly into the genre of film noir, what with Joel's murder and the crazed Norma Desmond bringing an eerie feeling to all its viewers, but it also does what previous silent and talking movies didn't. It added layers and a complex storyline that more could connect with, instead of just some grand adventure of mystery where everything turned out fine. It wasn't made to tell some happy story where a man and woman meet and fall in love. It told the truth. It told the story that so many Hollywood actors lived through, showed that not everyone in the industry is somebody. Sunset Blvd. wasn't just an entertainment piece; it was made to make you think.

This was an incredible movie, it had a unique plot and kept my attention the whole way through. Norma Desmond's character was one of the most unique and interesting characters I've seen. it was very thought provoking on the relationship of Norma Betty and the main character. it was an interesting concept that was well played out

reviews.review_title: A brilliant portrayal of a tragic destiny. A masterpiece indeed!
reviews.content: Director Billy Wilder brilliant portrayal of the tragic destiny of NormaDesmond(Gloria Swanson ),an aging silent film queen remains a classic masterpiece and one the best movies ever made. Celebrated masterful performances by William Holden(Joe Gills) ,Erich Von Stroihem(Max)and Nancy Olson(Betty) makes Sunset Boulevard a timeless classic.Norma Desmond is an aging silent film queen who is neglected for over two decades by the directors and forgotten by her fans. Joe Gills is a struggling script writer and accidentally stumbles across Norma's palatial mansion. His fortunes change for good though he hates his new life and wants to get back to his work.This unfolds a tragic destiny .William Holden's performance is truly commendable and together with Norma Desmond ,Joe Gills make up the screen's greatest characters ever. Erich Von Stroihem as Norma's discoverer,ex-husband turned her butler is a very important character who shows his faithfulness till the very end and will go to any extreme to ease Norma's pain.Betty(Nancy Olson) reader and a prospective script writer comes up with a poignant performance.Truly a timeless masterpiece indeed.
Bad decisions are always regrets as I've seen in this film. I don't know why they shortened the boulevard 😂

Gloria Swanson chews up the scenery as a spoiled and mentally disturbed former silent film queen who sees her big comeback coming closer when she sinks her claws into William Holden's desperate screenwriter. Both sad and darkly humorous and filled with tons of memorable lines.

reviews.review_title: Would like to see it without the narration.
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's "Sunset Blvd." is definitely a classic film with many memorable moments, but I can't help but think that it would have been better without the narration by William Holden's character. I think Gloria Swanson's performance deserves it's place on the list of all-time great ones and Erich Von Stroheim was very good as well. William Holden wasn't bad, he was quite good actually. It was his narration, however, that bothered me throughout the film. I was watching the final scene of Norma Desmond coming down the staircase and I thought to myself, this would be so much creepier if we didn't hear Joe Gillis' voice. Anyway, that's just my thoughts. Despite all that, this is still one of the great ones.10 out of 10

This picture takes the happily-ever-after myth of Hollywood stardom and shatters it for good. When talking pictures became the standard virtually overnight, the big studios turned their collective backs on most of the silent icons that had helped build them. This film offers a frequently sympathetic view of the descent of one of these icons into despair and madness - and for silent film buffs, offers a rare opportunity to see the likes of Anna Q. Nilsson and Buster Keaton in speaking cameos. This film greatly pushes the limits during a time where the code ruled over Hollywood. A Real trend setter

Sunset Boulevard was one of those movies that I kept thinking about the next day. The aged actress' character seemed very real to me, although she was eccentric and crazy. She was very sympathetic and I felt as if Joe took advantage of her. I liked the way this movie was made, the body in the pool, the darkness, the isolation of much of the movie. The inclusion of references to other film stars and film makers also brought a realistic feel to it. Their relationship somehow made me uncomfortable, I'm not sure if it was their age difference or because she was so needy and controlling of him. It did seem he had some feeling for her, because he went back after he found out that she tried to kill herself. That last scene was very powerful with the lights and the crowd, like her swansong. A very impressive use of lighting as well.

the reason i find this picture so interesting is the very delicate issue it talks about.an aging x Hollywood star is having a very hard time dealing with the fact she's getting old and still dreams of her big comeback to pictures even though they have changed from the time she used to act.having a hard time getting old is a very common thing its just that this specific woman develops it to some kind of madness or psychotic sickness that is damaging her life more and more as time goes by.she is basically obsessed with herself which naturally is the reason she gets neglected by everyone and ends up being lonely again and again, this loneliness is eventually what will make her suicidal.the only one who is always there and never leaves her is her servant which is her first husband.my opinion on this is that they got married when she was young and healthy with no sicknesses or self obsessions. this is also the reason he stays with her all along, because he knows how she is when she is OK and he's probably waiting for the day she will return to herself.the film is very exciting and even though you know from the start what is about to happen in the end you cant know exactly how it happens.it makes you feel really good watching a movie that is almost 60 years old for the first time and still being satisfied of it i.i have never seen a story like this in film before and even if i did i don't believe it would have been the same as in sunset blvd.i cant finish without saying something about the ending, it really doesn't get better then this.perhaps one of the best endings i have ever seen on screen.

I discovered Billy Wilder movies once COVID began in 2020. I am so glad I discovered his movies. As far as the way films were made during this time period, wilder is unmatched and a true genius. While a dark movie, the performances are stellar and the story sucks you in from the beginning. The narration of Billy Wilder movies makes it impossible for you to take your eyes off the screen.

Sunset Boulevard (1950) Hollywood is the land of dreams, fame, money, and broken hearts. "Sunset Boulevard" is an almost behind the scenes look at the industry and the type of people in it. Sunset Boulevard is a real road that runs through Los Angeles and Beverly Hills and features real Hollywood landmarks like the movie Mulholland Drive."Sunset Boulevard" opens with a murder scene, murder is always a hot subject in Hollywood, especially if it was someone famous or in the industry, such as Elizabeth Short, an inspiring actress became California's most infamous murder victim in 1947 because of the mystery behind her death and that she was actress and actor River's Phoenix who died from a drug overdose on the actual Sunset Boulevard, outside of the Viper Room. The movie also features a starving struggling writer and his experience with his rotten agent and the movie producer who wants to change his script. There's also the loyal butler, the fresh newbies to the scene writer and the party guy film crew worker. All of these stereotypes work very well to help create the world of Hollywood. They were made so stereotypical to the point of parody to show how crazy it can be to live in Hollywood, or as some people call it, HollyWeird! The bizarreness doesn't stop there, pet monkeys, Directors marring the stars, becoming their butlers, and super ego complexes.At the center of the film is Norman Desmond, as played by Gloria Swanson. Gloria Swanson wasn't by far the first person considered for the film, she wasn't even the sixth. But Gloria Swanson delivers one of the most memorable roles of all time with some of the most famous lines of movie history. Norman Desmond is a former silent movie star the world has seemed to forgotten, living in a huge run down mansion with a faithful butler. With a larger then life ego and in deep denial of her stardom, Norma is a diva that demands a lot of attention and often acts like the world revolves around her. Norma is writing a script when Joe first meets her and after reading it and hearing that it was written from the heart Joe says that it's the best kind of writing, but the script is heavily flawed. Norma longs to return to the limelight, she's had a taste of it and wants it back. She's also looking for someone to love and keep her company. When Joe arrives that fateful day Norma finds a gentleman who could help her with her script, but the relationship slowly grows and changes until Joe has become Norma's show boy. Joe doesn't really like being kept, but soon learns to live with it and enjoy the loveless relationship, well loveless to him. With Joe around Norma becomes more outgoing and ventures outside of her estate and sees more old friends. Much like Norma, Joe's taste of the limelight remains and he also gets caught up back in the industry and starts to enjoy writing once again.Casting is extremely well done for "Sunset Boulevard", it casts a former silent movie star Gloria Swanson who fit the role perfectly, to getting cameo appearances from other silent movie era stars. The casting adds to the world of Hollywood and makes it feel real with a real director playing himself (Cecil B. DeMille) and a director(Erich von Stroheim) playing the butler."Sunset Boulevard" contains everything Hollywood has: romance, power, money, deceit, actors, actresses, new comers, writers, directors, murder, a come back attempt, a studio and scandal.

Billy Wilder might be my favorite filmmaker from that era, and Sunset Boulevard is just another example of his towering brilliance.
