That just makes it heartbreaking to hear how All About Eve got all the attention that year, when this was the clear rightful winner, a movie so searing in its Hollyweird indictment, giving it Oscars is almost ironic.Everything that makes movies perfect is here, from performances (Swanson, Holden, Stroheim), to writing to direction to the cinematography that's gorgeous in the land of dreams themselves. Or nightmares once the story gets going. And what a story it is!! Above all, the greatest part of the movie isn't anything I've stated before, it's in the themes.In terms of themes and the story itself, I could write an entire paper on this, that's how dense it actually is. Holds up perfectly and is only better with age now. Greatness rarely ever approached on this level until the New Wave much later.

I thought this movie was pretty good. I like how it shows how Hollywood can affect a person and how being in the spotlight can consume their life. Norma Desmond played by Gloria Swanson is a perfect example. In this movie she is living in the past to when she was really famous. A man by the name of Joe Gillis ends up at her house and gets forced to look at her screen play. Norma seems like she has some kind of mental problem and that shes not all there. If Joe tries and goes somewhere and shes not with him she acts like she is gonna kill herself. At the end of the movie he tries and leaves but as he walks out she shoots him. It doesn't even phase her. When the cops come she thinks that they are their to shoot her movie. So we see the camera focus on her as she is coming down the stairs. She doesn't even know that they are their to take her away that's how messed up she is. She is to focused on being in the spotlight.

This movie is about a old movie star that still things that people love her and new who she is. her name is Norma Desmond and she was famous for silence movies. but it become a new era where they no longer making silent movie. she is love herself so much that she has photos of herself all over the place and she even watches her own movie. Joe Gillis is the narrator of the story he is also a man that just came upon her house when his car broke down. he was a writer for movie. she would help pay him to do look over her story to see if it was any good and to edit but what she really want him for was to stay with her forever. it is a Drama about a old crazy actress that just wants a companionship. the movie is a little slow but then it picks up
Stays enticing and incredibly abducting all the way thorough: from the first killer-shot till the last...from the first viewing to obsessing about it.

I very much enjoyed watching Sunset Blvd. I really liked the director Wilder a lot. I loved the plot I thought it was a different mix up from the typical romance films. I liked how it was about a faded movie star. It was something different that you didn't see a lot in the early 1950s, rather then all the glam. I have to say that I did like the soundtrack, it was a mix up which I really don't usually like. The camera work was great and the sounds. It brought out the city in a great way, you thought you were there during the whole film. The only thing I didn't like was that it was in black and white. I thought that it could have been a lot better in color.

I recently bought this classic on DVD and just last night had a chance to watch it.Being quite young I was amazed to be so impressed by a film from Hollywood's yesteryear. But then again that was the point of the film (Spoilers coming up).The film deals with Hollywood's evolution and taps upon the superficial nature of the industry especially how it treats it's workers!Gillis, superbly portrayed by Holden, is a screen writer down on his luck who accidentally becomes involved with Norma Desmond, Swanson, silent film star of Yesteryear. Wilder uses his key figures to represent the different ages of Hollywood. Norma Desmond "Queen of the silent film" star of Hollywood's Golden era is all but forgotten as Hollywood starts to make films with sound. Gillis whose scripts were popular during the Silver age of Hollywood are suddenly not popular any more as he can not adapt his style fast enough to the demand for riskier story lines. Finally the beautiful Betty Schaefer (Olsen) who represents the future of Hollywood.The film's main point illuminates how as Hollywood changes the people that helped build it are left behind when they cease to become popular. Desmond becomes a hermit - recluse from an industry and fans that deserted her. But in a chance encounter with Gillis she sees an opportunity to come back into the industry by way of a new script she has been working on. The film traces the start, peak and ultimately the demise of the relationship between Desmond & Gillis. A metaphor for the start, peak and ultimate demise of the eras they represented.Very intelligent and well directed film with Stella performances from all key cast & crew.

Superbly written and directed, it is a beautiful combination of dark humor and tragic film noir. The way Wilder shoots the film, he makes it like it is a blend of dreamlike images and hilarious reality. Perfectly captures Hollywood during that time period.Performance by Gloria Swanson was fantastic, amazing acting. In my opinion the genre of the film can be argued. It seems as though it is a blend of many different genres.

This IS a great film. But it is, unfortunately, over-rated.I find it fascinating, but the writing does not hold a candle to it's contemporary, All About Eve, nor does the acting. Swanson delivers a very good performance, but it lacks the complete mastery of her craft that Bette Davis delivered as Margo Channing in a much more moving and self-aware performance. Swanson was a great star but she always delivered her lines over the top and frankly I don't think she could have delivered her lines in this movie any other way. She was limited.The direction is excellent and in cinematography alone can this film be said to be superior to All About Eve.I never found William Holden particularly interesting as an actor but he does a credible job here. I find it odd that this movie is so adored but that I guess is all personal taste. I wouldn't put it in my top ten, although it's in my top 100 for sure.

reviews.review_title: one of the greatest classics of all time
reviews.content: The film itself is fantastic, with great dialogue, superb (over-)acting and some of the most memorable scenes in movie history. What makes it absolutely compelling is the way fiction and reality are intertwined. Make sure you see this one.

There is a lot to love about this movie, which is loaded with great performances, and intersects film noir with fading Hollywood stardom. It grabs us from the start with police called to the scene of a mansion with a body floating in its pool, and as we listen to a deadpan narrator. Director Billy Wilder gives us the first of what will be many great shots, this one from what appears to be the bottom of the pool, with policemen in the background standing over the body. The film then flashes back to a young writer (William Holden), down on his luck and pressured by repo men, trying to figure out a way to sell his work or borrow some money. He pulls into the driveway of a mansion by chance, and finds himself slowly entangled in another trap, that of an aging Hollywood star (Gloria Swanson). The feel is eerie from the start, as she seeks funeral arrangements for her pet chimp, lives in boundless ostentation, and has a single companion, her solemn servant (Erich von Stroheim) who plays an organ that otherwise wheezes drearily when the wind blows through it. While her pool and tennis courts have fallen into ruin, she lives in the past, surrounded by her own photographs and watching her own old movies. Out of what he feels to be necessity, he begins working for her and living with her, hating every moment. Gloria Swanson, who was 51, turns in an outstanding performance, and has several fantastic scenes. The one where she and Holden sit in the dark with the projector light going through smoke is brilliant, and one of my favorites. Another is him dancing with her on the floor that she says Valentino had danced on, surrounded by an orchestra and expecting other guests, only to realize there will be none. The one where she imitates Charlie Chaplin, complete with a little tramp outfit, is truly special. Wilder is excellent at gradually revealing just how far gone she is. It was a nice touch of his to include silent movie stars as her bridge companions in a small scene, including Buster Keaton, and to see Cecil B. DeMille on the set at Paramount was fantastic. We see both her delusion of still being an important star as she rolls up to the gate house in her expensive old car (an Isotta-Fraschini), and yet we also see her past stardom recognized by one of the gate keepers, and then people on the set when they realize she's there. It's a very touching moment. Things get more complicated when Holden begins working with the fiancé (Nancy Olson) of his affable friend (Jack Webb, soon to be better known for Dragnet). Not all of the scenes revolve around Swanson, and the one where Holden and Olson play act a romantic scene at a party is intelligent, funny, and utterly charming. The film gives us a behind the scenes look at Hollywood - brainstorming over scripts, the writing process, the vanity of those in the limelight, and the opulence. Swanson gets a little over the top at times especially towards the end, but the film feels both sadly true, and yet also fantastical, with her mansion other-worldly and not unlike that of the one Miss Havisham has in 'Great Expectations', as Holden observes early on. With such a setting and those poignant overtones, and having excellent direction, cinematography, script, and cast, it's hard to go wrong with this one.

I give this film a lot of credit for its creativity with respect to the storyline. I felt like it was an episode from the twilight zone because Gloria Swanson was so detached from reality. I liked the narration being from the point of view of the murdered man in flashback style. I thought this was unique. A lot of the story took place in the mansion of Gloria and I thought that the design did a good job of portraying her insanity. She had tons of pictures of herself and it was a good portrayal of her self-absorbed personality with respect to her former acting career. I liked the idea that there were a lot of characters in the film that were played by actual people who worked during the silent film era. It really contributed to the verisimilitude of the film. The last scene was classic and I will never forget it. The only way they could safely get her out of the house was by creating the image that she was acting in a film. Brilliant.

reviews.review_title: Superb film-art... and the story of Hollywood too.
reviews.content: This is the story of a demented old silent film actress who decides her day is not over. Through a comedy of errors, a happy-go-lucky and handsome young screenwriter stumbles into her realm and she latches on to him like a spider on a fly. He's broke and she's filthy rich -- she commissions him to live-in and write her Pinnacle role which she intends for Cecil B. DeMille, her friend of the good old days, to produce. She also intends for the young man to be her gigolo, a role that he's unwilling to fulfill.DeMille actually makes a cameo appearance in this fine old black and white production and the story is just a great one.I particularly recommend this movie to anyone interested in the doings of old Hollywood; however, almost anyone would enjoy this picture of love, hate, hope, revenge, and ultimately, murder!

People now a days are coming up with ways of making some hard earned money for themselves, mostly to pay off bills, pay off loans, buy food and clothing for themselves. It's important for people to earn their money the honest way, not by bribery or as an excuse to fall in love with somebody. It's also important not to be too obsessed with yourself and your achievements. Nobody's perfect in the world.The voice narration spoken by the main actor throughout sections of the film was deep and well spoken. The narration helped make the film feel like a crime movie by it's spoken visualizing details and mood the main actor was portraying throughout the film. At times, the narration make the viewers feel like they're in the Twlight Zone. The cinematography throughout the film was good. The slow montage that was used to show the title of the film was suspenseful and dramatic with the musical composition. There are many uses of scenes fading in and out of the bedroom scene as the screenwriter is alone writing the actress' screenplay. The closeups of the screenwriter looking into the bedroom and of the screenwriter talking to another man were well focused in mid-tone greys and well situated in their sense of depth. The use of artificial shone on the actors and their reflections on the wall were well shown in their dark contrast. The acting in this film was played out well.Although at times, the long takes dragged on the plot for a period of time, the movie kept up its suspense and drama through its great acting, lighting, mood, narration, and musical score that made the movie good. I would recommend this movie if you're interested in watching great Film Noir films.

reviews.review_title: Great film considering when it was made; taking account it was during the hays code and the year it was made (1950)
reviews.content: I thought that Sunset Blvd. was very intriguing the way it was filmed and the was it was scripted. Personally, "film noir style" doesn't appeal to me very much but the character development and plot made it worth the while. Norma's crazy, huge ego minded personality set in the rustic mansion contrasted with Joe's low income, easily persuaded (by money) character along with his romance with Betty sustained my interest for sure. The film makers really hyperbolized each of the characters most prominent traits, such as Normas batty behavior and Betty's soft, aspiring personality. I think this type of scripting brought the film to life and made up for the lack of colour. (of course, colour wasn't possible at the time) What added to the film was the symbolism throughout, and the irony of Norma being played by Gloria Swanson, previous silent film star. Overall, I found the film was very well rounded in the sense that it wasn't just a love story, but a clever, witty, dark, and emotionally touching piece made in a time where this was very hard to find.

The only fault to this film is the pacing. the film started out grabbing my attention, but since i already knew what was going to happen, waiting for the plot to pick up. The beginning that showed the events leading to Joe's residence at the Desmond estate was painfully slow, and instead of rising, my interest remained flat. After gradually developing Norma's character, the plot took off and my enthusiasm for the film rose exponentially. The ending was absolutely brilliant; setting Norma up to have her believe that she was being filmed for the picture that she wrote and had been preparing for. if Norma's character had not been so mentally unstable, i don't believe this film would have succeeded as well as it did.

I absolutely adored this movie. Plenty of suspense and it told a wonderful tale of a love that just doesn't work. The part of Norma Desmond was played brilliantly, and really drove home the part of a woman who is trapped by her own former glory, unable to move on and grasp reality. The final scene in this movie is absolutely amazing, with the camera crews and newsmen all crowding around her, while she indulges in her own fantasy that she has finally returned to the set and is making a picture once again. I first came across this movie as the number one spot in a lost of the top film noirs, and now I can easily see why. This is the only movie on this site that I have had the pleasure to give a perfect 10 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Sunset Boulevard is a Great and Dark Neighborhood
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard is one of the great film noir classics and a pivotal movie of the era. It is one of the first to show the darkest shadows hovering over Hollywood. Sunset Boulevard unfolds like a kaleidoscope, like petals of a flowers dropping into tears. The center of the plot, the total convergence of fantasy and reality, is realized in a single moment in the third act, at the top of the staircase of Norma Desmond. Can you spot it? Fantastic characterizations and performances. We in the dark are mesmerized by its haunting message.

This film noir shows the twists and turns of being an actor, and behind the world of Hollywood productions, and the guidelines and restrictions behind them.Unlike most film noirs, there isn't much of an antagonist, and it is more of a film focused on chracters and the interactions between them. The character of Norma shows perfectly the corruption and egotistical attitude an actor can portray if they allow themselves too, and is the first film I have seen that has done it so well.Unlike many of the traditional cookie cutter films at the time, this film decided to be different in its perspective, looking behind the scenes of the productions and people behind them at the time.The only thing I found wrong with this film was the pacing, the beginning of the film was quite slow and sort of felt like it was beginning to become repetitive. Apart from that this was a very interesting film, and everyone should watch it.

I was interested in the first 10 minutes of this movie, but sadly after that I began to lose interest in what was happening. I found most of the movie a little boring at times. The story is simple. A film writer needs money so he doesn't lose his car, as he is running away from the men that want his car, he walks into a famous but forgotten silent film actress. She is lonely and wants him to stay with her to keep her company, he is in need of money and she is rich and supplies him with all of this fancy stuff. He eventually gets sick of her buying him things, so he tries to leave. When he is trying to leave she goes crazy and says that she will kill herself if he doesn't stay. He walks out on her and instead of killing herself, she kills him. In the beginning of the film we see a dead body in a pool, now we know who the dead body was. I was disappointed with this movie, I would have liked it more if I was more interested in the story.

reviews.review_title: A new appreciation of a classic
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard 10/10When I couldn't sleep the other night, I watched the Special Collector's Edition of Sunset Boulevard. I saw this movie years ago. After seeing the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical in Johannesburg recently, I fell in love with it all over again. I know there's nothing new to say about Billy Wilder's classic – its camp sharpness, its haunting Gothic melancholy, its rich, dark comedy, its insidiously fascinating characters – so I won't try. What struck me was recognising Wilder as a genius director. Often seen as a writer who favoured the screenplay more than visual elements, in this movie he really showed some innovative insight into framing his masterpiece. Two, in particular, stand out – the fish eye view of the body in the swimming pool and use of powder on the edges of the camera lenses. I also enjoyed the commentary into the music of the film. When I watched the film again, I had a new appreciation for Franz Waxman's score.
Gloria Swanson was amazing in this film. It did a great job of depicting what hollywood and fame can you do to a person.
This is a classic movie that stays on top. Very good plot and interesting characters. Gloria Swanson will be remembered for many movies but this one makes her name immortal.

This film focused on dealing with ruined star, Norma Desmond. she live mansion fallen alone with her butler Max. After meeting with Norma desmond and Joe Gillis, story start to be different. Norma Desmond dream again that she comeback to stage. As much as the mind of dreams bigger, the obsession got bigger toward men who help her, and this led to the collapse of relationships and unfortunate events. impressive portion of this movie is when the movie was started, it show the scene the death of a man closely related to the ending. through this direction, i can more concentrated on story and infer what will follow myself. And also unique charcter and acting of actors are very well fit on the movie.

reviews.review_title: "I am big! It's the pictures that got small"
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's "Sunset Blvd" (1950) was a symbolic end of the Golden Age. Norma Desmond's silent film acting was long gone and she was well into her 50's but in her mind she was still a star.Joe Gillis played by William Holden stumbles upon Desmond's (played by Gloria Swanson) eerie mansion and immediately thinks it's been deserted. Little does he know has-been Norma is slowly slipping away into the isolation of insanity. Her mansion is more lair-like than anything with a frightening pipe organ that makes her haunted house even more disturbing. The lair is filled with photographs of the young and famous Norma that decay along with her."No one leaves a star!" Norma says over and over again right before she shoots Joe and he tumbles into the pool he always wanted. This scene was so haunting and terrifying, I couldn't stop thinking about it. It really stuck with me and I loved it.I've really come to love the classic film noir movies! I always find myself hoping that the flash forward at the beginning of the film won't play out in the end, even though it must.

I thought that this movie was quite interesting. Did I like it?! No, not very much. But I thought that the idea and the story line behind the movie was very well thought out. Unless you are an actor or actress yourself, nobody really knows what goes on inside the head of a burnt out or out of work actor. We learned this from Gloria Swanson's character, Norma Desmond. Norma was a silent film star who was intending to make her way back into the spotlight and dragged Joe Gillis (William Holden) into her crazy made up world where she would eventually become a movie start yet again. I thought that the acting was fine, and the cinematography was nice, which makes it seem like I enjoyed the movie; but towards the very end of the movie, I was just begging for it to end. I felt that the story was played out far too much, and I just didn't want to watch it anymore. Maybe it will be better if I watch it again, but I'm not sure if I could sit through it one more time.

reviews.review_title: Must watch for serious cinephiles and others alike.
reviews.content: I don't have to talk about Sunset Boulevard as the film is highly rated as it is. This is a great noir film, brilliantly lit and acted. The premise is simple: A Hollywood screenwriter chances upon an aging actress who orders him to rework a screenplay. He is relocated to her mansion- which is as much as a character as she is, and soon he realizes that not only is he trapped, but that the mysterious aging actress is a loose nut. Billy Wilder's film was a massive success upon release and its reputation has only grown since. William Holden is well cast as the tragic young scriptwriter and Gloria Swanson is magical as the elusive silent screen siren. This is dark comedy of the highest order.

This is definitely one of the best movies of all time.
There is no much to say.This is one of those movies that is better to watch without any information about it.
It is good how it plays with you, using so many resources, mixing so different genres, telling you a story with words, and another one with images.It is a little short, but also, this is really effective.
It never lets go of your mind, and keeps you sit and quiet.Anyone who loves cinema can't miss this.

reviews.review_title: An argument for black and white
reviews.content: There are three reasons why I love this movie: Billy Wilder, Gloria Swanson, and black and white photography.  Don't misunderstand me, I love the other actors (Holden is his usual solid self)in this film, but Swanson's performance has to be one of the small handful of all-time great performances by a leading actress (my other favorites are Meryl Streep in Sophie's Choice, Bette Davis in All About Eve, and Katherine Hepburn in The Lion In Winter).  Unfortunately for Swanson, All About Eve was released in the same year, so Swanson and Davis cancelled each other out and Judy Holliday stole the Oscar for Born Yesterday, one of the All-time Oscar travesties.  Swanson puts it all out there for us in this film, and we all get to just eat it up.  She's nothing short of mesmerizing in this film...just try not to pay attention to her and you'll see what an act of futility that is.Wilder?  Quite simply, he's my favorite director of all time, and this may well be his best work.  Eight Oscar nominations for Best Director! What's even more amazing is that he was nominated twelve (that's right, twelve) times for Best Screenplay!  How many contemporary directors also write their own work?  I don't mean to disparage modern directors; on the contrary, I don't expect directors to write the story as well as tell it, but that's what made Wilder so special.  His works include Some Like It Hot, The Lost Weekend, Stalag 17, Sabrina, The Apartment, Double Indemnity, and Witness For The Prosecution.  Counting Sunset Boulevard, Wilder has six films in imdb's Top 250, with none of those lower than 170.  That's one hell of a resume folks!Finally, the photography.  If anyone ever remakes this film, shame on them. Not only does this film HAVE to be in black and white, but it's just impossible to imagine improving on the way it is filmed.  Rarely have I watched a movie and gotten the creeps just from the atmosphere of an old house, but this film does it to me every time, and I've seen it several times!  For William Holden, this house becomes something of a prison, and just getting out of it means everything to him.  We the audience come to feel the same way.A great, great film, one of the best ever.  Check it out and enjoy!

reviews.review_title: Another really great classic that lives up to the hype
reviews.content: What I liked: the creepy feel of the old mansion during the first half of the film, the final scene of course, the weird incident with the dead monkey and its burial. What I didn't like: some of Swanson's over-the-top acting.

It is very simple.  If you haven't seen Sunset Blvd., you must. Every time I see it I get chilled.  Wilder at his best, which says a lot.  Beautiful to watch and superb acting add up to make Sunset Blvd. one of the best films I have seen.

This Movie was one of the most intresting and action packed black and white films I have even seen. The script was remarkable and I would consider the man who wrote it a genius. Everything from the cinemotography considering it was 1950 and the acting just everything came together to make an amazing film.

reviews.review_title: Did a good job at being unsettling
reviews.content:
Sunset Boulevard had me internally yelling the entire way "What are you doing?!". I guess it was extremely unsettling to me to see Gillis becoming dependent on the riches of such a painfully fragile yet egotistical woman. To say the least, it was just uncomfortable to observe the path that Gillis was taking himself through - he had a much more promising future working with Schaffer. Yes, he may have been close to drowning in Desmond's wealth, and could (maybe) have a shot at potentially enhancing her mediocre scripts to fit the likings of the people at Paramount, thus earning him a (very) dependant living. But did he really want that? I don't particularly think so. I feel like he was almost accepting his "fate" with a sort of resentment. Because he felt like he didn't really have a choice, because he thought he had a shot with giving her reputation a face lift. Eventually I'm pretty sure he started to realize that he couldn't stay with this lady anymore, that he needed to turn his life around and go back, find his own friends his own age, working with people his own age.
I think Schaffer alluded to many opportunities and chances Gillis could take to work with her, such as when Gillis had enough of Desmond and decided back to his friend Green to inquire on whether or not Green could give him a few nights at his place. Then he was subsequently informed by Schaefer that she believed one of his scripts had potential - and was almost abruptly turned down in return when he declined. Or when Mayerling divulged to him the nearly unfathomable fact that it was in fact he who was really writing and sending the fan mail to Desmond. Because clearly no one found much taste in her work anymore. And her fame was vanishing. Fast.
I feel like the entire time he was almost battling an inner doubt within him - to find wealth and work with a seemingly crazed older lady with a fragile ego, or sign a deal with Schaffer who comprehended that his work had potential. I feel like he was in a way not really sure what he was getting himself into in the first place - he was $300 in debt, no one would lend him anything, and he started to develop mutual relations with this old woman. The ending was almost scary to me. He completely lost his chances with Schaffer. It was like his double life was seriously messing with his thinking too. The second Desmond revealed the firearm, I was 99.9% sure he wasn't leaving the estate alive (the 0.01% I was reserving for a miracle. I mean, you never know with this woman who seemed dazed to the point of becoming schizophrenic-like at the final ending shot). Somehow when she was following him with the gun I still hadn't connected the dots to the shot at the start with the dead body in the pool. But then, yes - it all made sense in a landslide.
Overall, if the film was meant to be perceived as unsatisfying/settling to their primary audiences, well it worked for me.

Joe (William Holden) is a young screenwriter down on his luck and is struggling in Hollywood to make ends meet after leaving a news reporting job in Dayton, Ohio to pursue a screenwriting career in Hollywood. While avoiding the repo man Jo make a left turn into a situation he will never forget.  The driveway he turns into is none other than the famous silent screen diva Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) who lives in an amazing decrepit Hollywood mansion. Norma Desmond is a once famous movie star who is having problems facing the reality that stardom is no longer part of her life. Norma has been working on a script for a movie that would star her as the lead character propelling her back into her superstar status. Norma hires Jo to refine the script housing him conveniently above the garage. Jo being broke cannot refuse the offer. When water damage forces Jo to move into the main house Jo becomes more tangled in the web of the temptress Norma.  Jo becomes a kept man receiving expensive clothes and trinkets from Norma and loses touch with his life as a budding screenwriter. Opportunities for romance are faltered by the meldding Norma with Jo getting fed up with it all wanting to return to Ohio but he does not make it. Norma gets her final close-up from the news reporters who engulf her mansion to capture footage of the once famous movie star turned murderer.The film begins with Jo doing a dead mans float literally, reflecting on what went wrong with his interactions with Norma Desmond. This film is classified as a Film Noir and Gloria Swanson's performance creates an eerie feeling anywhere in or around her mansion that complements her creepy character. The audience can tell Gloria's character has a few screws loose and the anticipation for something bad to happen is apparent throughout the film especially because you know Jo is killed at one point in the film.One of the things I liked the most about this film is the gaudy limo that Norma and Jo are driven around in by Max (Erich Von Stroheim) the butler. The limo is an imported hand made monstrosity that has leopard skin seats. Norma and Jo are driven around like royalty in this limo while people are pointing and laughing at the sheer site of the limo. The funny thing about Max the butler is that he is the director that found Norma as an actress and has accepted a menial job just to be around her.  Max is really creepy and seems to being always lurking around the mansion observing what is going on. Some significant facts about this film are for one the film deviated from the classical Hollywood mold of film making while pointing out what happens to stars that are no longer wanted by film makers and the movie viewing public exemplifying the myth of the Hollywood life. Norma Desmond is a delusional actress that has been used up and no longer needed by the Hollywood film makers. Hollywood did not like the way this idea was portrayed and only time could give the credit due for this film. Gloria Swanson was actually a silent movie start in the 20's and was making a comeback starring in Sunset Blvd. The friends that come to play bridge with Gloria's character were also silent film stars. The butler Max Von Mayerling (Erich Von Stroheim) was actually a prominent silent film director.

This seems to be William Holden week on AMC.  Last night we saw "Sunset Blvd." and the night before, "The Country Girl."  I was struck by the fact that, at the end of "The Country Girl," Grace Kelly (b. 1929) returns to Bing Crosby (b. 1901) & everybody (presumably) cheers her fidelity.  While midway thru "Sunset Blvd.," Wm. Holden (b. 1918) forces himself to get in bed with Gloria Swanson (b. 1899 or 1897, depending on whether you believe IMDb or Roger Ebert).  So Swanson is an old hag, while Crosby is still a reasonably attractive guy.  And the age gap is actually less between Holden & Swanson. Go figure, but to me it looks like the double standard in action.  The question is: Have we improved since the '50s in our attitude towards this sort of situation?

Sunset Blvd. is a movie about movies. Something that was bound to happen at some point, but was never bound to hit so close to home. The commentary in this film about the washed up actors, and screenwriters struggling to make ends meet is very refreshing in an era where most movies followed a set of rules to never undermine the Hollywood system. Silent movie actors went somewhere, most of them nowhere good.

Billy Wilder always liked the obvious and easy things. For instance, Jack Lemon is the "middle American everyman", Marilyn is the dumb girl, Stanwyck is the blonde wicked vamp, Stroheim is "one of the three grands directors of the silent era", Swanson disguised as Chaplin, etc. His films are often overwritten (lines like "next time I'll write "The naked and the dead", "who wants to see a film about the civil war?", etc.). "Sunset Boulevard" is a typical Wilder film, full of obvious and overblown things like that, but is a film that it gets better as the decades pass by, I don't know exactly the reason. It is a film that is "so bad that is very good". Perhaps in ten years, another awful "wilderiana" as "The big carnival" (almost worse than SBoulevard) will be also redeemed by its campy flavor.

This movie was right up my alley with the psychology of it, the feel of insanity. This is a film-noir that caused a stir in the Hollywood world. This was due to it portrayal of Hollywood; not old the actors and actresses but of what goes on behind the scenes. The scandals and things that get swept under the rug. It was a real slap in the face for the many that think of Hollywood as glamorous and ideal. These days it's not that hard to believe that Hollywood is so scandalous because their "dirty laundry" is made public all the time in tabloids and such. I also find it ironic that all Norma wants is to make a comeback and never does, when in real life Gloria Swanson did just that.

reviews.review_title: Welcome to Hell House aka Norma's Place
reviews.content: I was so glad to have seen this film again. It had been many years since I had first watched it, and now seeing it, it was so much more of an important film to me. There are several little tricks that work on such a great level in this film that the next time I watch it I will be excited about this wonderful film. Joe's narration, opening the film with the end of the film, the set design of Norma's house, the superb cinematography and most of all Gloria Swanson. This is the only film I have ever seen of hers and she is so amazing. The character of Norma Desmond is one of a somewhat forgotten actress of the silent era who believes it is time for her great comeback to the silver screen. There is one problem though, she is a loon. Outright over the top whack job who obsesses on her career. Swamson is over the top. Very believable at times and as well, very laughable. There is a movie out there called The Forbidden Zone from early 1980's. The actress Susan Tyrell portrays a character very similar to the Desmond role, even in her facial expressions. I recommend this film to all who enjoy a good drama/thriller. I have a feeling that this film will never get old.

Sunset Boulevard is an original and entertaining story, a film noir based on some proximate parallels in the subculture of Hollywood celebrity.The actual story involves an aspiring writer on the lamb who without prior notice drops in on an aging leading actress of some renown.Her name is Norma Desmond and she is cared for by her butler who is also her ex-husband and former director Max (von Stroheim). He is her big believer and he is cognizant that his place is by her side within the archaic LA mansion.Norma proves to be a meticulous and neurotic handful as she attempts to resurrect her life of royal splendour using the much younger Joe Gillis as her new love, or future husband.Joe gets cold feet and arranges for secret nights out away with friends.Norma becomes suicidal with envy and deteriorates into a shivering bowl of jelly.In Sunset Boulevard, Norma Desmond at last judges Joe Gillis when she pulls a loaded handgun against his fleeting escape. She shoots and kills him in the back when there only can be her.Upon Max calling out by telephone an old well-oiled machine is re-engaged.'It's the famous Norma Desmond, now we can start making money!' (paraphrased)A final riddle is devised:Who else could anyone prefer to be?

from the start an absorbing and fascinating movie.  at the end, a vivid, satisfying and thought-provoking great movie.  don't even have to go into the performances -- masterful in every way.   Memorable even months after seeing it.

It's usually refreshing to watch a film that, even with the sheer amount of praise and recognition it gets, still delivers on all fronts. Sunset Boulevard is one of these movies; it has a great balance of not only being significant with its commentary on old Hollywood, but also being entertaining. There are many parts to this movie that contributes to its joy factor, my favorites are how dark this film turns out to be along with its character performances.Many classic films that I know of have a predisposition to be slightly comical and lighthearted, primarily because of the "overacting" and probably just due to how people looked at film back in the day. Sunset Boulevard is dark; drama is not merely a tool for storytelling or showcasing of talent and personal relationships are not touched on the same way modern drama films usually do so. The character archetypes are developed throughout the film are done in away that makes all the mystery and suspense so easy to become invested in. This is where my other favorite part of the film comes in: the actors/characters.Dramatic acting in old films is always so fun to watch. It's a craft that seems to have influenced a large part of acting seen in modern films but also can't be replicated due to their novelty. In Sunset Boulevard, the talent frontline consists of actors William Holden and Gloria Swanson. It's so easy to become enraptured by the performances these two give; Swanson's dramatic overacting is so entertainingly outlandish but also gathers meaning over time and Holden really knows how to portray emotions without verbalizing them while also giving some great little monologues here and there.Sunset Boulevard has been called "a movie about movies" with its commentary on the perceptions and misconceptions of Hollywood back then. Billy Wilder, the director of this film, came under a bit of fire for going this direction with this story. I think I can relate to most fans when I say that his efforts in portraying Hollywood and the film industry as a whole in such a different light has gained my utmost respect and gratitude, as I also found this film to be a very enjoyable experience.

Sunset Boulevard is one of the few movies that diehard silent movie fans will watch over and over because it rides very close to the border of reality. How many great silent actresses became forgotten as they aged? And actors too, for that matter? A couple of silent screen superstars were asked if they wanted the role of Norma Desmond before Gloria Swanson snatched it up, but none were as good actresses to fit Norma's mad and wild personality. The film was shot in black and white in an era where Technicolor was taking over, but such a movie wouldn't be the same in color. Color is so bright and cheery, and Sunset Boulevard is a dark, even slightly frightening story.The story is as follows: down-and-out screenwriter Joe Gillis (William Holden) can't pay up debt on his car, so he hides it in a garage. The garage turns out to be part of an elephantine mansion belonging to aging silent screen star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson). She wants him to work on a long and tedious script she's been working on for her screen "return." But when her beloved Paramount studios calls her up, they don't want her to be in one of their movies-they want to rent her car for a few weeks for a movie. And when Norma finds that out, the insanity is indescribable. The mentions of real-life silent stars makes you shiver: Wallace Reid, Pearl White, Mabel Normand, John Gilbert, Rudolph Valentino, Vilma Banky, Rod la Rocque. It makes you think how far 1950 really is from 1929 and the years prior to it. Everyone should see this film, especially fans of silent movies. Also to anyone who wants to return to a job when you want them to stay home.

reviews.review_title: A simple story about a pool guy.
reviews.content: Quite simply, one of the sharpest screenplays ever written and luckily it has performances to match.ASome people have points they argue about this movie. Why did Joe stick around for so long ? He was a shallow guy, he wanted the meal ticket that he was being offered and, yes, despite his disgust at the offerings he always ended up taking them. Why did he end up back with Norma on that fateful night after her suicide attempt ? Because he was too scared, he didn't want to feel responsible for anyone else's pain. If he'd never actually heard of Norma's fate then he would have been long gone but once it was relayed to him, and still with the fresh memory of the part he played, then he had to make sure that he hadn't done any long-term damage. Joe enjoyed making a buck but he wasn't a completely uncaring man.As for Norma Desmond herself, she may well be the single greatest human character ever to be thrown onto celluloid. Half Quasimodo, half Bride Of Frankenstein and . . . . . . ummmm . . . . half Dracula's Daughter. Gloria Swanson bravely plays the faded movie star with a perfect mix of sadness, fiery anger, intense narcissism and pride, all mixed up with some mild overacting and permanent melodrama.William Holden is the coolest narrator ever and his character, although often unlikeable, just about keeps us onside for the duration of the movie. Even if writer/director Billy Wilder doesn't manage to keep our sympathies with the right character for most of the movie he produces some scenes in the second half that give Holden's character a twisted redemption and reason to finally make a completely clean breast of things.Max, the butler, IS the avid fan taken to the extreme. Devoted, adoring, ever-present, he's the perfect audience member and just what Norma Desmond needs to keep her sanity for as long as she does. Does he actually help her or is he ultimately responsible for her fall over the edge ? Max or Joe, who is the bigger culprit ? An interesting question that I'm not sure I could easily answer.Of course, many other people also help to keep Norma from the truth. Cecil B DeMille, her card-playing buddies, even security guards still working at the studio. If more people had reacted the same way as Joe did initially (dismissing Norma and prompting her reply of "I AM big, it's the pictures that got small") then maybe she would have eased back down to earth. If her ego and vanity would have EVER allowed it.The only real innocent character in the movie, the only one who doesn't help to perpetuate any fantasy and who doesn't act for purely personal gain, is Betty Schaffer. It is poor Betty who is quickly drawn in, chewed up and spat out by Holden's character (hmmmm . . . a writer responsible for breaking the heart of a young, up and coming lady . . . . surely not).I love this movie with all my being. I love the faded, preserved shrine that is Norma Desmond's house. The car and the swimming pool being returned to working order, just as Norma herself is, for the benefit of Joe. Are we watching Gloria Swanson playing Norma Desmond throughout this film or are we watching an older actress play every idol that we've ever discarded ? Is the movie disturbing because of the interplay of the characters or because we, as an audience, do not want to venture into this world of forgotten stars and empty theatres ? Am I reading too much into this film ? Maybe I am and maybe I don't care. Just see it and love it.

reviews.review_title: The Best movie I've ever seen, and I've seen them all!
reviews.content: Never has there been a movie made with more passion. It was just made in the wrong year (1950, or it would have won every Oscar and other award. (Too bad All About Eve) William Holden has never been more valiant and Gloria Swanson is beautifully cast as the aging actress. And has there been anyone as creepy as Erich Von Stroheim in a movie since? The answer is no! It is brilliant because it adds suspense, love, hate, allusion, and foreshadowing all together in less than two hours. I just wish that there were still movies made like this gem today. There are, of course, great movies still being made (Mostly by Scorsese and Eastwood), but this classic is will forever be one of the greatest ever filmed!

reviews.review_title: A movie within a movie directed by Max
reviews.content: "Madame" is still living in her movie which is also her own world. This hits he audience in the end of the movie in the creepiest way possible. However, until the audience gets to the end, they are given some clues to what kind of a woman this "Madame" is. She is a worn out star who is 50 and lives alone in a house which reminds us of Ms.Havisham from Charles Dickens' "Great Expectations". This bit of comparison is actually made by the narrator of the movie who is also one of the main characters, who is also Madame's platonic crush.The movie actually starts off with a death scene and then is narrated by the victim himself. Then goes back 6 months and is oddly narrated by the dead character. Joe is a writer in Hollywood who is after his Hollywood dream. However, he has realized that it is just a dream for him unlike Betty who is a script reader who has a passion for her job and later for Joe. They start working on a script together while Joe is in a complicated relationship with Madame. Things get tragic in the end because the movie ends in a traumatic way for Betty and Joe. Madame on the other hand, is just starting her own movie which Max is directing for her.This movie does the justice of putting a few smiles on the viewers face. In fact, in the end when you feel like you should be crying, you end up smiling because of the ridiculous feelings Madame and Max make you go through.So if you would like to see a fake movie within a real movie then this 1950s wonder is the right "picture" for you.

Beautiful black & white cinematography, character chemistry, and scripting. Interesting to see a relatively young Hollywood's cynical self reflection. Guest appearance by Buster Keaton is a treat. Would recommend.

The most enjoyable part of the film is the end of the film. After killing the male protagonist, the heroine who has entered a mad state thinks that her new film will be filmed, so she is exquisitely dressed, wearing a gorgeous dress, holding her head from the spiral stairs, slowly Walking slowly down, the reporters and policemen around the scene stopped at this moment, forgetting their duties, as if they were also captured by the heroine's courage, thinking that they were on the set, confusing time and space, and greeted The old but still charming, proud princess walked slowly down the escalator.At this time, the lens was converted into a subjective lens of a camera. The heroine in the lens was as charming as a demon, extending her skinny hands and spreading her five fingers, as if to put everything in her palm. The film ended here, leaving people with an unforgettable face. That is a face that is not to be forgotten. In fact, how small humans are in this world. Although most people want to leave traces on themselves, how many people are truly lucky to be remembered by history? Everything is just like a cloud, like a dream.

Sunset Blvd....one of the greatest films I have ever seen. It is definitely a shame that today's entertainment industry does not have the talent that such actresses as Gloria Swanson had. She was absolutely marvelous in the film, and it is exhilarating to watch. William Holden also plays a very interesting character, with some comical touches here and there. The film's plot and storyline is breathtaking, and is undoubtedly a great classic.

reviews.review_title: Gloria Swanson is indeed "the greatest star of all"
reviews.content:
An iconic film from the 1950s, that set the standard for film noirs. A dark, twisted and subtle film set in Hollywood.
Sunset Boulevard depicts a very refreshingly realistic view on Hollywood stars and the film industry. Although it is brutally honest, I fully appreciate that it brings the attention away from romanticizing Hollywood as it is often done in films we see today. This film successfully shows the point of view of a hustling screenplay writer and a forgotten actress.Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) is a mentally ill, somewhat self-obsessed, retired and tragically forgotten Hollywood actress with an eccentric personality that intrigues the audience throughout the whole film. Norma carried us through the whole film only showing very small parts of her madness. Right at the end, when the timing was right, she drew the audience in with a full-blown meltdown. This was possibly my favorite scene - grand and bold. The audience had been waiting for her to crack fully and when she did, I was absolutely satisfied with the performance. Nancy Olson was okay, but boring. I wanted to like her but she was so mind-numbingly nice and much too dependent on a man then necessary. Joe Gillis was perfect for the role of the screenplay writer. Seemingly, a put together man yet he makes some questionable decisions that kept me guessing.The plot of Sunset Boulevard initially seems relatively simple but throughout the film, Billy Wilder adds in some subtle yet drastic twists. Technically speaking, it was beautifully shot. The cinematography is something I rarely focus on but in Sunset Boulevard it was phenomenal. In the mansion, the use of shadows portrayed the grunge look. The lighting was subtle and created a depth when appropriate.

reviews.review_title: SEE THIS MOVIE ON THE BIG SCREEN!!!
reviews.content: I've seen this film over and over on tv and video.  Last week I got to see it on the big screen.  WOW!  GO, Drive miles and miles, walk if necessary, steal a car, whatever - any chance you have to see this film as intended TAKE IT!  I've always loved this film and thought it was brilliant - NOW I know it's truly a masterpiece!  Gloria Swanson's performance is unbelievable - just how DID Judy Holiday win that oscar?!?!?

There is too much to say about this film in just 10 lines, especially considering I did this for my breakdown. Since that focuses primarily on cinematography and sound, I will talk about plot and acting. Joe Gillis, played by William Holden, is our alienated main character who gets caught up in debt with his lenders. Joe finds reprieve from his debtors and his Hollywood apartment when he comes across a deserted mansion belonging to silent film star Norma Desmond, played by Gloria Swanson. Swanson's performance in a word is chilling. Her delivery is purposely melodramatic to play off of her silent film techniques and her outdated conception of films. Her career is essentially dead and Joe's arrival provides an opportunity for her revival. Norma is one of film noir's most famous femme fatales, considering her obsession with Joe causes her to shoot him in the end. In the aftermath, Norma's delusions about her resurgence in film causes her to think the reporters crowding her estate are cameramen filming a scene for a new film. Norma's delusional perceptions of her own reality lead to her own demise and Joe's faith in her delusions led to his demise. The wisest character is undoubtedly Max, Norma's servant who keeps her satisfied by fueling the delusions and preserving her delicate feelings. Overall, this is a must watch film for any movie lover. The cinematography is very precise and well executed and the use of sound is specific.

reviews.review_title: Film noir with a dash of dark humor
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard (1950), Billy Wilder, is a film about Joe Gillis (played by William Holden), a screenwriter hired to help re-write a fading film star's script in the hopes of re-igniting her career. Sunset Boulevard is a prime example of great writing, acting, cinematography, and editing come together to create a really entertaining film. The film is dark and melodramatic but also has some moments of dark comedy that I really appreciated. While I felt the pacing was a little slow at times this is definitely a must see film.

When I first viewed this film I did not know what to expect. It turned out to be a very ominous and dreary film. The acting isn't the best but the story makes up for that. I had seen many quotes from this film but didn't actually know it was from THIS film which was shocking but great. Overall it's decent.

reviews.review_title: Dangerously Daring Story about Losing Fame!
reviews.content: The story, the acting, and the lighting are all very well done in this film. It was unfortunate to see that Joe couldn't have a happy ending with Betty, but it is understandable what happens to him, ditching Norma, and going behind her back to meet with Betty to discuss and work on another script while Norma's was being put under consideration.But overall, this film is a very good look at not only the process of studios choosing which scripts are better, but also a very good look at what happens when an old-school actor/actress loses fame and tries to recover. I would recommend this film for anyone who is a fan of the actors/actresses in this film (such as Gloria Swanson, William Holden, Nancy Olson, and Buster Keaton just to name a few), and the overall story of showing an old star dive into insanity because of losing fame.

This movie had no dull moments. Norma Desmond keeps the movie going. The whole set up of the house and her dramatic behavior keeps you wondering what she will do next. My favorite scene is when she is looking at the sky after she shoots Joe and says "stars are ageless". Her strange demeanor after she is being interviewed about the murder is classic. Once she heard "cameras" she lit up. She was so bizarre, "What is the scence", "Where am I"? Oscar material! She was out of her mind and I loved it!! "Alright Mr. Demille I'm ready for my closeup".

reviews.review_title: Classic atmospheric daring story of being washed up, obsession and Hollywood of the 50s
reviews.content:
A dynamite surreal movie that got made within the usual traditional constraints of the Hollywood studio system. It's the story of a struggling screenwriter who by chance befriends an aging forgotten (and struggling) actress who is desperate for attention, a mate (and work) whilst living in almost complete isolation.
The visual atmosphere is dark, ambient and beautifully stale- incredible ...and the psychiatric narcissistic madness acted out by the main actress is fully believable. It's part mystery, part psychology a bit horror and full on art. It's full of iconic memorable lines as well. This is a must have classic dark film that is comfortably punishing to its main characters and an accurate depiction of what more than often eventually happens to those in the movie business. By the way, this is one of director David Lynch's (Mulholland drive, blue velvet, eraserhead) favourite films and has cited it as a major influence upon his work (I.e. sunset Blvd <==> Mulholland drive).

It was interesting how the ending was showed at the beginning of the film. The floating body of Joe, who was murdered by Norma. And the film goes on it shifts to the begging of the whole story narrated by Joe. As the story goes on its events are predictable and are anti-realistic. Making the movie "uncomfortable", Overall I think these movies are not "real movies" in my opinion. What I mean about that is they are not realistic, realistic as in it could happen in the real world. And those series of events would very unlikely happen in the real world.
