reviews.review_title: Sunset Blvd is a star of a film
reviews.content:
I normally do not write with spoilers but I figure that my review will get lost with the other reviews plus this a movie filmed in the 1950s so my exposure will be minimum. What I will do here is to write about the story and ask myself what did i enjoy it. Well let's start in the beginning where the police find the dead body in the pool. Like many other movies I've seen the voice over narration really pulls you right into the story. Not only that but the black and white makes it a gorgeous film to look at. So right in the beginning you know this is a well crafted story. 
 This is the oldest movie i seen that uses the technique of showing you the death of a character and later rewind back and show you how they got to that point. But it felt right for the movie.  Joe Gillis is a poor screenwriter trying to make into hollywood. He does not have the means to sustain his vehicle. They are people who are trying to repossess his vehicle and so he tries bypass them by hiding in what looks like in abandoned mansion. But soon we realize that is not a abandoned mansion but that gloria Swanson lives there, a old Hollywood actresses in the silent era who longs to work in cinema again but is no longer relevant to the new era. There Joe Gillis starts working on her script that is full of silent era technique and consider to be a bad script. While living there for free Gloria Swanson become attached and Seemingly falls in love with him joe Gillis. The problem is that Joe Gillis does not share same feeling and therefore start to feel trapped in the life. The dilemma: He then must make a decision to be with Swanson and her lavish life but deal with her delusional fame and her fall to grace as a Hollywood actress or escape with a young screenwriter who is young and pretty but has nothing to offer for a stable career. The movie pacing is excellent . first we start caring for joe because he is broke and needs money. Then later we get interested in the life of Gloria Swanson and little by little we figure out the possessive character she is. That adds more drama for Joe because we see how unhappy he really is. This add more drama when he decides to leave at night and see another women. Until the final showdown where gloria goes to the extreme to stop joe from leaving.  Norma Desmond acting as Gloria Swanson was outstanding and exquisite, she stole the show and is deserving of my full admiration. Her role as a fall to grace Hollywood star was believe and we pitied her from the moment we realize that paramount did not want her up until she kills Joe and we see her outbreak to insanity. The scenes were she is preparing herself for the comeback to Hollywood really did hurt my soul. And of course that ending. When she steps foot descending from her bedroom to her destiny as criminal. The lights were switched on, the cameras were rolling and she was in front of the camera for the very last time. The euphoria that she felt in being that Hollywood star.  Grade: A

This film was really good. It was interesting and showed the inside of the film industry. The movie had some great themes that showed through. It showed how everyone loved something but that love was impossible to achieve and if it does it doesn't last. It also showed dreams that are are difficult to achieve and tend to be unattainable. The movie was cynical, or maybe that's just the way I am perceiving it.The performance of Gloria Swanson was wonderful. She was convincing in her unstable frame of mind set on returning to the spotlight and stardom. She even makes a comment, "stars last forever"(or something like that). She wants to return to the spotlight and make a comeback and be loved. Probably best shown through her obsession of the young guy who she "held captive" and how she wouldn't let him leave her.Like all film noir, the movie was dark in plot as well as lighting. Our poor hero was sadly killed by his femme fatale who was not all there(mentally) in the beginning the movie. The film was well done with the narration and interesting in how the story was told from a dead guy and the events leading up to his death. The movie also had some good commentary towards the struggles of the film industry on all sides and gave a little insight into behind the scenes of that world for the audience. It was a good suspense filled film I suggest seeing.

It's worth a watch but nothing out of the ordinary, at the beginning you see the end and as you watch the film you keep thinking how did it end like that. It was interesting through out was not bored at all. What brings the film to life is Gloria Swanson who is a scary crazed woman she acts this beautifully. She brings the movie to life its worth watching only to see her. Not a bad film but nothing great, cannot give it more than 6. But throughout wondered if it would have been better in colour, there were so many scenes i am sure would have been better in colour.

This film encompasses the Noir style of filmmaking, the dark tones of the movie with the flashbacks and underlying mystery of it all just draws the viewer in. i would definitely recommend this movie to some one who is a fan of Noir style films and has not yet seen this one. the way that this film depicts the industry and how actors and actresses are portrayed in this film are years and years ahead of their time.

Let me start this review by saying that this is a good movie. The plot works on various levels with different interpretations and an actual focused theme. It's not just a love story, it's an honest Hollywood depiction, it's a meditation on fame and time. Good work there! The movie, though, presents some important flaws. Most relevant the off- voice, which was distracting at the beginning and honestly very on-the- nose sometimes, not centered in giving feedback or highlighting a concrete point, but rather there as a lazy job on the director's part. Swanson's performance (what an appropriate name!) is borderline unwatchable by the way.
While I'm not typically a fan of old movies, this movie was fantastic. It had lots of character development & kept me guessing the whole time.

Norma Desmend, played by Gloria Swanson did an amazing job at portraying a mentally imbalanced person who dreams of returning to her previous life as a silent movie star. Joe gills, played by William Holden seems to be disconnected to Norma in that he lives with her and pretends to be there to write a movie script in which she is the star. The themes in this movie are still relevant issues today and that's one of the reasons I believe that this movie is considered timeless. Norma still yearns for the attention that being a movie star brings. She is holding onto her past life and therefore cannot move forward in any other aspect of her being. The movie did make me laugh in parts, at times because of Norma's disillusionment however at the end I just felt sorry for her. Like many people in Hollywood today, their acting careers fizzle out at a certain age unless they reinvent themselves significantly. This often is the case with child stars that then turn to acquire psychological issues or addictions to drugs or alcohol. I also think it is quit sad that her butler and ex husband still lives with her because he loves her. It seems like in this each character is not living but existing in their life. I think it would add a greater dimension to the film if the audience knew a bit more about max as her ex husband and the history of them.

As a 17 year old female, I do  not normally watch black and white films, however Sunset Blvd. was on TV, so I decided to tune in.  I was not disappointed! In fact, it exceeded my greatest expectations by far.  It is so cool.  I found it to be fascinating.  The character of Norma Desmond is so kind of freaky it's interesting. (if that makes any sense) Good storyline, but the acting makes this film a classic.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful, dazing movie with a lot to say
reviews.content: This is a wonderful movie. I say this for a few reasons; the different characters you meet during your time watching each seem to have things to say about the state of Hollywood at the time. Although some of the commentary could carry over into criticisms of the same Hollywood today. I would even argue that some of the things the main actress expresses from the beginning to the end: could speak to some of the affects of Hollywood on child actors. One of the driving forces of this movie is the actions and behaviors of the former silent screen actress, that ultimately collide with the realities of the changing world. I feel this movie has a lot to say that you may not be able to catch with the first sitting alone. While it's not the kind of movie i'd recommend to relax to after a long day, it is an excellent one to watch. I promise an impression will be left on you after watching this; and some of the jokes are better understood if you have seen your share of older and a few silent films. Highly recommend.

reviews.review_title: An Interesting way to tell the story of a murder
reviews.content: I really enjoyed this film, it starts off with telling you that the protagonist is already dead. Then goes on to tell the story of the time leading up to his death when he stayed with an older famous actress from the silent era. The movie uses lots of narration so we get to hear what the main character is thinking constantly, this works really well as they use this in comedic ways constantly. It is ultimately a tragic story of an actress who is dying to make a comeback after 20 plus years away from the film industry. The story was so engaging i honestly forgot that the main character had been murdered in the beginning, so it really brought the story full circle when we see his downfall.

This film was very well done with every aspect, from cinematography to plot. Gloria Swanson's wide-eyed facial expressions held such intensity that you could feel the crazy as if it were right next to you. The way the film is shot intensifies this mood even more: black and white that emits a powerful, severe feeling. I found the narration to be extremely effective; I felt very involved in the story as an audience member. All of the characters' (Max, Norma, Joe especially) psychological struggles were very fascinating to follow as well. The complexity hiding beneath the surface in this film is captivating.The plot is also odd but relatable in a way; I found the movie to be very applicable.. Not only do some recent movies parallel Sunset Blvd. (like Black Swan), but we can also see ourselves in Norma. As everyone knows, it is incredibly difficult to give up a dream you have worked so hard for, and although this film takes it to the extreme, we are warned of the devastating effects of a close mind not willing to see the greater picture. This film definitely critiques the Hollywood facade and illustrates the real effects of such a pressure cooker.

The influence and everlasting effect of Sunset Boulevard is beyond doubt. A film made about a starlet from a dead era, but the movies she starred in hadn't even been cold in the ground yet! The bold, brash lines, and of course, the undeniably dynamic and purely iconic acting of Gloria Swanson. This is a film where the supposed main character, in this case Joe Gillis, is just a backdrop, a segue into the true protagonist and star of the show, Norma Desmond. The lighting to show mood and tone, the snappy and emotional dialogue. Not many movies like Sunset Boulevard are both a hit when they come out and a classic more than 50 years after, but this film nails it on the head.
I really enjoyed this movie for what it stood for and represents. Swanson does an amazing job portraying a woman with personal issues. A timeless movie in my opinion.

This is a movie that shattered the pure image of classic Hollywood. It takes on the fact of their ideal image of beauty and the effect on women when they no longer fit that standard. The film follows a start that has fallen from her golden thrown and her deep seated struggles when all she has ever known is gone. To further complicate this there is of course relationship drama. This is a great movie to start off the 1950's and encompasses a classic film noir.

The acting in this film was incredible. I like the fact the introduction included the death of a monkey but never referenced him at any other point in the film. At least, not that I can remember. I also appreciated the social commentary the film made about the pressures of staying relevant in the entertainment industry as well as, the internal aspects of moving up the ladder (so to speak) in Hollywood. It depicted the intensity and desperation of Hollywood so dramatically that it almost made it seem hyper realistic. It also had a very good balance of plot twists.

I knew this was a classic movie, hearing of it many times over the years. Totally not what I expected! The writing in this movie so good that it really had me wondering through most of the movie, what exactly was going on. Although from the beginning you know something is off, you can't really put your finger on it. The ending was a complete surprise to me, including the last line, "All right, Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my close-up." Huge iconic quote and I had no idea it was from this movie. The lighting was amazing and was more fun than usual in this movie because of the content. The audience could see some of the lighting being used to "film". The same for the camera usage, more interesting than usual because of the content of the film. There were some great shots throughout the movie that totally made me know this was one of the great film noir's made at that time!

I can't believe I watched that entire movie just so I could hear Gloria Swanson's famous, and often misquoted line 'Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my closeup'. Horrible 'over' acting and I can do without the narrating throughout the movie. I liked it better when it was called 'Whatever Happened to Baby Jane'.

Sunset Boulevard is a movie about a screenwriter, who works with an silent movie actress on a script for a new movie, because the actress want again the old days, her fame and feeling of being star back.Sunset Boulevard is a brilliant story. And a couple of very interesting scenes. As a viewer I asked always myself what I would do , when I would be in the role of the screenwriter Joe Gilles.But at a interesting point around the end of the movie is where Betty Scheafer asks the screenwriter Joe to leave the silent movie actress Norma Desmond and to go with her, but Joe stays and so story becomes from a peaceful end (if he would go with Betty) to a very cruel and , when don't play attention to first movie scene, choking end, but I think the movie would be less interesting when it would end with the leaving of Joe with Betty . So I asked me too when Joe Gilles was so annoyed by Norma Desmond, why did he not just leave, why did he stay at this house with her so long, these are parts of the movie, which give the viewer really to think about it

This film is certainly a Noir film, but you won't find any gangsters here, no main grizzled detective to follow through a dark alleyway in a crime-riddled city, only a star, past her prime, incapable of living with the thought of having fallen from stardom, and a man, a poor writer who can't help but watch.

This film is a fascinating character study, a classic example of what happens when a delusional actress comes to believe her own publicity. The picture is well-written, superbly cast and acted, and moves at an excellent pace, with no unnecessary scenes.
The backstory of this film is almost as fascinating as the picture itself, and is the subject of a book, available from amazon. The male lead was originally offered to Montgomery Clift, who turned it down - some say because of his involvement with middle-aged torch singer Libby Holman, who told him to reject the script. Perhaps it was just too close to home. (The life of Libby Holman would itself make a fascinating film)
According to rumor the picture was actually based on the life of Corinne Griffith, one of the most beautiful women in silent pictures, who was also a real estate expert. When Norma Desmond states "I own three blocks downtown," that was Corinne speaking - she did own three blocks in Beverly Hills.
Wilder and Brackett had been working on the script for some years when it finally jelled. The picture contains some famous lines that have become part of our folklore, such as "I'm ready for my closeup." I would recommend it to any student of the cinema, or anyone who is just a movie fan.

I've been watching The Last Drive In with Joe Bob Briggs on Shudder. He did an episode where he talked about the negative stigmatism calling your film a horror film. Horror, according to critics at that time, meant cheap and low brow.I watched this movie for the first time last night. I am now mad at myself for neglecting this movie for so many years. I woke up still thinking about this movie. This is a good movie.This is drama.This is suspense.This is horror!Prove me wrong.Side note: Is this the mansion during the shoot out at the end of Beverly Hills Cop?

With all those annoying superheroes flicks being released on a daily basis, I have decided to explore some classic material. Arbitrarily, I decided exploring the 50's. So far, I am loving it. So many cool stories and talented actors. I am glad to have decided doing it. My favorite one so far has been Bette Davis' "All About Eve". Such a cool movie in many ways. About Sunset Blvd, i was also very pleased. However, I honestly expected more from it. It's not that It didn't live up to my expectations. Acting was nice, in general. Plot a little predictable, but well constructed. I think my problem was that maybe i just didn't like Mister Holden that much. I just didn't find him charismatic enough. Anyway, it was a cool movie, but definitely not an 8.5 (maybe a solid 7).

At the time, Sunset Blvd. was one the movies that explored the underworld of Hollywood and its true face. It follows a struggling screenwriter and ends up in the hands of Norma Desmond, the classic femme fatale of film-noir. This movie takes a lot of risks and that's what makes it a very good movie. Many romance movies eventually end with the main guy getting the girl and they walk off the sunset. But this movie does not do that, it is very dark and it had to be work. The way it shows Hollywood as a dark place, especially during this time, by using actor or actress for a long time and then they just throw them away like an antique. It also shows that people who work in Hollywood aren't perfect people, everyone looks up to Hollywood like its a glamorous place, but the main character is trying to get away from paying his car bills and then, he also seduces a female screenwriter after she says that she is engaged. If the movie had ended with him going with Betty in the end, it would have gone against the purpose of the movie, and probably not make it a film milestone that it is today.

reviews.review_title: Got a little boring, not a happy story
reviews.content: I had a hard time getting into this movie. I thought the story was interesting though and how it was all narrated by the main character, telling his own story after he had died. I was able to watch the beginning fine, but during the middle it got a little boring and dragged. It was also predictable because the end of the movie was already explained in the beginning of the movie, it wasn't hard to put the pieces together. All in all, it was a sad story and I don;t think there was even one happy part. :(

I couldn't stand her. I've never saw her in a movie before, but was that all of Gloria Swanson's mannerisms in real life? Bug-eyed, hateful, and horrifying?How could anybody ever find her attractive, even Joseph Kennedy? And I don't mean the fictional Norma Desmond - I mean, Gloria Swanson, the supposedly late great movie star. Was she truly as ugly in person as in the movie?At this point, I wish I could see how Glen Close portrayed Norma Desmond in the musical version. I bet she portrayed her as human - cruel, bombastic, etc., but human. Unlike this Gloria Swanson who was as ugly as the beast Desmond had to bury in a funeral ceremony early on in the story.Every word Swanson uttered was an emotional declamation. I bet if she had had a line that says, "I am going to brush my teeth," it would sound like a warning on the end of the world. Overacting was hardly sufficient to describe her performance. She should have been told that movie goers even in her time were not as dumb as to beat them with her theatricals over the head.Or maybe the trouble was not Swanson herself, but the character Norma Desmond, as disgustingly written by Billy Wilder and Charles Brackett. If there were any feminists worth their salt out there, it was this denigrating stereotype of cougars and would-be cougars both in the movies and in real life that they ought to protest against.It was the predatory Vivien Leigh's Blanche DuBois, all over again. In A Streetcar Named Desire, DuBois, without regard for her sister Stella's feelings, shamelessly flirted with her younger brother-in-law Stanley Kowalski, played by Marlon Brando, ultimately accusing him of rape.It was, again, the cringy older Anna Magnani's sex-starved and woebegone Lady Torrance in The Fugitive Kind, allowing herself to get pregnant to hold hostage her boy-toy Val, also played by Brando.It was the suicidal Mrs. Stone (Vivien Leigh again!) in The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone, dangerously tossing her apartment's keys to an anonymous stalker, after her boy-toy Paolo (played by Brando wannabe, Warren Beatty) insulted and abandoned her.There are many pathetic examples of cougars in real life, especially among celebrities with descriptions both libelous and barf-inducing, but let me give just one example, the very classless way the young Brando in his autobiography, denigrated the elderly Talulah Bankhead, his co-star in the stage play, "The Eagle Has Two Heads:""Whenever I was onstage with her and the moment approached when I was supposed to kiss her, I couldn't bear it... Her tongue would explore every cranny in my mouth before forcing itself down my throat... I tried eating a lot of garlic, but that didn't stop her, so I asked a stagehand to buy me a bottle of mouthwash, and after each time I had to kiss her, I went offstage and took a swig, but that didn't work either, so I bought a very strong astringent lotion and began gargling with it in the wings after every kiss."Was there ever an older woman-younger man relationship in a play or movie, where the cougar was held in high esteem? Yes, there was. It was Jane Wyman in Magnificent Obsession, with a difference: Rock Hudson was no boy-toy in the movie. He was an honest and ardent younger lover who tried and succeeded on improving himself to be worthy of her love. Wish there were more of that kind of May-December where the woman was the May; if not, at least, the conventional desperate romance between an older woman and a younger man with its share of tenderness and pain, that would not scandalize.Unfortunately, it was not so with Gloria Swanson and William Holden in Sunset Blvd. For one thing, William Holden was a bit too old to be a boy-toy. For another, Swanson just seemed to be the most horrid, most despicable and a more frightful cougar than the examples mentioned above.But how could she have done better? Apparently, that was how the misogynists Billy Wilder and Charles Brackett wrote Norma Desmond. No wonder quite a number of the old silent movie stars declined the part. They felt insulted by the role.According to Wikipedia, Wilder first considered Mae West and Marlon Brando for the leads, but West rejected the offer out-right. West portrayed herself as a sex symbol through her senior years and was offended that she should be asked to play a Hollywood has-been.Greta Garbo and Clara Bow were not interested. Norma Shearer found the script distasteful. Wilder and Brackett then visited Mary Pickford, but before even discussing the plot with her, Wilder realized she would consider a role involving an affair with a man half her age an insult, so they departed.Way to go, late classy ladies!Why four stars? Because everything else in the movie, except the Desmond character, was perfect. The innovative point of view of a dead man telling his story with occasional biting humor; the awesome cinematography and clever use of light and dark, the music score, the story development, the locations and props, the interactions of the supporting cast and fascinating cameos of actual old stars and directors were tops.Furthermore, the handsome William Holden was at his greatest.

Watching this 1950s film was actually interesting acting so dramatic including the female who acts as if she is nothing without her husband. There was a very common scene where a character falls into the pool. This film/movie gives a realistic view on how a Hollywood movie is done. One scene sort of gives the audience a crisp view of Norma Desmond face as the camera lens zooms in giving a three dimensional view. The lighting within the film was pretty blurry yet gave a Film noir appealing look to it where the female is edgy, seducing, and don't go along with it.

This extremely dramatic film noir was surprisingly a movie that I liked. Although at first glance, I admit I assumed it to be over the top or annoying perhaps but I was wrong, Gloria Swanson (famous silent film actress) stepped out of her silent film career to play this more well known role of her career. Surprisingly enough, this film is about Hollywood in the 1950's. William Hollden is a somewhat struggling film writer who ends up meeting Norma (Swanson). The pair make for a humorous yet strange pair throughout the entire film. The black and white film itself creates for an even more intense and certainly dramatic mood, it especially helps to atmosphere of the movie when scenes take place in Norma's gloomy old mansion. Narration throughout the film is in first person from Holden's point of view. The entire thing is a sort of- flashback, as most noirs are. Camera tricks such as fading in and out are used quite often in the film to add to dramatic effect as well. Of course the ending was my favorite part where Norma stares blankly at the screen and says " Mr. DeVille- i'm ready for my close up." I really liked this film a lot. It was visually and emotionally enticing.

This movie starts with a case of murder in a mansion located in Sunset Boulevard. The victim, Joe Gillis was an unsuccessful playwright. He was hired by a descended great actress, Norma Desmond and lived with Norma and her butler, Max. Joe begins to tell everything of this tragedyAt that time of this movie, the movies changed from silents to voiced. Norma could not adapt the change and she dreams to return to the brilliant show business, believing that she is still a beautiful movie star. In the story, Norma and her old friends who were succeeded in movies play cards in her mansion. One of her friends is Buster Keaton who was an actor in silent films. I like his film originally. Including Keaton, their appearances and expressions are very sorrowful and Joe thinks that they are as if wax dolls. I can't stop feeling the rise and fall of life. In this movie, the character of Max produces a mysterious atmosphere. I was really surprised at the reason why he serves Norma
Very good movie in many ways. The acting is so well done for the time it was made. Has a little bit for everyone. Witty, dark, comical, and for those who really appreciate cinematography.

Billy Wilder's film Sunset Boulevard, keeps you on your toes throughout the whole movie because there are so many twists and turns you do not expect. The plot is really interesting because you see the inside of how a film is made, but also the underlying love story that goes changes throughout. The way Joe gets pulled into somewhere he thought he wanted to be, but realizes he needs to get out and write his films. The whole plot is well developed, as well as the movie itself is well made. Very intriguing movie and I would definitely recommend it.

Just from looking at the cover of the tape, I could tell this movie would be slow.  It is almost 2 hours long and I don't understand how people who call this their favorite movie actually sit through it.  I'll agree that the begining was interesting and I liked the ending but don't tell me that the whole ending wasn't predictable.  I knew exactly how it would end with half an hour left.  Although G. Swanson was perfect at her part, just her performance didn't make it a good movie.  Somebody please help me out and tell me why all of these old movies are so highly praised when I can only pick out a handful that were actually good.Overall Rating: 5/10

Although I found the plot and lines of Sunset Blvd. to move very slowly, I can't help but to admit how well the film aged. It tells the story it portrays in a creepy, gruesome manner which makes it that much more engaging. Honestly, if Joe left with Betty, I think I would've been slightly more satisfied with the ending even if it is cliche. The happier endings may be less exciting and interesting, but happier endings are better for peace of mind. That being said, I did enjoy the shock of the ending. They showed Norma's true psychotic break when she shot Joe and was still on about being a star. I also really enjoyed Joe narrating the whole thing even after he was dead, because I often wonder about the characters and what they think after their death. Overall great movie, just a little too slow-paced for me.

reviews.review_title: A Movie That Makes You Feel for The Characters
reviews.content:
This movie has aged very well. The plot was strong and the mood the characters gave off really made you feel for them and want them to succeed. Joe, specifically, made you root for him throughout the movie. After his first encounter with Norma you realized that she would trap him and he would be unable to escape the toxic realationship. After he met Betty, you really wanted them to run off together and for Joe to escape his problems at home with Norma. In the end, Joe is shot by Norma and it was his own fault. He had the opportunity to leave and he missed it. He allowed his feeling to overtake his mind and he was unable to think properly because he was trying to do what was best for Norma.
The mood of the movie would have concluded happy had Joe left with Betty when he had the chance. Staying to help Norma changed how you felt about Joe and gave the film a dark mood.

This movie was pulling you in right from the start. Although it was tough at times to follow all the dialogue being thrown at you the acting in it was superb. It wasn't a cliche film with a happy ending but it the film drew you in right from the start knowing it was going to end badly. The film was gripping from start to finish. The characters were hard to really like other than Betty Schaefer but that was a huge pull in when Betty was pleading with Joe near the end of the film to come with her and drop the life he had with Norma. You want him to go so badly just for you to be let down knowing what is coming right from the start of the film. This movie despite being older has kept it's kick.

reviews.review_title: One of the finest noirs ever made
reviews.content: I don't have to talk about Sunset Boulevard as the film is highly rated as it is. This is a great noir film, brilliantly lit and acted. The premise is simple: A Hollywood screenwriter chances upon an aging actress who orders him to rework a screenplay. He is relocated to her mansion- which is as much as a character as she is, and soon he realizes that not only is he trapped, but that the mysterious aging actress is a loose nut. Billy Wilder's film was a massive success upon release and its reputation has only grown since. William Holden is well cast as the tragic young scriptwriter and Gloria Swanson is magical as the elusive silent screen siren. This is dark comedy of the highest order.

Sunset Blvd. is a story about an unsuccessful film writer who by chance meets a has been movie star of the silent film era, but after this, things only get more twisted. You could say this film was the beginning of a much darker time for film, and the first time people on the the audience could see that Hollywood was not all good and shiny as they had thought before. While this film might seem exaggerated in the character of Norma Desmond, who becomes literally mad with the idea of her past fame, there is truth in her character. Fame and money are funny things, while they make one seem powerful and beloved, these are the same things that can really bring out the worst in people, as we see in Sunset Blvd.The acting throughout the film is especially superb, I was really impressed with Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond. I feel like her character would be such a hard one to play, but from the way she spoke to her gestures, I really believed she was a narcissistic actress who was indeed mad. William Holden (Joe Gillis) was also perfect for his role, as he plays a man who really hasn't had much success in following his dream, but he tries nonetheless. His character has a good amount of humour for a not so light film, and the way he acts tells us that he really is a good person. Betty Schaefer, played by Nancy Olson I think is the impersonation of innocence, naiveness and goodness in an industry where those characteristics are rarely seen. She helps lighten the film and gives us hope that Joe can come out of the situation he has found himself in with Norma Desmond.This was one of the first, if not the first to use a non-linear storyline in a film, and it fits perfectly. The technicalities of this beginning sequence are also amazing, as they didn't use an underwater to film the body, instead they used a mirror to reflect, and that's how we see Joe's body. It was also shot in such a way that it was not really revealed this was Joe until the very end. This would later set the stage for other films, especially with a dark theme to use this form of storytelling; some of these are Pulp Fiction, Fight Club and 12 Monkeys.I really enjoyed this film, overall everything was great, and it was a really creative story that showed a darker side of something that people had generally thought was all fun and good. The way Cecil B. DeMille plays Norma's butler, and how he has "protected her from the world" by allowing for her to think that she is still relevant was simply great. The last bit of the film was perfect. Joe believes he is tainted, instead of leaving with Betty as he should have he prefers to let her go to spare her from himself in a way. Norma believed herself so great that she couldn't allow for her to be rejected, so in her rage and jealousy she killed Joe, fully bringing her down through the final steps of madness. I think that the way her butler brought a camera crew for her at the end was a mercy for her that she truly didn't deserve. This movie is a film because it shows what a self centred way of living and fame can do to people and that sometimes things that seem very good, are most likely flawed in a way inside.

reviews.review_title: The Best Movie of the Best Movie's Director of all time!
reviews.content: Forget "Citizen Kane"! Forget "Casablanca"! Forget "The Godfathers"! Forget all the John Ford's westerns! Besides, forget all that theory-of-montage-invented-by-Eisenstein stuff. The true genius of cinema has a name: BILLY WILDER. And "Sunset Boulevard" is his best film. Not of him, in fact, but of all time. It's a disgrace that he has lost the Academy Award for "All About Eve" - another great movie - but this became another of the countless injustices of the Oscar's history. There is not any other movie director that can show a filmopgrafhy as the one Billy Wilder. The 40's and specially the 50's was a example of masterpieces, one after another. Of course, I admit that he didn't maintain the same level after this time. "The Apartment" was its last great movie, in spite of him to have made great works after this, as the overlooked "The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes" and "Fedora" - almost a "Sunset Boulevard" re-make. But "Sunset Boulevard", reviews today, it stays with its qualities, witty, intelligence, cynicism. It's the screenplay - perhaps Casablanca also deserves this honor - it is that possesses more brilliant sentences, that until today we know by heart. It's my film number one, in any list of best movies of all the times!

I think there is only one word to describe this film; Phenomenal. Sunset Boulevard paved the way for film making and storytelling today. Most definitely a film, (more specifically a film noir) it's dark narratives and 'rounded' story were what brought it to life. I was instantly drawn in by it's classic intro. The unexpected plot was a great refresher and the twist ending was a really smart addition to the narrative.I could honestly write this whole review about Gloria Swanson's performance. She managed to capture a failing artist's final grasp for stardom perfectly. This is because she was one herself. She didn't need to act so much as project. This is what I was most impressed by in Sunset; she chose this over many other roles and offers as her comeback. She found Norma Desmond a captivating character with tons of potential. And although the other acting was equally incredible, Gloria was simply the standout.Something I noticed in this film was that there was no true protagonist. Norma was flawed and toxic, manipulating Joe and everyone she met. She was trapped in the past, unable to forget how forgotten she was. Strangely, Joe was quite similar to Ms. Desmond. He only cared about his work and that he wasn't able to get any. He resented Norma for ruining him, when he had many opportunities to leave. Even in the end when Betty offered to forget everything and run away with him, he refused only to complain about it later. Because if this, he later met his demise, bringing Norma with him. I found myself unsure of who to root for, hating both Joe and Norma's actions throughout. Their chemistry was scarces and their failure in life was brought forward by the other.Sunset Boulevard was a jumping off point for films today, i.e Brick and Pulp Fiction. They are able to address dark topics and mimic the shots and cuts of the classics. Pulp Fiction mimics angles and takes influence from film noirs like Kiss Me Deadly. Primarily, they use the 'rounded' story to give their films an edge. They start with the end, before returning to the beginning to show you how we get to that point. This is able to capture your attention while confusing and drawing audiences in.
Sunset was the perfect starting point. They were able to convince us that the man dead in the pool had nothing to do with our main character, Joe. But as we continue, we learn that this man is in fact Joe. It's a smart way to shock your viewers and compel them. Overall, an intriguing film that delves into Hollywood's effect on their craftsmen, how desperate some are for stardom and how long and hard the fall from the top really is.

Foe my "History of American Cinema" class, I had to watch a movie under the genre of film noir. The movie I chose to watch was, "Sunset Blvd.," directed by Bill Wilder and released to the public in 1950. Film noir movies have an overall mood of pessimism, fatalism, or menace. I think this film had a strong mood of pessimism. This film had a very cynical view of Hollywood(especially during the 1950's), the plot line's message was how Hollywood makes people famous, then dumps them when they are no longer needed. The script is very clean, clever, and witty. There were a variety of camera angels, with clean transitions. I also enjoyed the element of romance throughout the film. The actors really embraced their characters and brought the script to life and made you feel emotional throughout the movie, because it seemed so realistic, and like these were real people going through hard times. The movie was shot beautifully in black and white, and gave off a very gloomy vibe. I really enjoyed this film and think it deserves all the success, because it is an interesting movie and makes you feel emotional involved. I recommend this movie to someone would wants to see a Hollywood film noir classic.
A masterpiece is the only word I could use to describe one of my favourite films of all time.

Sunset Blvd. is the gloomy tale of failing screenwriter Joe Gillis (William Holden). Right from the beginning you know his story is doomed to end in tragedy when we see his body lifelessly floating in a pool. It sets the tone for darker things to come, we are following around a dead man.Joe Gillis, an aspiring screenwriter with a couple of features to his name, can't seem to catch a break. He has no money, no one can give him a job and even his agent leaves him. Whilst on the run from creditors he ends up at, what looks like, a deserted mansion. To our shock we learn the mansion is actually inhabited by forgotten silent moviestar Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) and her loyal servant Max (Erich von Stroheim). Norma, clearly insane, can't accept the fact that she has faded away and spents her time in the illusion that she is still the biggest star of them all. Joe becomes entangled in her fantasy and agrees to help rewrite Norma's story, for which she has high hopes of sparking her glorious comeback.Gloria Swanson sparkles in one of the best acting performances of all time. Always on the brink of mental breakdown, never truly reaching it until the end.
Joe, who finally has enough of her drifts of melancholy and insanity, desides to leave her. Him leaving her puts her over the edge. "No one ever leaves a star." Norma says "Thats what makes one a star.", and both Joe and the viewer know she has now completely lost touch with reality. In one of the most memorable endings in cinematic history we see Norma descends down the staircase. It is as if she is reaching out to the audience in one last attempt of regaining her glory. "You see this is my life, it always will be! There's nothing else, just us and the cameras, and those wonderful people out there in the dark."Billy Wilder masterfully directs the movie, combining satire and tragedy to create the ultimate Hollywood horror story. A case study of what fame can do to people and the coldness of Hollywood. It shows us the illusions that come with stardom even though we are supposed to see through them.

reviews.review_title: A film to strangle the genre
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard set the style for epic Film-Noir movies everywhere. It inspired graphic novel writer/artist Frank Miller the creator of Sin City. It inspired the writing and screenplays of Christopher and Jonathan Nolan the brothers behind the movies The Prestiege, Memento, Batman Begins and the Following. It inspired most of the film-noir/ comic book crime genre that has evolved from it. This movie was the beginning of a beautiful friendship.It was a great story told threw the narration of Joe Gillis as William Holden whom was the main star of the film. It was basically him a washed up B screenwriter trying to make some money running into a famous actress who decides to give him a job Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond. In end it develops a chain of events that makes Norma obsessed over William.Nothing really surprising about the film everything could be well predicted its just the dialog and acting that would flow to that point would tie you up to your seat handcuff your hands to the back and open up your eyes with clips Clockwork Orange style. It was a amazing film for semi-dark/mystery lovers who don't care for twists but rather just have a nice flowing plot with a satisfiable ending.The ending was decent but since you knew what was going to happen from the start of the movie it took away from it a tad. It was still a bit surprising however to the turn of events afterward but the lunacy of the acting from Gloria Swanson at the end took away from the flick in my opinion. Some may argue it was perfect others may say it was terrible, it was really a love it or hate it scene that I believe could have been done better. I just believe that she had better moments threw out the film.It was definitely a classic tale with near perfect dialog that inspired some of our industry greats. In end if your even remotely interested in the genre of Film-noir then don't keep strangling yourself with garbage and watch this film.

reviews.review_title: Ground breaking movie for the 50's era
reviews.content: That was a great surprise ; often old movies fails to impress me, but this one was so well done that I didn't mind it was 68 years old and I just had a great time watching it... The photography was sublime and the scenes weren't too long, they somehow managed to do a good editing job, so ahead of his time. People lost that class some humans used to have back in the fifties, I don't know how to explain.... maybe it's just the way they all stand up so d*mn straight....A big Kudo for Swanson, which delivered an oscar worthy performance. She was better than both Crawford and Davis in Baby Jane, her silent movie skills shown every single emotions it needed to, in the most perfect way, it gaves me shiver and she is no milf... as a matter of fact I'd rather go with the Butler and the Boy Toy.... at the same time.... but this isn't the place to talk about it.... The fact that a woman was taking the patriarcal role in the relationship by providing the ressources must have been groundbreaking for 1950, but anyways. The end could have been a bit better in my liking, and the cheezy love side-story with the young lady made me cringe. But overall i rate it 91,5%

When this film was made the idea that there was something nasty behind the glitz of Hollywood was new and shocking.These days this is not news. There have been dozens of films that have mined the same territory.Unfortunately when you take away the premise, you are left with two lead actors who do their best but don't have any chemistry. And I don't mean erotic chemistry necessarily, I mean emotional chemistry.Swanson plays a woman with delusions of grandeur, something again that's been done many times since. Delusions aren't interesting by themselves. You need to bring out the deep humanity so that we can be in her shoes.The dialog is nondescript. The supporting actors are competent but one-dimensional. Eric von Stroheim's sour-faced butler is a case in point. Here is a character that has just one facial expression through the entire film.The story arc of the main character isn't well developed. We are shown at the end, that Joe has decided to leave Norma. The decision was made inside his own head and handed to the audience cold. We don't see why he made this choice. We can certainly figure it out after the fact, but that isn't as engaging as knowing the character so well that we have a deep understanding even as he makes that critical decision.

Sunset Blvd. is, though it is not considered, a satire. It tells a story of madness and corruption that thoroughly describes the way Hollywood was back then. There are three things that make this film great: 1)The Story: the classic tale of a star that has faded into Hollywood obscurity and driven herself mad by obsessing over the glory days of her youth. She finds her way back into the spotlight when she meets a young screenwriter and she thinks she is cured but doesn't realize that she is slowly fading deeper into insanity.2)The Director: Billy Wilder's ingenious direction is what practically makes this film. His intricate eye to detail is one of the things that makes this film a success.3)The Stars: Gloria Swanson, William Holden, Nancy Olsen, and Eric von Stroheim are the people that make this film what is today: a classic. Gloria Swansons stunning performance as Norma Desmond truly deserved the recognition that it received. I think her performance is the greatest of all time and was totally robbed of the Oscar for Best Actress.All in all, this my favorite movie and it is one of greatest films ever made.(P.S. This so should've won Best Picture instead of All About Eve. I mean, All About Eve is a great film but not as great as this one.)

Billy Wilder is slowly becoming my favourite filmmaker ever. In what is arguably his greatest film, Sunset Boulevard takes on the dream machine that is Hollywood, and succeeds in providing a scathing, haunting and bleakly humorous film that will remain timeless, as long as films continue to exist.Bare witness to a simply stunning and equally disturbing performance from Gloria Swanson as film star Norma Desmond, whose fame and popularity faded into obscurity during the arrival of 'sound' films. William Holden plays struggling screenwriter Joe Gillis. Gillis, who seriously considers giving up Hollywood and returning to his hometown in Ohio, ends up in Desmond's fantasy world and its dangerous consequences.Wilder, who also co-wrote the film, slowly and meticulously deconstructs the Hollywood dream by creating detailed and developed characters, a whole historical background behind them and the famous locations of Tinseltown for the viewer to immerse themselves into. Beautifully directed, with a range of amazing visual shots, the world portrayed on screen gradually becomes more sinister as Norma Desmond's mental state goes from fantastical and theatrical to terrifying and dangerous.More than a film noir, more than a psychological drama, more than a bleak and bitter black comedy, Sunset Boulevard is rightly a highly placed work of art. Along with David Lynch's Mulholland Drive, this film continues to stun me with its savage analysis of a town obsessed with fame, fortune and immortality, and the darkness behind it all.

Sunset Boulevard excellently illuminates the excess of Hollywood in that era. Joe is a burnt-out, unemployed writer, while Norma is a fading star, still convinced she is a supernova. The characters self-destructive actions and exciting dialogue is enough to captivate the audience up until the bitter end.Joe's refusal to leave with Betty is the final setpiece that truly defies Hollywood tropes. I love this ending, even though I had dreaded it for the entirety of the film. Had he left with Betty, the ending would have felt empty and cliché, and I am happy with the direction the film took.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest noir films ever made
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's Sunset Blvd. is one of the better-known films from the golden age of cinema and one can see why. Featuring a fantastic screenplay, great pacing and some great performances this film is rightly considered a classic of film noir. William Holden plays an unsuccessful screenwriter who chances upon a mansion owned by silent screen siren Norma Desmond. It's about time that I watched this movie! It moved. And, considering that it was made over half a century ago, i would say that it worked wonderfully. The story, the dialogue, the acting, the production design and the direction were all superb. William Holden, whom I've seen in other roles (Network and The Wild Bunch) plays a writer who is sort of weary and is muted in his actions and reactions. What may seem to be wooden in his approach is actually a wonderful characterization of a weary, beaten writer by Mr. Holden. In contrast, Gloria Swanson plays a very theatrical aging movie star, "Nora Desmond." Actually a former silent film star who just can not let go of her past and her former popularity. She lives, almost as a recluse, in her mansion - a safety bubble of her old studio days.Desmond hires Holden's character to write a screenplay, so that she can make a major comeback. And he succumbs to her wishes, because he is down on his luck (and on the run from creditors).None of the great elements described would have worked without the absolutely wonderful direction by Billy WIlder. Mr. WIlder knows how to tell a story without letting "direction" or the camera get in the way, and he is wonderful with his actors. Mr. WIlder is helped greatly by a very fine screenplay by Charles Brackett, D. M. Marshman Jr and Wilder, himself.Special mention should be given to the art direction. And also to the solid cinematography (John F. Seitz).All around a great movie.

Sunset Boulevard is rightly considered by The American Film Institute to be one of the greatest films of all time. The story of an aging actress and a young struggling writer has timeless appeal. This movie should be noted for the importance of its various settings - Norma Desmond's house, the Hollywood film studios, the writer's office - which play a very important role in the story. The choice of narrator is a particularly innovative one and makes the plot even more compelling. The acting is superb; Gloria Swanson perfectly portrays Norma Desmond's increasing narcissism and vulnerability and the inclusion of various older Hollywood stars who play a bridge game with Norma was a nice reminder of the silent era.

I just want to clear up a misconception about Gloria Swanson and her performance as Norma Desmond. Gloria Swanson was NOTHING like Norma Desmond in real life. At the time she was offered the role, she was very busy (thank you very much) in New York with, among other things, pioneering early live television. She had a very busy family and social life, and wasn't that keen on returning to California and the silver screen. She was, however, very intrigued with the script, and was talked into it by Wilder. When she got to the coast and began to make contact with some of her old friends from the silent days, she was very disturbed and a little freaked out to discover that there were indeed many "Norma" cases hidden in the Bel Air hills. She was shocked to find many of her old acquaintances were stuck in the past, where as she had moved on and never looked back. She then actively sought out these people and began studying them, incorporating parts of each of them into her portrayal of Norma Desmond.A couple of interesting stories about the making of this movie are worth relating. In 1948, Billy Wilder and his collaborator, Charles Brackett were searching for story ideas. They were lunching at Chasens restaurant in Beverly Hills and Wilder noticed an aged, apparently "homeless" man hovering around C.B. Demille's table. Wilder observed DeMille motioning the old bum over and whispering something to him. The bum shuffled out. Intrigued, Wilder filed the incident away. Several days later he ran into De Mille on the Paramount lot and asked about it. "Oh yes, that was old Griffith asking for work again." Aghast, Wilder asked "Griffith WHO?" "D.W. Griffith" Demille simply replied, and walked away. It so shocked Wilder that such a titan of the film industry could become such a severe hasbeen, could have fallen so low. It gave him and Brackett the germ of the idea that eventually became "Sunset Blvd"-the true, unvarnished look at how Hollywood treats its "living legends".Another interesting story occurred at the films Hollywood première. It was, of course a huge, star-studded affair. Everyone who was anyone was there. After the screening, L.B. Mayer, then recently deposed head of MGM and one of the most powerful of all movie moguls stormed into the lobby. Billy Wilder was there, holding court, and enjoying praise from all. "You muckraking scum! You've ruined this town with this filthy picture! You and your kind are ruining our industry!" Mayer barked in Wilder's face. Wilder, with an ever so faint smirk on his face clucked his tongue and said "Go f@ck yourself"

reviews.review_title: Outstanding script along with excellent acting
reviews.content: Before I watched Sunset Blvd I knew it was an old 1950's classic in black and white, and I was slightly reluctant to put it on only because I was feeling a bit tired and wasn't sure if I was in the mood for something that required deep attention. But I was wrong, Sunset Blvd was actually a very easy to watch movie, it did not have an overly complicated plot. As soon as the movie began my eyes were glued to the television and my brain easily absorbed every single detail of the plot. What I also liked about it was that they kept it to a nice length, only 1 hour 50 minutes long. A similar film that I recently watched is All About Eve, which ran for 2 hours and 20 minutes, I felt that was a bit too long and they dragged out much longer than they should have. Sunset Blvd went by at a much more pleasant pace. In other words there was never a moment in which I zoned out. The characters in it were unique and intriguing. But what I liked most of all about the film was the screenplay, which is slightly ironic given that the film is from the point of view of a screenwriter. The one liners that the characters come out with are so artistically, smooth and poetic. This type of film writing is an art that has been lost in todays making of pictures. The acting performances was some of the best I've witnessed in a while, especially from Gloria Swanson. How she didn't win an Oscar for it I do not know. One thing I will say is that if you're not a fan of old fashioned films in general then you may not enjoy it because after all the film is in black and white and was made in the early 1950's. But you never know Sunset Blvd could be the exception.

Sunset Blvd. takes an interesting look at age and stardom. The film is well written with common tropes of the noir genre, such as the main character giving quite a bit of voice over narration. The characters are all very interesting, in that none of them are villainous. Every immoral action a character makes is very clearly justified to them, making it easy to empathize with all of the characters. Visually, the movie is very good. Shots are composed in a way that's very nice to look at, and the sets are very fitting for the story. When we're first introduced to the house, it has a subtle gothic feel to it, similar to Dracula's castle. This feel goes away as the film goes on, and we become more and more familiar with it.

reviews.review_title: A Billy Wilder classic; one for the ages
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's Sunset Blvd. is one of the better-known films from the golden age of cinema and one can see why. Sunset Boulevard was an extraordinary film that portrays the afterlife of has-been silent film actress, Norma Desmon, (portrayed by Gloria Swanson; a silent film actress herself) from the perspective of a struggling film writer, Joe Gillis ( portrayed by William Holden). The concept of the film was very unique and set the stage for well-known films such as Pulp Fiction. The film starts at what is actually the end of the film, with a dead man floating face down in a pool. I really like it when films do this because it gives you a taste of what's going to happen. It leaves you wondering.It wasn't until the film was nearing its end that it became clear that Joe Gillis was the dead man in the pool. I'm not sure if that was intentional but I couldn't really make out the face in the pool well enough to make the connection. This certainly didn't affect the outcome of the movie for me. I still enjoyed the surprise. The story itself is really captivating. It paints an interesting picture of Hollywood at the time and the silent film actors who suffered after the addition of sound to movies. Norma Desmond, lives a lonely life of luxury with her ex husband/director turned butler, Max Von Mayerling (portrayed by Erich Von Strohiem; a silent film director of his time). Buster Keaton, Hedda Hopper and Anna Q. Nilsson (portraying themselves) make a ghostly cameo at one of Norma Desond's card games, enjoying get together with old silent film pals. For some of those actors, it was their first role in forever, despite being beloved by millions on the silent film screens of the past. The choice to cast silent film actors and directors really helps convey the story director Billy Wilder is trying to tell. The film was a really enjoyable watch. The story was compelling and heartbreaking and I would recommend it to anyone who is interested in a tragic tale of struggling artists.

reviews.review_title: the best horror film of all time
reviews.content: sunset boulevard 50 years on remains the best movie ever made about Hollywood. a terrifying movie, all the more terrifying because it is true. everybody talks about Gloria Swanson's's magnificent performance, but it's William holden's cool persona, compared to Swanson's's over the top personality as Norma Desmond, that helps make the striking differences between the two main character more effective.horror is not about vampires or werewolves; it's about seeing the true, terrible reality of the world, and in a place called Hollywood where hypocrisy reigns supreme, stabbing in the back is the best known form of entertainment, there are victims such as Norma Desmond who are given the world and then have it taken away from her for ever.

DeMille, who unlike Norma Desmond, does not live or reminisce about the so called good old days. He has moved with the times, plus he has become an older respected figure in modern day Hollywood.The second highlight is the clever writing of the screenplay which was co-written by Billy Wilder.I recommend this film for movie buffs And tickled pink.

Sunset Boulevard was one of the first films to break from the hollywood system. It has a great and deep story. The only weakness i can find in it is the acting.

Sunset Boulevard is a classic. In 1950 when it was released, not everyone was thrilled - especially the head of MGM, Louis B. Mayer. He was upset at its dark portrayal of the inside of Hollywood. But he was in the minority. Luckily for us no one was able to stop the public from seeing the picture. It is one of the best movies made by director Billy Wilder and features former silent film stars, fresh faces, directors in acting roles, Hedda Hopper as herself, Jack Webb years before Dragnet fame, and a young William Holden in the lead. But the most amazing performance, by far, has to be the one given by Gloria Swanson - exceedingly dark and creepy! Funny, but she is playing sort of a version of herself - an aging, and largely forgotten star of silent films making comeback. Together, Swanson and Wilder create a character - Norma Desmond - who is equally bizarre and unforgettable. According to the documentary on the special edition DVD, Mae West and Mary Pickford, among others, were considered for, or offered the role of Norma before George Cukor suggested Swanson to Wilder over a casual lunch. Seeing the movie now, who would ever guess that she wasn't the first choice? There's no way the movie would be the treasure it is today without Swanson.The script is also top-notch with many memorable lines, none more so than the final one when Norma Desmond says: All right Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my close-up.*SPOILER*After shooting Joe (Holden) as he tries to leave her, Desmond utters another classic: No one ever leaves a star. And my favorite is this exchange: Joe: Hey, you're Norma Desmond. You used to be big. Norma: I'm still big! It's the pictures that got small. *SPOILER*The whole movie is seen through a flashback, narrated by the already-dead-and-floating-face-down-in-the-swimming-pool Joe. Our first view of him is from the bottom of the pool looking up into his face, with the police and photographers gathered at the side of the pool about to fish him out. A shot that could be easily recreated today - but not in 1950. To simulate the view from below, the cinematographer had to place a mirror in the pool and shoot from above the water level to capture the images that Wilder wanted. It's very effective - a creepy way to start a very creepy movie.

I've heard the name Sunset Boulevard repeatedly over my life, but I hadn't seen it until now. Since I'd heard it heralded as a classic, but didn't know much about it, I was excited to see it, and it was an interesting film to finally watch. This made some scenes feel dull or unappealing to watch because I didn't really care what happened to the characters. That being said, most scenes were still interesting, and it was still fun to see a "classic" old film.

Sunset boulevard was one of the most intricate movies that I have ever seen. It was brilliant and it showed flawed characters and how making certain types of choices reflects on how your life is going to be.
I didn't sympathize with any of the characters, I only had a slight preference for Betty, which was innocent, but too naive for my personal taste. I absolutely loved the expressiveness of Gloria Swanson (but since she was a famous silent movie actress I couldn't expect less than that). I am happy with the final: him not leaving when Betty asks him so is what males this movie "realistic".
We all hope love to triumph, justice to be made and the manipulators to lose, but in my opinion this movie wouldn't have been a classic if Joe had left with Betty. He made too many mistakes and lost his chances of saving himself, but instead he always preferred to keep living the way he was. At the end, his destiny was already sealed and deep down he knew what was gonna eventually happen.
Great movie, I enjoyed watching it and I recommend to watch it

Before 1950, I believe that films used to be strictly and only entertainment. Billy Wilder,Charles Brackett, and D.M. Marshall Jr, decided to change this ongoing struggle, creating an absolute masterpiece that would soon change the film scene forever.The images of the black and white sceneries are quite fascinating and unforgettable. The beginning of this film noir is in my opinion, one of the greatest openers to a film of all time. As the eerie quiet piano music plays in the back, the creepy, sinister narration creates a whole world questioning what happened to this dead body laying in the pool. The open eyes of the writer stares right into your soul, as you are excited to see what's next, but also confused to see why this is the beginning of the movie. I think this style of film making is the best because for me, I tend to lose my train of thought and get bored with long movies, but like this film noir, and some Tarantino films. The scene at the beginning of this film just keeps me on the edge of my seat the whole time.Sunset Blvd. is one of the finest Films ever made This has everything, dark humour, suspense, fantastic acting, flawless cinematography, and overall this is just a must-see for all movie lovers.

As I first started watching this movie. I did not expect it to be good. All other older movies I had seen had either been silent films, which significantly limits the depth of the story, or slapstick comedies which I am not the biggest fan of. surprisingly, it was a great story told in an interesting way. This movie definitely popularized this style of storytelling and set the stage for many movies to come.As far as I previously knew. Old movies in the Film Noir genre didn't have great stories, acting or cinematography. This movie piqued my interest and has guided my interest to watching more Film Noir movies in the future.

Sunset Blvd is an amazing film, with an incredible plot. This film teaches you so much about the influence fame can affect a person. This film has such an impact on the viewer. This film really keeps the viewer wanting to know what happens next. The plot twists are incredible and keeps you intrigued every second of the film. There wasn't a moment where i lost interest or didn't want to keep watching. Sunset Blvd is definitely a film because of the way it teaches you about the film industry back then and how people were treated. He did all this just for money and was very happy and thought all his problems had gone away but later in the movie he would find himself bored and unhappy even though he was very rich and had no financial problems. He then had an affair and was offered any amount of money but he left without any valuables or money and just wanted to go back to his old job and not be rich but be happy.

I'm new to "film noirs". While i've most definitely seen a few, and liked them, I never knew it was a whole genre of movies. Sunset Blvd is one of the most classic film noirs as it was made in the 50's, and film noirs became popular only a few years prior (40s.) This movie really influenced all of film for the following years. I enjoyed this movie, but the backstory to it and all the little random things I learned about it while reading articles made me like it even more. For example, one of the main characters Norma Desmond is played by Gloria Swanson who herself is a very well known silent film actress. It was her come back into the film word after many years and plenty movie opportunities offered to her. Knowing things like that about the movie (there are much more) make me more interested and impressed by the film.I liked this film a lot as its a heart-wrenching, soft yet intense story. It starts out with the classic film noir style.... A shot of main character Joe Gillis (played by William Holden) laying lifeless face down in a pool. It shocks you, and leaves you wanting more. I really enjoy this style of movie as I'm someone who has a very short attention span, meaning movies and films are sometimes hard for me to stay watching, but in this case I was intrigued a minute into the movie and stayed intrigued. I consider this production a film, as I can tell the creators of this movie made it with care and dedication, and not just to please the public. Also, this movie was way ahead of its time as I genuinely had no idea that it was made in the 50's until after the movie. It's incredibly well done for it's time, and gave a great example for the film industry. a lot of films and movies we know today wouldn't be the same without this film.If you consider yourself a film person... you need to watch this movie at least once.

What a wonderful and witty script, filled with cynicism and an immaculate set up of two characters-Joe Gillis and Norma Desmond-who are so different that they perfectly drive each other deeper into each other's hubris. The more I learned about the history of that time, and the wise allegory the film makes so ahead of its time, the more I appreciate this cinematic gem. It's hard to know where to begin. The larger than life settings are awesome in the true sense of the word: from the formidable and grotesque mansion (with more trinkets than those owned by the world's best hoarders), to the real film sets in Paramount Studios, and the humdrum writing office turned into a courting stage filled with spark and excitement. The acting is fantastic, and Gloria Swanson seems to have been born for this part-perhaps her creation of Norma was inspired by her own experience, being a silent film star herself.The intelligent plot and character development brings both Desmond and Gillis to self-destruct, and bury each other further in delusions, while staying entirely convincing throughout. The misery of both of them, and their consequent desperation and need for each other, makes the viewer even more engrossed in the picture and the inevitable fate of the two.There are not enough words to describe the magnificence and precociousness of this film-it simply needs to be experienced and taken in. How lucky to have been able to watch it on the big screen! Thank you TCM.

reviews.review_title: A Cool Concept With Okay-Ish Excecution
reviews.content: I found Sunset Boulevard to be pretty alright, personally. There wasn't anything that I found particularly jumped out as wild or interesting, but that might just be my view from here in 2019. Back in the 50's when this was released, I'm sure it was a lot more nfluential and out of the box. It did a good job of the Film Noir style, with the main character not being the 'shiny perfect' guy, instead having flaws and not exactly being the most likeable. But all in all, there was nothing very memorable about it. The plot fell flat, and I didn't find myself caring about the characters as much as I should have.

reviews.review_title: Historically Significant but Modern Day Uncomfortable
reviews.content: Sunset Boulevard made me extremely uncomfortable, I will not lie. The film itself was pretty good, on the surface it could have passed as a movie even. It was easy to follow, the cinematography was pretty good, the soundtrack was fitting, it was overall well made. It was filmed as a movie, I would say, but it is a film. The cinematography may not have been super artsy, and the story may have been simple enough, but it still made me think. It made me wonder: about people, about history, about humanity, and that is what makes it a film. And sure, one could watch it and see it simply as a movie and still be entertained, but to watch it as a film I think is a different experience. To pay attention to the history being told, the historical perspective of the story and it's characters, the underlying human emotions that riddled the story... It makes a huge difference. But it still made me uncomfortable. Norma Desmond made me very uncomfortable as a character. She was desperate and unhinged and messy, and honestly, she was creepy. I didn't like her at all, which I would say means that Gloria Swanson did a fantastic job at making the character seem real. Her emotions were too much, her selfishness was believable and horrible to watch, her dramatics were cringeworthy and awful. I hated it, but I also can appreciate that it means the story was told well. When someone feels as much disdain towards (most of the characters) in this film as I did, then the storytelling is going well. As much as I found this film difficult to watch after a while, I have to say that I was intrigued to how it would end, and that's good when watching a film noir, because the end is the most important part. I think Sunset Boulevard set a strong precedent for the film noirs to follow it. I don't know much about the film noir genre, this is one of two film noirs I've seen in my life, but I have heard it is well known, well appreciated, and historically important for the film industry, and so I think whatever amazing films and stories came out of its existence were probably well worth the work it took to make it.

Gloria Swanson's performance is one that is over-the-top and melodramatic, but in the best possible sense. It's the way Desmond knew how to live. She gained fame by working her hands and face. She was an expert in conveying emotion strictly through body language. The lack of sound in her films demanded it. The result in Sunset Boulevard is a sympathetic character that is also one of the best villains of all-time.Sunset Boulevard also shows that our obsession with fame and maintaining it aren't new. Although much can be said and written about the hyper-invasive tabloid times in which we currently live, it's really a dream that's been around for a very long time. Desmond needs the spotlight to survive. Outside of it, she struggles to survive. The need to be remembered and, in a sense, worshiped, is what drives her and her passions. But like every film, it's all an act and one that ultimately cannot be maintained while still remaining sane.Arturo Montenora

reviews.review_title: What a bizarre, psychologically draining ride
reviews.content: This movie deserves all of its fame. It is the creepiest movie I've seen in recent memory, but not in the usual way. In fact, it is a perfectly believable story about perfectly believable people -- no supernatural stuff. And yet, man, what a draining film.I could go on and on, but I'll keep my review covering just the most salient points. Perhaps the most important of these is that the movie explores the concept of wealth combined with loneliness better than any other I've seen to date. Norma's desperate cries, the large house they live in, the strange things that seem to always be happening; I think whenever I think of the combination of wealth and loneliness again in the future, Norma Desmond is the character I will have in my mind. This is one of the great movies about Hollywood. Even if you're not interested in that stuff though, you'll still find something to your liking here. Just watch it.

Sunset Boulevard is a classic movie from the 50s which was deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" by the U.S. Library of Congress. When the movie started and I saw the body floating in the swimming pool I could see that til the end I would be hooked to the story, and indeed I was. Gloria Swanson perfomance was just brilliant and amazing without her the movie probably wouldn't be the same, but my favorite character is Max, he's such an interesting character.
But one question kept me thinking, what would happen if Joe abandoned Norma and went to Betty? Well, my conclusion is that the movie would end like the others, with a happy ending, that's why I liked it, that made the film fascinating for me

I think most people agree with me, when I say that this is a great classic that has influenced a lot of other movies, even long after it was made. But would that have been the same, if Joe would have run away with Betty in the end?
In my opinion: No. Sure, the film would have been good nonetheless, because of its many small details, also because of plot twists like Max being Norma's first husband. All of those features would have made that a generally good film, but I still think that it wouldn't be the classic it is today if it weren't for the ending, because the ending plays a big part in making this film extraordinary. If Joe would have left with Betty, this would have been a good romance, but nothing more. It would have been too predictable and mediocre. The fact that he didn't leave with Betty, is what makes the film stand out, which I think is the reason for it being a classic.

The story is set in Los Angeles, where the screenwriterJoe Gillis, who is having a hard time, ends up by chance in the beautiful house of Norma Desmond on Sunset Boulevard. Norma is a former star of silent cinema who lives dreaming of her return to the scene. She will convince Joe to help her, however with time he will realize that she "imprisoned" him in that house anche he will try to "escape" lieing to her.A central character throughout the movie il Betty. We see her at the beginning of the play and as the movie goes on she becomes more important. Almost at the end Joe will have to chose between Betty and Norma: Betty offers him to go away together, but Joe refuses deciding to live with none of the two.
This decision will cost to Joe his own life, as Norma kills him in order to stop him from leaving her.
It would have been easy to make Joe go away with Betty and so give a food ending to this masterpiece. So why it didn't happen?
Going away with Betty to live with her would have meant that Joe didn't grow from all the experiences he lived and so all the development that the character undergoes throughout the movie would have been wasted.Just after watching the movie and analysing it you understand why so many people love it and why it is still appreciated nowadays.
