Sunset Boulevard tells the tale of a young, down-on-his-luck screewriter, Joe Gillis (William Holden), and his bizarre relationship with an aging silent film star, Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson). Joe narrates for the viewers beginning with the results of a tragic event. He then recounts his chance meeting with Norma by pulling into a random driveway on Sunset Boulevard to escape the men trying to repossess his car. When she learns that Joe is a screenwriter, Norma employs him to help finalize a screenplay she wrote for DeMille to direct. Out of a lack of better options (I.e. any options), Joe reluctantly takes the job. After having lived in her house for so many years with no one, but herself and her butler Max (Erich von Stroheim), Norma turns her and Joe's simple working relationship into something toxic. Sunset Boulevard is a story of forgotten glory, ludicrous ambitions, and selfish desire. It is a landmark of American cinema and is worth any individual's time to enjoy.

This movie has Hollywood telling on itself. Whereas, that may seem commonplace today, it was probably pretty rare for 1950. If you like old movies, there is a lot to be said for this one. The aging starlet, who watches her own films, on a projection screen hidden behind a painting, in her living room, is something else. About ten years later, The Twilight Zone television program did a great takeoff on this concept, in an episode called, "The Sixteen Millimeter Shrine", starring Ida Lupino. That episode was what persuaded me to someday find "Sunset Boulevard", and give it a looking-at. Turns out, it's a great movie, and I can see why it was often imitated and spoofed.

I adored Holden in this. His voice-over, especially. But... I think this movie have gone in the wrong direction. Yes, it's good all that stuff about pathological Hollywood's inner life, transiency and fatalism of film-noir anti-heroes, but I excepted story about Holden trying to find inspiration for his writings in those dark and crazy corners of Sunset Blvd... He would eventually become crazy, too. Now that would be great! Gloria Swanson's 'eager-for-attention' acting is nice, but maybe somewhat overacted. Cinematography is beautiful, though. After all, I find this movie overpriced. 8.7? Come on! Sunset Blvd. is good film-noir, but it's silly to consider it as one of the best movies ever produced.

reviews.review_title: SUNSET BLVD - Possibly THE great American film....
reviews.content: Billy Wilder's SUNSET BLVD is possibly THE greatest American film yet made. This is a powerful statement (or assumption) to make, considering there are other outstanding American films which could vie, perhaps, for such stature. Yet SUNSET is in the rare position of being among a handful of films that are achievements of cinema perfection, and these works have in common one very important quality that secures their artistic status - sublime momentum.  SUNSET is a mesmerizing experience from beginning to end, its continuity a seamless triumph of cinematic construction.  With a cynically incisive script which never once falters, and an exquisite style and look that is visually breathtaking throughout, SUNSET BLVD is a spellbinding and unforgetable piece of filmmaking from one of the world's great 20th Century artists, Billy Wilder, who is arguably the best of the best in American cinema.  True, he's contributed his share of mediocrity, and worse; but, then, there isn't an artist dead or alive who hasn't failed aesthetically at one time or another.  What Billy Wilder has given us with SUNSET BLVD and his other great films are treasures to cherish.

reviews.review_title: Amazing life imitates art tragic Hollywood story.
reviews.content: One of the best ever films about Hollywood and the double-edged sword life in the old Hollywood Studio system.Billy Wilder Directs amazing performances from Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond, a faded Silent Film star deludingly trying to reclaim her glorious past and William Holden as Joe Gillis, an indebted 'Boy wonder' Screenwriter who is running from the law when he accidentally finds refuge at the former Silent Film star's Hollywood mansion.Also an uncanny, excellent performance from real life legendary film maker Eric Von Stroheim as Norma Desmond's loyal serving and empathetic butler for many years.The film does an absolutely brilliant job of showing both the glamorous and tragic sides of the heyday of classic era Hollywood.

reviews.review_title: An exquisitely creepy, and alluring portrayal of '50s Hollywood. Must see.
reviews.content: Sunset Blvd.'s appeal lies in its exquisitely creepy and alluring portrayal of '50s Hollywood. Its timelessness and ability to retain relevance more than sixty years after its release is especially ironic considering the plight of its lead, the eccentric faded silent-film star, Norma who despite her desperate and obsessive attempts to cling to her former stardom, remains obsolete. The unique ambiguity between reality and fiction achieved via the casting choices adds depth and allows for audiences to look past the illusion of the glitz and magic of the industry and witness a story of failure that was, at the time, uncharacteristic to the typical film climate of Hollywood escapist pictures. The mordant wit and lavish, Gothic set design are aspects that add to the overall tone of this gorgeously grotesque classic. Both Norma and Gillis are outsiders, teetering on the edge of obscurity, caught in the claw-like grip of hopeless need and desire to make it in the industry. Wilder's film captures the callous nature of the studio system, through the narrative of Gillis and the investigation surrounding his mysterious murder. MGM executive, Louis B. Mayer's reported disgust at this film had much to do with the belief that the movie was a disgrace to Hollywood. Sunset Blvd.'s portrayal of Norma was terribly offensive to the industry, which "relied heavily on the power of illusion" (Culbertson 2006). Mayer's revulsion must only have been magnified as the film went on to win three Oscars and an enduring place in Hollywood history.

What a film. Written and directed by Billy Wilder, this film encapsulates the mania of Hollywood through three characters. This film is fantastic for how well it has aged, not at all like Norma Desmond - still true to it's themes of obsession and self-image. Time for my close-up, DeMill!In this story we're introduced to hack screenwriter Joe Gillis. With only a few B movies to his name, he struggles to put out scripts from his Hollywood apartment. Being chased down by the insurance company for late car payments, he decides to hide his car in the worst possible house he could've found in the hills, the house of Norma Desmond.A great film about film-making, this is one of Billy Wilder's best. It makes satire of the business of Hollywood tying an intriguing plot, bittersweet, funny, and reminiscent of an era. Dealing with many intra-personal problems, you will find either great comedy withing this film or great drama. This film is fantastic, and if you haven't seen it, you're doing yourself a great disservice.

You see all of his emotions very well throughout the film, when he's angry, when he feels sorry for Norma, and the helplessness on his face when he finds out Norma is madly in love with him, and he can't do anything. We just returned from Europe and "Sunset Blvd" was playing on the airline's Classic Movie Channel. I watched the whole thing twice, after having watched it dozens of times over the years. I was struck again by just how timeless this film is, in every way. Every aspect is perfect--the dialogue, the casting, the cinematography, the costumes & set, the soundtrack, and of course the brilliant acting & directing.Others in this comment section have written wonderful plot summaries and spoken to technical features so I won't repeat. I will point out just two things that I noticed: 1) When Swanson visits DeMille at Paramount, and he tells her to sit in his chair and watch for a bit, she is almost hit in the head by, of all things, a microphone on a boom. Annoyed, she pushes it firmly out of the way and out of the screen. Just priceless! What an inspired bit of symbolic "business"; it so beautifully, almost subliminally, underlines her feelings about how the movies have disintegrated into "talk, talk, talk". 2) In the final scene, when Swanson is descending the staircase, the figures of the spectators are arranged just as carefully as those on a bas-relief frieze over a Roman temple. The composition is stunning! Even as the camera follows Swanson down the stairs, she passes people in poses just as static and stylized as statues. Another example of inspired juxtaposition of old and new--true genius at work. I wonder how many arrangements of people Wilder considered, and discarded, before he came up with this very specific one.An incredible achievement in every way, even more amazing considering the year it was made. God bless everyone who labored to preserve this film for the rest of us. Thank you, Billy Wilder.

Yes, Gloria Swanson's acting is slightly over the top in this drama however, for this movie it works! The reason why it works is because her character "Norma Desmond" a once famous silent screen actress from yester-year is stuck in the days gone by when actresses didn't need words because they had (what she refers to as)"Faces" and every expression was over dramatized on film to get the story across to the viewer. However, these over theatrics and acts of grandeur is something she carried into her real life... which seems fitting when you take into account this is a woman who thinks of herself as larger than life.Not only has Norma refused to accept that the now popular "Talkies" has taken over the movie industry but, she also still has it in her head that she was and still is the greatest actress that ever was...... In her mind,time hasn't really passed by or, passed her by because she's "Still big. It's the movies that got small".Swanson is marvelous as a woman who is obviously delusional and to make matters worst... mentally unstable. William Holden is perfect as the down-on-his luck Hollywood writer who had the misfortune to form a bond with the great Norma Desmond and Erich Von Stroheim is wonderful as Norma's faithful servant. If I have wish about this movie..... It would be to learn more on how his character "Max" became her servant.This is a classic movie that I never tire of watching every couple of years.
